PETITION.TITLE: Judeo-Christian Values
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are concerned that the Judeo-Christian moral values which have been fundamental in our laws and education systems since the foundation of the country are now being undermined in the current practice of law making, and we are concerned that the values of the secular-humanistic philosophy have taken their place therefore jeopardizing the moral climate of our society and contributing towards immorality and violence in our society.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate for the restoration of Judeo-Christian laws and moral values.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Relocation of Transylvanian Village Dwellers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens and residents of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate, the plan proposed by the Government of Rumania, to re-structure the Rumanian countryside. Some 7,000 villages, many of them in Transylvania, at this time still occupied by the descendants of those Hungarian extraction citizens of Rumania, whose ancestors lived there for over 1,000 years, are earmarked for total destruction. The Rumanian Government's intention is that no trace of such inhabitation remain. The reasons proposed for the destruction, that is: to ``provide arable land'', is nothing but a ruse.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully urge the Senate, to ask the Australian Government, to call on Rumania to forthwith desist from any action envisaged in the bulldozer-policy.

Rumania signed many international instruments which provided guarantees to the human rights and the rights of the minorities living in Rumania. Now the rights of all people living in the 7,000 villages are in danger of not only being eroded, but irrevocably destroyed.
The destruction would not only affect homes, the monuments, the cemeteries and the churches, some 9024 (!) churches of many denominations, would disappear forever.

PETITION.TITLE: In-vitro Fertilisation Patients: Medicare Funding
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable, The President and Members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows a request for Medicare benefits for in-vitro fertilisation for the medical treatment of infertile couples.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled grant Medicare benefits for in-vitro fertilisation, IVF, for the medical treatment of infertile couples. 1 in 10 Australian couples are infertile and unable to conceive and carry a baby to birth. Having a family is one of the most fundamental and rewarding aspects of life and benefits the community as a whole. IVF is an established and proven treatment for infertility. There are existing mechanisms to regulate and control IVF, including the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Reproductive Technology Accreditation Committee. Currently IVF patients pay up to $1500 per treatment cycle for IVF out of their own pockets. This means that some couples who need IVF to help them establish their own family do not have access. We request that Medicare funding be granted for IVF for the treatment of infertility, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them, for cost saving reasons only, on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra Bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that is is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senators in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That it be recognised the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill is a public, legal acknowledgement that Australians who are non-aboriginal do not have sovereignty in their own country.

2. That the Australian people are opposed to the idea of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Australian people who are non-aboriginal and those who are aboriginal, and the Government has no mandate or authority to pursue it.
3. That the proposed legislation and treaty
will damage Australia's position under international law and in any conflict,
will cause distrust and conflict between our aboriginal population (1%) and the non-aboriginal population (99%),
will extend aboriginal land rights, contrary to the wishes of the Australian people,
will not be acceptable to the aboriginal people themselves,
will solve none of the problems of aboriginal people who need housing, health services, education and employment.

That therefore, the Senate reject absolutely the announced proposals for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, and the negotiation of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Commonwealth and aboriginal people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions and Fringe Benefits Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We are gravely concerned at the Government's proposal to reduce significantly the pension and access to fringe benefits of persons who in good faith bought market linked insurance bonds, friendly society bonds, approved deposit funds, deferred annuities and unit trusts to protect their savings.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, amend the proposed legislation to ensure that it will not apply retrospectively and that provision is made to protect savings against inflation.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Senators in Parliament assembled,
The humble petition of the undersigned Citizens and Residents of Australia (of Albanian background from Kosova in Yugoslavia), showeth:

(i) We draw attention to the House that in Kosova, we have left behind our Fathers and Mothers, Brothers and Sisters, our relatives and above all our people, whom we love very dearly-that is why we fear for their well being.

(ii) In recent times, Albanian people have been under enormous oppression and terror from the greater Serb ``Communist'' Leader Milosevic and his Nationalist-chauvinist elite, whom the Weekend Australian of 24/25, 9, 88 parallels with the Nazi propagandist Goebbels.

(iii) Albanians in Yugoslavia are being imprisoned en masse and many are being murdered in mysterious ways; Quote: ``Xhemail Blakaj (22) was arrested on 3/11/86 and on 8/11/86 was said to have ``Committed suicide'', his family was told of his ``death'' on 11/11/86 when instructed to collect his body. Many Australians, and indeed people of other nations, are, for the first time, becoming aware of and concerned about the implications of what is commonly termed `the greenhouse effect'. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was speaking on the Appropriation Bills on Wednesday I was stating that the competition between the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has reached the point where the real economic management of the country is in jeopardy. Many of the statements emanating from the Government at present do not truly reflect the state of the economy and its outlook. In recent times we have seen statistics rolling out on inflation and the balance of payments which demonstrate quite clearly that the Government does not have its hand firmly on the tiller of the nation. Many of the problems can be sheeted home to the internal political problems within the Australian Labor Party. Those pressures are generating very great concern in the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: In order to put the argument into perspective, perhaps we could examine the stewardship of the Labor Party since it came to power in 1983 by looking quickly at two or three indicators. First, if we measure Government expenditure against gross domestic product we see that, after appropriate adjustments are made for such things as asset sales by the Government, the percentage of Commonwealth expenditure as a proportion of total product in the country has not fallen at all. This is quite contrary to the Government's claims. Secondly, if we look at taxation, we see that in 1983 it represented 26.4 per cent of the gross domestic product of the country. That has now risen to over 27.4 per cent. In other words, the Government has failed those two critical tests of its management to reduce its involvement in the total community. Of course, the Government would have us believe otherwise.

Looking at some of the other relevant statistics we notice that the taxation applied in 1983 by the Hawke-Keating Government to ordinary individuals comprised 51.3 per cent of total collections. In this financial year that has risen to 54.3 per cent. In other words, the pay as you earn taxpayer is bearing far more of the taxation burden now than when the Hawke Government first came to power, and the people of Australia know it. They know that they have been had by this Government.

We have been somewhat negative in our comments about the Government but let us try to examine where we are going. The only way that this country can really improve its situation with the repayment of its huge debt that it faces in the future is to improve its productivity. Productivity of course is the volume of goods and services that are produced per head of population in the country. With the balance of payments crisis, the debt crisis that Australia faces, one would have thought that the Hawke-Keating Government would have been putting a great deal of effort into trying to improve the productivity of the nation. Yet if we look at just the last four quarters of the last financial year, we see that the total productivity per person in this country has in fact declined quite significantly. Since the September quarter last year productivity has gone down from 100.3 on the index to 98.9.

With the crisis we have in this area, we would have expected the reverse to occur, that there would have been an improvement in productivity, that incentives would have been provided through tax reductions for people who worked harder so that we would have seen some improvement in people's ability to earn more if they worked harder. As a result, productivity would have improved. But no, that is not the result. The reverse is occurring. Through high taxes and disincentives imposed by this Government and all kinds of restrictive labour practices in various areas, this Government has failed to improve our productivity. It is productivity that will determine the final outcome of our economy. It will determine whether we can repay that huge mountain of debt-debt having trebled since this Government came to power in 1983.

Other areas of concern regarding this Government's management have caused and are causing significant worry to Australians. I refer first to the activities in our financial markets. We have seen recently the collapse of Rothwells merchant bank in Perth and the ramifications that that has had for the financial system generally. It comes as a shock, though, that the Treasurer, in reply to a question in the House of Representatives the other day by the Opposition's financial spokesman, Dr Hewson, about the financial collapse of Rothwells bank, was able to dismiss the suggestion that the ripples rolling outwards from the collapse of Rothwells will have an effect on the financial system.

This is very disturbing, because we know, firstly, that that company has been put into liquidation; secondly, that the auditors are finding it very difficult to put together the financial statements of Rothwells in order to find out its exact financial position; and, thirdly, the National Companies and Securities Commission NCSC, which is the national securities watchdog, is conducting investigations and collecting documents preparatory to an exercise designed to determine what has gone on in Rothwells in recent times. I applaud what the NCSC is doing in this area. We would like to see it moving faster. We would like to see it properly resourced so that it can undertake a thorough examination of Rothwells affairs and its associated companies to ensure that we get to the bottom of the cause of the collapse. I think it behoves the Government to take a far more serious view of what has happened in Rothwells and in the Western Australia Inc. scene, as it is called, than it has to date.

Rothwells after the recent collapse has ended up being virtually a shell-from which $400m, $500m or maybe $600m has disappeared. When one analyses the statistics and figures one can see that there is a very real danger that the Western Australian Government will be obliged to pay into Rothwells funds, when the liquidator calls upon it, a sum of at least $150m to cover a debt to the National Australia Bank. That debt has been cleared, but, quite clearly, there is a question mark over those payments and they could well be called back by a liquidator as a preference.

The second thing that is of great concern in relation to Rothwells is the creation, by nefarious means, of an investment of $400m in a company called Petrochemical Industries Co. Ltd. When one analyses the assets of that company, PICL-and it really is in a pickle-we find that it has virtually none. It owns a block of land worth about $200,000. It has certain heads of agreement in its name concerning the supply of gas to it by the gas producers in Western Australia. It also has some agreements, apparently signed for the sale of the product of the proposed works-some plastic materials-but at prices which are only equal to what can be supplied by Taiwan or any other Asian nation. There is, therefore, not much prospect of this company reaching a very great state of productivity and profit.

We see that $400m has been invested in this organisation-an organisation with virtually no assets. The question needs to be asked: Just what has happened to the $400m? Does it exist? Is there value in PICL or not? The answer that we can determine at the moment from published records is that there is no value to PICL. Consequently, the $400m invested in that company really constitutes a nothing; a piece of paper-nothing else.

Who has invested that $400m? The facts are that through a series of transactions too complicated to mention here, the Bond Corporation has a paper investment of $225m in the petrochemical company. The Western Australian Government through the Western Australian Development Corporation has invested $175m in cash on loan from the State Government Insurance Office. That is then a further risk that the taxpayers of Western Australia have in respect of the wash-up of Rothwells. It appears that at the moment there is a total commitment and obligation of $175m at risk in the petrochemical operation-an operation which, of course, has not started, and does not look like starting. There is the possibility of a further loss of $150m from the repayment of the guarantee for the National Australia Bank. That represents a total of over $300m. There are far too many questions that cannot be swept under the carpet with just a cursory examination of the figures I have mentioned.

The fact remains that the taxpayers of Western Australia are exposed, by a series of transactions that have been undertaken, by up to $300m. This is an absolute tragedy for them because, obviously, it will mean higher taxes and charges for the people of Western Australia as the Western Australian State Government seeks to recover the funds in the event of loss. The taxpayers are certainly at significant risk. On the other hand, the Bond Corporation has received repayment of a great part of the moneys it had deposited with Rothwells-something in the order of $200m. One could say that virtually the investment I have just mentioned in Petrochemical Industries by the Western Australian Government of something like $175m has in fact been funnelled out through Rothwells to the Bond Corporation. Consequently that represents a repayment of its debt by way of a loan from the Western Australian Government. Of course, the people at risk are the Western Australian taxpayers.

I mentioned that the NCSC is presently conducting an examination of the affairs of Rothwells. I believe, however, that it needs to take the matter further and to do that quickly. I believe that there is a crying need for the National Companies and Securities Commission to immediately institute a public hearing into the affairs of Rothwells to determine what has happened to the organisation's funds, to determine who is at risk-whether it is the Bond Corporation, the Western Australian taxpayers via the Western Australian Government, or other persons connected with Mr Connell who, of course, was the Managing Director of Rothwells; and his various associates. I believe that those questions have to be addressed now. They have to be addressed now because as time goes by memories change and, of course, documents disappear, as might money disappear-money which ought to finds its way into the hands of creditors to whom that money is properly due. I think that is the first point that has to be noted. The NCSC should immediately institute a public hearing process into what has happened with Rothwells bank.

Secondly, because of the way in which Rothwells has been transacting its business across the various State boundaries and the way in which it has been collecting funds from depositors in Queensland, the Queensland Government, through its Premier, Mr Ahern, should immediately institute a royal commission into the transactions that occurred at the time of the creation of the Rothwells merchant bank. There should be an investigation of the role of Sir Edward Lyons, who at the time was Chairman of the Queensland TAB, and his role in depositing money with Rothwells bank in Western Australia. The Premier of Queensland, Mr Ahern, should set up that investigation immediately as a proper judicial inquiry with royal commission powers. That is fully appropriate to demonstrate to the people of Queensland, if nobody else, that the investments in Rothwells were undertaken with proper consideration of the risks involved. The people of Queensland demand that that occur. I believe it should happen as soon as possible.

Thirdly, there are many unanswered questions about the Federal Government's role in relation to Rothwells. Many of those questions have been discussed in the Parliament. I invite honourable senators to recall that in 1974 the Federal Parliament passed a law called the Financial Corporations Act, part of which requires merchant banking organisations to report to the Reserve Bank of Australia each month on their financial position. The part of the Act which touches that question, however, has never been proclaimed by any government. In answer to a question in the House of Representatives the other day, the Treasurer chose to use that fact as an excuse for the Reserve Bank's not properly surveying the financial affairs of Rothwells bank. In fact, the Treasurer slipped out from under in his obligations on that. That is simply not good enough. If the Reserve Bank was not properly exercising its role of overseeing the financial affairs of Rothwells, surely there was enough information about in the general financial community for the Government to be alerted to the dangers of various kinds of investments in Rothwells. The point needs to be noted that reports were given to the Reserve Bank by Rothwells and that those reports, on the face of it, may well have been incorrect and false reports, in which case the financial position of Rothwells may have been misrepresented to the Government. That matter needs to be investigated by the Reserve Bank-even though it is so late-and certainly the Treasurer should take an interest in it.

The point of real concern is: if the Reserve Bank did not have a role in overseeing the affairs of Rothwells, who did? It is somewhat at odds with reports in the newspapers this week that the Reserve Bank has been ringing around various banking institutions in the last month to determine their exposure to Rothwells. The information that had been provided previously in the returns, which the Treasurer claims were not actually examined or taken seriously, was available to the Reserve Bank all the way through. Many questions need to be answered in that area. Consequently, it behoves the Federal Government to move immediately to institute a royal commission into the affairs of Rothwells bank at the Federal level. Of course, it should coordinate with the State corporate affairs commissions. It should coordinate with the National Companies and Securities Commission. It should coordinate with the various State governments in view of the information they have at their fingertips. I mention particularly the Western Australian Government in that context.

We also have the very important question of the role in the affairs of Rothwells of the financial institutions under the control of the Western Australian Government. The Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia has lent money to Rothwells. We also have Western Australian Government Holdings with its loan to the State Government Insurance Office. All of these are at risk. The Treasurer's statement that there is no risk to the financial affairs of this nation or of the financial community generally from Rothwells collapse is totally without reality. There are many unanswered questions concerning the role of the Queensland and Western Australian governments in the affairs of the various institutions over which they have control. The way in which money was invested in Rothwells by Queensland and Western Australian government instrumentalities, trade unions, charities and other organisations at the behest of the Western Australian Government causes Australian investors and the financial community generally very real worry.

The Federal Government and Mr Hawke and Mr Keating should move immediately to set up a royal commission to examine the affairs of Rothwells. If we had the power in the Senate I would certainly be prepared to move a motion to that effect. The Government should give immediate consideration to that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The economic situation we now find ourselves in is far different from the one that was presented to us at Budget time. It is far worse than the problems we then thought we faced. They have certainly been dramatised to be far worse. One could almost chart the way in which our economic prospects have declined and our economic problems have been built up by the heat and fervour of the push by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to become Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: At Budget time when the forecasts were high, when governmental expectations were great, when everything was fine and the world's greatest Treasurer had solved all the problems, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was under immense threat from the Treasurer. All around Australia there were reports of the deals being done by the Treasurer to try to usurp Mr Hawke's position. What has happened to those pressures? The answer is very simple: the economy has gone bad. Mr Keating's forecasts were wrong. There are now serious troubles facing us, as in fact the Opposition said at the time the Budget was brought down. Coincidentally, Mr Keating's push for leadership has evaporated because he has made a mess of the one issue on which he had any sort of foundation in his push for prime ministership, that is, the economy. Anyone who looks at the political scene is aware of that simple fact. We have only to look at the recent economic indicators that have been coming out to see just how wrong Mr Keating was in his Budget about the economic prospects we face this year.

The assumptions on which the Budget was based, the assumptions which Mr Keating made and trumpeted at Budget time, have been proved dramatically wrong. The more they are proved wrong the more Mr Keating's push for power, his attempt to usurp Mr Hawke, has been brushed aside. It is simply no coincidence that Mr Keating's evident attempts to undermine Mr Hawke have eased up. It is no coincidence that no longer do his henchmen, such as Mr Dawkins, go to the Prime Minister and tell him that he must stand aside before the next election to enable Mr Keating to have at least a few months as Prime Minister before the Australian Labor Party gets defeated at the next polls. All that has ended, and it has ended for one simple reason-because Mr Keating has been clearly shown to have been incompetent in the Budget which we are now discussing. The veneer of the world's greatest Treasurer certainly has not lasted to push him to become, in his view, the world's greatest Prime Minister. Let us face it: if he maintained the same mistake rate, if he ever did get the Prime Ministership, it would be for a very short period.

Let us see how much the Government's strategy has been shot to ribbons; for example, by the huge blow-out in the external deficit on the balance of payments. In the first four months the loss in our overseas dealings has blown out to $5.4 billion. The Budget forecast was $9.5 billion for the whole year. It is well over half that after only four months. In fact, if the present rate continued the blow-out would be about $16 billion for the full year, as against $9.5 billion in the Budget. I do not expect that to take place, but there is no doubt that the Budget target, which is one of the key assumptions of the Budget on which the economic plan for the nation was set by Mr Keating, has blown out enormously. It has occurred because, according to the latest figures, exports are down and there has been a huge rise in imports. This has provided us with our worst trade balance for years.

Just to show how serious this is, Senator Walsh said in an answer to a question in this place, I think this week, that the external deficit on the balance of payments could go up by up to 4 per cent this year. Senator Walsh got very little press for admitting that. The media chose to ignore that most extraordinary admission. For Senator Walsh to admit that the deficit could go up by up to 4 per cent means that this year's deficit could be over $12 billion. There has been an admission by the Finance Minister that the external deficit could end up at over $12 billion, which would be worse than last year's figure. We can imagine what effect it would have on Budget forecasts if our external deficit-our balance of payments deficit-was even bigger than last year's disastrous result. We can see that on this one key assumption on which this Budget was based there has been a major error.

There is a major need for the Government to look again at its economic policy. There is no doubt that if these figures keep up there will have to be a May mini-Budget-another admission of mistake. What is particularly irritating about these mistakes which have taken place consistently under this Government is that on every occasion the Opposition has pointed out where the Government has been wrong and what it should do. We have been proved consistently right. The Government has been proved consistently wrong, particularly going back to the first two Budgets which, in fact, undermined our economic recovery.

The 1983-84 and 1984-85 Budgets were absolutely disastrous for this country and we are still paying the price for those reckless increases in government spending. It is all very well for the Government to say now, `But we have cut in since', but the fact is that it should never have been increased. Government spending was increased by extraordinary volumes by the Treasurer in those two Budgets. It is largely because of those two disastrous Budgets that this Government has had to respond so vigorously-and, I must say, has at least recognised the problem, if it has not dealt with it properly-and savagely, according to some people, in some areas.

The fact is that there has not been enough reduction in government spending. There has not been enough genuine fiscal policy restraint by this Government, with the result that the people of Australia have to carry the burden in the huge interest rates that this Government is now imposing upon us. That is another of the assumptions on which this Budget was based which have been blown aside by what has actually happened. According to the Budget Papers, monetary policy was to remain firm, not get more severe and not have huge rises in interest rates. Instead we have interest rates going through the roof. The extent of that rise is only too evident to those people who have borrowed to build a home. The problem facing people who want to be home buyers in this nation are so clearly evident and so disastrous. The Sydney Morning Herald ran a very interesting article last Saturday under the headline `The new price of a home-no kids for 10 years'. The article went on:
Many young couples are agreeing to put off having children for up to 10 or 15 years to qualify for a home loan in Sydney.
This is because both partners' incomes are committed to the limit to pay the mortgage.

That is one of the prices of incompetent economic management by this Government. Interest rates are now pricing so many young Australians out of the prospect of owning their own home. Another of the major assumptions on which Mr Keating's economic strategy was set for this year and on which this Budget was based has been blown aside.

Inflation is another key basic assumption on which this Budget that we are discussing today was built. Inflation has blown out. That destroys any chance of meeting the Budget target of 5 1/2 per cent. The Budget Papers show that the Government expected the inflation rate by the end of the year to be down to 4 1/2 per cent. The latest 12 months figures show that inflation is up to 7.3 per cent as against this target. This is way beyond the Government's year end forecast of about 4 1/2 per cent. What is the Government doing about this? Clearly, one of the reasons why it has jacked up interest rates so high is to try to calm down economic activity, to hit the private sector, to hit ordinary Australians, and to reduce their economic activity. These people are suffering the burden of a problem that has been generated by the Government's refusal to cut its own spending. We have heard some extraordinary comments and some remarkable claims from this Government about its restraint. The Government has no interest in actually reducing its expenditure. Page 12 of the Forward Estimates that came out only this week says:
Current Outlays on the Commonwealth's own behalf are not expected to change in real terms in 1988-89.

In the current year this means there will be no cut in real terms-that is, after we account for inflation-on the Commonwealth's own current outlays. This is set out in the report, but that is not the rhetoric we hear from this Government; all we hear about are the dramatic and enormous cuts that have been made. We hear Senator Walsh saying that there is no scope for further major cuts in Government spending. I do not know what he means by `further'. The Forward Estimates say:
Current Outlays on the Commonwealth's own behalf are not expected to change in real terms in 1988-89.

In other words, most of the figures which it has been using to try to show it has cut its expenditure are fudged figures. They are crooked figures. This report reveals that the Government is not cutting its expenditure in the current year. In its capital spending this Government has been guilty of a multi-million dollar fraud in hiding the real size of its capital spending. That multi-million dollar fraud relates to the $250m-odd that it has hidden, that is really capital expenditure. But the Government has decided to make the purchases on time payment, so we do not see what the real level of spending is.

I pursued the matter in Senate Estimates hearings. We found that the Government will be paying for its Parramatta office for something like 10 years. This kind of inventive accounting enables the Treasurer and the Finance Minister to pretend that there have been great cuts in government spending. Yet we know the reality. According to the Commonwealth Department of Finance in its report on Forward Estimates, current outlays on the Commonwealth's behalf are not expected to change in real terms this year. That means that they will not be cut.

The Government is saying, `Isn't it wonderful? The Forward Estimates show that government spending will fall next year'. That is what the report says. It says that current outlays are estimated to fall in real terms in 1989. However, much of this relates to the completion of big projects-for example, this Parliament House and other major investment projects. Next year's figures will reflect the full year effect of taking a lot of expenditure off Budget so that we do not see it any more. It is just changing the accounting practices, not the spending. For example, the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation no longer appear in the Budget figures; and they are big operations. The Government has caused a large amount of the current problem by not matching its rhetoric with facts. It keeps talking about restraint and cutting government spending but, as this report shows, it is not cutting expenditure enough.

The three major assumptions on which the Budget was based have already been proved wrong. On that basis, the Treasurer this week put on one of his normal and, I believe, totally disreputable stunts. During this week, immediately before Question Time, when he knew that he would be subjected to attacks from Professor John Hewson, the Opposition spokesman on finance in the House of Representatives, he called a press conference and released the hurriedly printed report on the Forward Estimates of Budget outlays. I understand that there was a special printing run the night before to provide enough copies of the documents so that the stunt could be pulled. It was an attempt to divert attention from Dr Hewson's very effective attack on the Government's economic policies which took place in the House of Representatives that afternoon.

Having given that press conference, the Treasurer then went into Question Time and took a dorothy dix question, saying what a wonderful prospect there was for the economy despite the fact that the three major Budget assumptions had been proved wrong. They were glossed over, and ignored. Having taken a dorothy dixer to say what a clever fellow he was, he then scurried out of the chamber and could not bring himself to respond to the parliamentary attack on him, on his policies and on his economic performance by certainly the most outstanding economic brain in this Parliament and one of the most outstanding economic brains in this nation. Professor Hewson, until he became a member of this Parliament, was the Dean of the Faculty of Economics at the University of New South Wales. He was on the board of the Macquarie Bank and was involved not only in theoretical economics but also in practical business. He is exactly the sort of person whom, if Mr Keating had any strength, determination or competence, he should have answered. If Professor Hewson had a good case to demonstrate that this Government is on the wrong economic track, it was cowardly of the Treasurer not to respond to him and to put up a backbencher to reply.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, we allow a fair degree of latitude in these sorts of matters but I would ask that Senator Baume withdraw the inference that the Treasurer is cowardly. I think that goes beyond the pale.
—I withdraw the word `cowardly'. I leave the people of Australia to judge how they should--
—Withdraw unre- servedly.

—I totally withdraw. Having withdrawn the word `cowardly', I leave it to the people of Australia to determine for themselves how to categorise a Treasurer who refuses to come in and face criticism from the shadow spokesman on finance-criticism that is well based, that is well founded-which the Treasurer is apparently incapable of responding to. Mr Keating has shown himself to be an expert in foul language in the Parliament; it is a pity he cannot display the same competence in dealing with economic matters in the Parliament. His failure to respond to Professor Hewson, his ducking of the issue, his inability, it seems, to defend himself and his policies against vigorous, effective and of course totally correct attack say a lot about Mr Keating and how badly he is doing right now.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, we have not heard anything at all about his push for leadership. But it is interesting that all Mr Keating's assumptions that I have just outlined are wrong. The Budget is built on those assumptions. Let us see how good those Forward Estimates that Mr Keating was so triumphant about the other day are. The report says:
The economic assumptions underlying the forward estimates are consistent with, and built upon, those for 1988-89 detailed in Statement 2 of the 1988-89 Budget Paper No. 1

So the Forward Estimates are built on and consistent with these assumptions which have already been proved wrong. Yet Mr Keating has the hide to say in a press conference, `Isn't it wonderful. Look what the Forward Estimates show-they show how clever I have been, how wonderful the economic future is, and how the Government has shown restraint and how Government spending will fall'. Who can believe statements like that, based on Budget forecasts which have already been established to be wrong?

TALK.START.PARA: —It shows desperation, doesn't it?

—It shows an enormous degree of desperation. I might say that this desperation to resolve some financial problems appears to have flowed over to the activities of the Australian Taxation Office. There is no doubt that the Government's desperate need for money has manifested itself in a whole range of Taxation Office activities. Many people have commented on the vigour of the Commissioner of Taxation's pursuit of some people who it is claimed have been tax dodgers but who quite rightly say that what they were doing was totally within the law.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to pursue that matter now; I want to raise another matter-the question of why so many ordinary taxpaying Australians are being cheated of their tax rebates by this Government. I use the term `cheated' in a very vigorous way, because that is what is happening. I have been receiving complaints from tax agents in my region, the Illawarra region, about the incredible and unjustifiable delays in paying tax rebates to ordinary Australian taxpayers who put in their tax returns early, on time. The delays indicated in my region this year are just incredible. One tax agent I spoke to only yesterday told me that the number of delayed rebates in respect of returns that he has put in on time has trebled, from 573 to 1,708. The Tax Office just has not got around to paying the money back-significant rebates in many instances-to ordinary Australian taxpayers.

Another tax agent in my region wrote to the Australian Taxation Office and to the Treasurer saying, `Come on, what is wrong? Why aren't my clients getting their tax rebates? There is nothing wrong with their returns. They are honest, decent people and their returns are clear'. Under the new system in the Tax Office, it should be easier for taxpayers to get their rebate back within a reasonable period. The Tax Office is now spot auditing rather than examining individual returns. I want to read the reply from the Tax Office, which strikes me as being incredible. The Tax Office wrote to the tax agent in the following terms:
It may better help you understand the situation if we firstly explain that, at this time last year-
The tax agent clearly said to the Tax Office, `Look, at this time last year we had very few outstanding rebates but this year there are an enormous number'-

our resources were such that we were in a position to provide a quick turnaround time for most salary returns that were lodged. This year, however, considerable resource constraints imposed on us as part of the Government's budgetary process has meant that the same situation no longer applies. An industrial dispute earlier on this month -
that was back in August -
did nothing to improve the situation.
The letter then said:

One of the key objectives of the Australian Taxation Office's Corporate Plan for 1988/89 is for all salary returns to be issued within ten weeks of lodgment and this is what we are currently working to-with, we add, considerably less staff this year.
The letter continues:
Irrespective of our imposed constraints, we are firmly committed to making the most efficient use of the resources we have to achieve our corporate goals.

A couple of things are not mentioned in that letter. Sure, it is evident that this Government has imposed restraints on the Tax Office. But let us notice who is picking up the bill for that restraint. It is not the Government-it keeps the money. It is the Australian taxpayer. As part of the pattern of this Government's economic restraint pattern, the Australian taxpayer is not being given his money back. That is great! Decent, honest taxpayers are being penalised because of this Government's incompetence by not being given their rebates.

Another matter of concern is hidden in the last sentence of the Taxation Office's letter in terms of the comment about making the most efficient use of resources. One of the reasons the Tax Office has not had enough people in the tax rebate area is that staff have been involved either with the tax amnesty or the tax file number proposal. In other words, once again the ordinary Australian taxpayer has had to suffer as a result of this Government's priorities. It seems to me that the Tax Office is trying to offset the economic impact of the amnesty, and various other things which are delaying the payment of some tax rebates, by holding on to the money that should have gone out to taxpayers long ago.

I was told by the accountant that the turnaround time of 10 weeks that the Tax Office says it is working towards is simply illusory. According to his advice, returns lodged in one week are not recorded then by the Tax Office. There is such a pile of returns to be registered, by the time the Tax Office gets around to registering what time they came in, it is two or three weeks later. It seems to me that there is a real problem in the Tax Office-which just happens to suit this Government's policies and helps resolve the problems that it has at the moment.

I say to the Tax Office and to this Government: I think you had better get your priorities right. It is the people of Australia who deserve a decent level of treatment. There should be no delaying of the payment of rebates to ordinary, honest Australians in the volumes in which they have been delayed. If this Government believes that all it has to do in taxation is harass people, make highly publicised raids and all that sort of thing to try to discourage tax cheats, that is fine, but what is it going to do about the honest taxpayer? When is it going to give him his rebate? Let us stop the concentration by this Government on matters that happen to suit it financially but disadvantage the ordinary Australian.

We all know that Mr Hawke has very little association now with ordinary Australians and is much more interested in his new old mates, the rich and powerful of this country, with whom he seems to find a great deal of pleasure in associating. Certainly, he finds far more pleasure in associating with them than with the ordinary taxpayers to whom he will not give rebates.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is just arrogantly out of touch.

—He is arrogantly out of touch. It is interesting in light of all the problems we have at the moment to see that the list of the people invited by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the opening of Parliament House is not to be made public. I asked to see it and was told, `No, you cannot'. I wanted to know who invited Mr Kornhauser, for example, to the opening. I am told that he is an old mate of the Prime Minister. He is an old mate of Russ Hinze, too. We notice that. I want to know why the Prime Minister is treated differently from me. The names of the people I invited to the opening of Parliament House were revealed publicly, yet the Prime Minister's invitees are somehow different. They must have privacy but the people I invited have no privacy. These kinds of double standards, I believe, are aimed at preventing the people of Australia knowing just how close Mr Hawke's old mates operation really is. The names of his old mates whom he invited to the opening of this building, for example, were not revealed to the public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite what we have just heard, we are debating the Appropriation Bills, and I would like to return to those. I notice from reading the Hansard record of the beginning of this debate that the Opposition proposes to move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) which condemns the Government for being out of touch and so on and makes three points, (a) (b) and (c). Later in my speech I wish to make some comment about point (c), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: coercing participation in the ABS Household Expenditure Survey in the face of substantial doubts about its validity and legal basis,

That is a most appalling amendment, based on no fact at all. But, as we have just heard, that would not necessarily stop the Opposition. In addressing the matters contained in this legislation, the Opposition has run some very curious arguments past us. If one reads the speeches made on these Bills by Government senators, particularly Senator Maguire and Senator McKiernan, one sees that many of the points raised by the Opposition have been thoroughly canvassed and dealt with.

Senator Chaney made two points in particular that I want to take up. I refer first of all to his comments about the family. He was particularly outraged, as was, I think, Senator Michael Baume in his contribution, when he cited very selectively comments that have been made to the effect that in some families a couple might have to work for 10 years so as to be able to afford to buy a house, implying that all of this is somehow associated with an attack on the family. I do not believe that the Opposition in making such comments indicates that it has much understanding of what constitutes a family in this country or yet what constitutes the information that goes into people's decision making as to how to live their lives.

What couples take into account when they decide to have a family is a very complex and multifaceted matter. I am sure that Senator Messner would agree with that. It is certainly much more than one item here or one item there. It is also quite interesting for me to hear the Opposition argue that couples having to work for 10 years is apparently preventive to having a family when there is all sorts of evidence in this country that couples who do have families continue to be two-income families. There is a lot of evidence from the use of child-care in this country, from the informal arrangements for child- care and from the use of private and public sector child-care that all sorts of couples continue to work as two-income families and have children.

I urge caution on the Opposition about suggesting that figures on housing mortgages and statements by bank managers may be the only evidence that needs to be taken into account when we are talking about how people decide to have families. It is not bad if one wants to make a one line political statement, but it is very wide of the mark in terms of comprehensive analysis. Members of the Opposition do not need to be told that, although I am very happy to tell them. I would like to pick up a quite extraordinary comment from Senator Chaney's speech. He spends quite a lot of his time complaining and bagging the Government because it has not done anything to help families. On page 2630 of the Senate Daily Hansard, Senator Chaney stated:
With respect to assistance to families, I condemn the Government for the fact that the only families it has been prepared to help have been those on the lowest incomes.

Even if that were true, what an extraordinary remark. How splendidly Senator Chaney highlights one of the priorities for this Government. In the very process of highlighting that, he also condemns the Government for daring to offer its priority assistance to families on the lowest income. I should have thought that that is precisely one of the principal priority areas and one reason the Government is proud of this Budget and the appropriations before us.

But as Senator Chaney said, the Opposition condemns the Government for the fact that the families it has been prepared to help are those on the lowest incomes. Can I assume that Senator Chaney would actually praise us if we had helped families on the highest incomes? This is a very curious comment from Senator Chaney and it runs quite counter to the complaints he wants to make. It is not the only assistance this Government gives to families, but it is certainly curious to be condemned for targeting as a priority those on the lowest income. In fact, I would have thought that it might give Senator Chaney considerable cause to read his own speech.

One interesting thing about attending the presentation of the Budget Speech this year and the briefing beforehand from my perspective was to compare the response and the feeling at the time of the announcement of this Budget with that in relation to the Budget we had to deal with when I first entered this Parliament in 1983. At that stage we were dealing with the consequences of seven years of Fraser Government and a presumed or projected Budget deficit approaching $9.6 billion. Our first Budget was aimed at reducing that to about a $6.5 billion deficit. In just five years we are now looking at a $5.5 billion surplus. It is an extraordinary achievement. It is certainly something, I am amazed to say, to have experienced that extraordinary turnaround in just five years. It has been achieved because of any number of decisions that this Government has taken. These decisions, in the macro-economic level, are very well described in Senator Maguire's speech and I have no intention of running over all of them again. But to highlight them: we have restrained government spending and public sector spending, and we have certainly targeted that spending so that it goes to those most in need. It is easily targetable. At the same time there has been massive restructuring in tax. To hear members of the Opposition talking about tax in the last few speeches, one would believe that they were talking only about personal income tax. I have not heard them talking about the contribution to tax revenue of the capital gains tax; I have not heard them talking about the contribution to revenue of the fringe benefits tax; I have not heard them talking about the contribution to revenue of those people previously, one way or another, not paying their tax and now paying it; and I have not heard them talking about their extraordinary restructuring and the consequential benefits to revenue and to all Australians. I have not heard them being appreciative that we have a surplus. I do not suppose that it is an experience they know-at least not from being in government. I do believe that for the record it must be acknowledged that this is an extraordinary achievement and turnaround in just 5 1/2 years of the Hawke Labor Government.

I also have considerable difficulty listening to members of the Opposition because they are very long on complaint. I have yet to hear from them what they would propose to do differently. We have had policy documents, the release of programs prior to elections and a number of promises and at the moment we are apparently waiting with bated breath for a manifesto. But I do not know of any substantial contribution to an alternative program announced by members of the Opposition, not even during this debate. They do not have any clear ideas of what they are proposing to do. (Quorum formed)

I was reminding members of the Opposition that we have waited for a long time for policies or platforms and we are now, apparently, waiting for a manifesto in which they promise that they will tell us what they would do that in some way would be different from what we do and also that they will tell us anything that they plan to do. It is interesting that Senator Newman called a quorum on me at this point because my notes here say that it is also very interesting that members of the Opposition forever get up in this place and argue about the importance of government restraint in expenditure. They say that the Government must cut expenditure. One principal argument we have heard over the last few weeks has been the veritable same Senator Newman arguing about the need for Defence Force expenditure. I do not quite know how Senator Newman is planning to argue within the manifesto that government expenditure can be restrained across the board but increased in defence. It may be that that is a priority she will be able to win in the Opposition party room, but apart from anything else it is a curious case in point that the Opposition, which wants to see restraint in government expenditure, is very excellent at arguing for increase in government expenditure in this place. I have not yet heard how members of the Opposition plan to balance those two, although any reading of Senator Walsh's speeches over the last two or three years would explain, on his evidence or on any evidence brought to his mind, that they do not know how to do it.

It is also interesting that not too long ago, in a debate in this place on pharmaceuticals, the Opposition objected to the very criteria, and said that, as well as responsible assessment by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee about medications, it should also take into account cost restraint, amongst other things. The Opposition argued at that time that the cost restraint criterion was very bad and should not be considered at all-was not a proper consideration of government. I find it very curious that, while from time to time we are criticised strenuously for cutting expenditure or trying to restrain it, members of the Opposition argue that it should be cut even more and then come in here and argue frantically for increased expenditure.

What this Government has done, just in terms of the deficit to surplus, stands worthy of serious appreciation. In targeting its expenditure to those with specific needs or those most in need, the drain on the public purse has been reduced so as to benefit all Australians. That is a point that the Opposition seems not to remember. The high unemployment we had some time ago, apart from anything else, was an enormous drain on outlays. It, therefore, cost all Australians. By creating 1.1 million jobs in the last five years not only has the Government reduced the outlays side and all those unemployment benefits and other services attendant on people in need; it has also increased revenue from the tax those people are now contributing. This is of benefit to all Australians. But the Opposition's case has much to do with homing in on individuals and their needs-not as the right consideration but as the only consideration. This confuses the issue and I think creates misrepresentation in the minds of the people listening.

This Government's achievements have been spelt out by my colleagues, and I will not go into them in great detail. The 1.1 million jobs which have been created in the last five and a bit years are many more than the Government's promise of 500,000 jobs when it came into office. That promise was more than achieved, and the Government will continue to achieve in this area.

One of the things I note is that the percentage of those jobs going to women is a matter of considerable satisfaction: all those women who have sought employment are now getting it. About 56 per cent of those jobs now provide opportunities for women. At the same time, for the first time ever, the labour force participation rate of women in this country touched 50 per cent. Most women are very pleased to have had the opportunity to move into the work force to get that income assistance and support.

Backing up the need to work, let alone the need to train or the need to seek an education, has been the Government's policy of necessary infrastructure in the area of child-care. There has been an enormous increase in the number of child-care places. The number of child-care places has been necessary to assist not only women, but in large part women, who still have the priority consideration of looking after children. They are now able to enter the work force to contribute to those two-income families. Senator Chaney seems to think that it is not possible to have two-income parents and a family.

Child-care is also providing opportunities for many more women to obtain education and training. For the first time ever more than 50 per cent of students in tertiary institutions in this country are women. The figures also show that more girls than boys are completing year 12 schooling. All of those things are very exciting for those of us who have been pushing for opportunities for women-not more opportunities than for men but an equal prospect of opportunities along with men in this country, for so long denied to so many women.

I believe that Mr Kinnock made the comment-and it certainly did not win him the last election against Maggie Thatcher-that he and his wife were the first people in their families ever to have had the opportunity of tertiary education. That is the case for many Australians, and particularly it is the case for many women in our society. For the first time for generations, women in those families have been able to take up the opportunity of completing school to year 12 or going on to tertiary education of whatever sort they might choose. It is also true that we now have that high participation rate-over 50 per cent-of women in the work force.

I think all of those things are indications that the Government's programs targeting women are having considerable success and are being considerably appreciated. I am quite surprised that the women in the Opposition in this place-Senator Vanstone and Senator Newman-seem to be loud in their protests about the benefits of child-care. Anybody who had talked to women in the community would be quite clear that child-care was one of the most sought after needs for people in the community, in particular, for women. (Quorum formed) In the few minutes remaining to me I want to return to paragraph (c) of the amendment proposed by Senator Chaney, which states:
coercing participation in the ABS Household Expenditure Survey in the face of substantial doubt about its validity and legal basis . . .

I chaired Estimates Committee C and heard at length the evidence about the legality of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) household expenditure survey (HES). No evidence was brought forward and there has never been any doubt that that expenditure survey, HES, is anything other than legal. Its validity and its legality are not in doubt.

The Opposition's amendment flies in the face of all the evidence. A considerable amount has been said and written about this. From the beginning there has never been any doubt that the ABS household expenditure survey is legal. If I put the kindest interpretation on it we are dealing with a considerable misunderstanding by some in the Opposition consequent upon letters being received and not known to have been received. I do not want to go into the details. If it is necessary that might be taken up with the Minister in the committee stage of the debate. But even to move this amendment suggesting that there is any doubt about the validity and legal basis of that household expenditure survey is wrong and it will be defeated.

When I read the report of Estimates Committee C I also noted that there was a dissenting minority report to the Senate. It was signed by Senators Teague, Messner and McGauran. They raised, amongst other things, the points about the failure of the ABS to inform fully the Attorney-General. They talked about the appropriation and asked that consideration be given to not providing the appropriation for the ABS survey; that is, that part of the household expenditure survey for the period 1 July to 30 September 1988 amounting to $1.3m. There is no way that that can be sustained either on any of the evidence to the Estimates Committee or on material brought to my attention subsequently. Nor do I think that an Estimates report should direct attention to the Chief Statistician's correspondence with the Clerk of the Senate. There are more appropriate ways of dealing with those matters. I think they were properly dealt with but they are mentioned in the dissenting report.

There is a bit of a crack at me for failing to conduct some parts of the Estimates consideration in a sound and fair manner. I find this quite interesting, because, if we are to talk about mannerly behaviour or maintaining the usual procedures, I must say for the record that I find it very curious that I was not provided with a copy of this dissenting report until I tabled it in the Senate already bound. In terms of manners, it is a bit slack of the Opposition not to have at least provided me as chairperson, if not the other Government members of that Committee, with a copy of their dissenting report.

It is also important to say that there was considerable and extensive examination over many hours in the Estimates of the legality of the household expenditure survey. I repeat: no evidence was brought before the Estimates Committee to sustain the Opposition's amendment that there is doubt about the survey's validity or its legal basis. There is also no evidence that anybody has ever been coerced into providing that information when the household expenditure survey has randomly chosen people and asked them to contribute to the ABS data. I think everybody in this place acknowledges the importance of the data, the importance of reliable and accurate collection of the data and the considerable number of surveys returned so that the statistical analysis of that data is comprehensive.

If honourable senators have any further doubts about this, they might like to read Senator Bob Collins's contribution in this place yesterday during a debate on Senator Sheil's private member's Bill. He very comprehensively dealt with the issues and more than adequately addressed the spurious point raised in this amendment by the Opposition. It is regrettable that those kinds of campaign, not dissimilar to many other campaigns by the Opposition, does not contribute to light and reason in our community but up the level of fear and anxiety.

I particularly condemn the Opposition for those sorts of tactics. It is not without a pattern. The Opposition is running its campaigns around this country on fear. It is also because it has no policies. But underlying all its attacks, whether on pharmaceutical benefits, elderly pensioners, the household expenditure survey or whatever, is its lack of policy in this area. I guess I could say that I am waiting with bated breath for the Opposition's manifesto but I would be misrepresenting myself. I am not waiting with bated breath. I am not sure we will ever get one. It certainly is not the first document that I want to read when it comes.

In closing my remarks on this Appropriations legislation, I simply say that this country is emerging from the straitened times it has experienced over the last decade or more as a consequence of seven years of Fraser and, more recently, the loss of $9 billion or more of revenue to this country. We have seen a government that has restructured the Budget in a way that has enabled it to proceed from deficit to surplus. By targeting its programs and expenditure outlays to people with specific needs it has been able to provide the number of services listed in the Budget Papers that I have chosen not to list in detail.

In particular, I would like to highlight the women's Budget Paper and the contribution to women in Australia not only in this Budget but also since we came into office. There is clear evidence that the Government, in this appropriations legislation, is making sure that all Australians participate, as they have in the past, in restraint and now in the opportunities this country continues to provide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to join the debate on the Appropriation Bills which are at present before the Senate. When the Budget was brought down in August the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) were quick to congratulate themselves on achieving an estimated Budget surplus of $5.5 billion. However, the method by which that surplus was achieved and the treatment of individual sectors leave a lot to be desired. It must be very clearly understood that the massive Budget surplus was achieved not by brilliant economic management, massive spending cuts or productivity gains but rather by increasing levies, sales tax and excise duties, and maintaining high personal tax rates.
—The highest taxing government in Australia.

—Yes, I am going to say that shortly. I am very distressed to see that the average Australian family will gain very little from Mr Keating this year. The Hawke Government is obviously quite comfortable with its record as Australia's highest taxing government. Senator Parer agrees with this. The Government is in no hurry at all to rid itself of that reputation.

SPEECH.PARA: In the five years since Labor came to office total tax revenue has almost doubled from $44 billion to an estimate of $82.3 billion for 1988-89. Personal income tax revenue will increase by 13.8 per cent this financial year, bringing it to $37.9 billion. About $10 billion of tax revenue collected this year will be due entirely to people being forced into higher tax brackets as they receive pay rises under Labor's wage indexation policy. The Government has continually promised but not delivered on tax cuts for average Australian workers. Cuts in personal income tax were promised by Mr Keating in his May mini-Budget. Cuts were again promised in the August Budget but the Australian taxpayer is not likely to see such cuts until shortly before the next Federal election. This latest promise of tax cuts will of course be conditional upon the unions maintaining wage restraints.

While the Government maintains its tax gathering obsession, it has consistently refused to take any serious steps towards curbing spending. Total Government spending in 1988-89 will go up by 4 per cent, to $82 billion, from the figure for the previous year. Indeed, I heard Senator Michael Baume say earlier that current outlays are not expected to change in real terms in 1988-89. That is an interesting point.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much have they cut the States?

—Of course, that is where the cuts have been made, Senator. The States have to learn to live with it. The people in the States are the ones who suffer. In his Budget Speech the Treasurer, Mr Keating, dismissed calls for spending cuts as being irrelevant. The average Australian, struggling to pay off a mortgage and feed his family, continues to subsidise the welfare state Australia has become. The Government's only response is to continue to tax him to the hilt.

SPEECH.PARA: Interest rates remain well above the average rates of our major trading partners. Savings bank home loan rates are currently 14.5 per cent. Prime rates for loans over $100,000 are about 15 per cent. The rates for credit cards, which many people use, range between 21 per cent and 23 per cent. Wages and labour costs in Australia far outstrip those of our major trading partners. Under the national wage case decision handed down on 12 August workers were to receive an immediate 3 per cent wage rise, plus a further $10 a week rise in six months time, thus increasing average weekly earnings by 5.2 per cent and forcing many into higher tax brackets.

Australia's gross foreign debt in the June quarter 1988 totalled a staggering $115 billion and will increase further during 1988-89. Let us compare that figure with our gross foreign debt in June 1983. At that time the debt stood at just $36 billion. There was a change of government, of course, at that time. That figure of $36 billion was bad enough, but nothing like the $115 billion in the June quarter 1988. It is small wonder that under Labor we have lost our AAA international credit rating. Under Labor our current account deficit has risen from $6.7 billion in 1982-83 to a massive $11.9 billion in 1987-88.

Surprisingly, in the Budget, the Government saw fit savagely to attack our export industries, at a time when those vital, wealth generating industries were most in need. Every assistance scheme for export industries has been cut by over 25 per cent on the figures for the previous year. These are incredible moves, considering that Australia's economic well-being is so dependent upon our ability to compete and trade on world markets.

The Government is pouring money into non-productive areas, while it continues to bleed dry productive areas generating wealth. If this country is to remain competitive, the Federal Government should be doing everything possible to increase our competitive ability. Instead, regrettably, the opposite is being done. I know that Senator Boswell agrees wholeheartedly that something needs to be done to increase our competitive ability. For example, the Budget grants for the development of export markets were cut by $59m for 1988-89.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very short-sighted.

—That is true. Export and trade promotion was cut by $7.1m. Funding for wool promotion is to be cut by $10.4m in each of the next two years. Assistance to the sugar industry will be cut by $8.4m in 1988-89.
—And they have lifted the embargo too.

—Not content with slashing assistance to the sugar industry, the Government appears determined to proceed with the proposal to remove the sugar embargo. Senator Boswell must have known what I was going to talk about. The Hawke Government has done a complete about-face on its position in 1983 when it strongly defended the sugar embargo as being crucial to the survival of the industry. The Government has now decided that as from 1 July 1989 the embargo is to be removed-a step which constitutes a direct threat to a most vital element of the industry's security.

SPEECH.PARA: The sugar industry is export oriented. With 80 per cent of Australian sugar sold on overseas markets, the industry is very exposed to volatile world prices. It relies heavily on a home base of secure and predictable markets. The Government's action in removing the embargo will erode this essential base to the detriment of the local sugar industry and to the benefit, I regret to say, of its international competitors. The Australian sugar industry guarantees full supply to the local market at Government controlled prices. As a result, Australian consumers have, for many years, enjoyed sugar prices which are about the third lowest in the world. Thus, the consumer has benefited from the embargo, the industry has benefited, and it has not cost the Government anything. So why remove the embargo?
The sugar industry has been made a sacrificial lamb in efforts to boost Australia's status in world trade negotiations. It is doubtful--

TALK.START.PARA: —So Senator Evans can strut around on the world stage.

—I was about to say, Senator, that it is doubtful that other countries such as the United States and those in the European Economic Community, with major sugar subsidies in place, will respond. In summary, the embargo provides guaranteed sugar supplies for consumers, control over domestic price rises, and stability and confidence for sugar producers. Loss of the embargo will, I believe, result in higher sugar prices for the consumer. The competitiveness of our sugar export industry will be severely eroded. Refiners and middle men will benefit. The industry's confidence and stability will suffer a major setback.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget contained no joy for rural Australians. There is no recognition of the tremendous contribution to export earnings made by primary industry over the years. There is no incentive offered in the Budget to maintain the industry's excellent record of productivity. Meanwhile, total revenue from primary industry levies will increase by $105m this financial year. Total revenue from other primary industry charges will rise by a further $19m. These increases relate to rises in wool tax, the livestock slaughter levy, milk levies and export inspection charges. It must be understood that the success of the Budget is conditional on a 9 per cent improvement in Australia's terms of trade and the continued performance and efficiency of rural industry.

While the Hawke Government recognises the importance of rural industries in its economic forecasts, it has again failed to provide any of the ingredients vital to improving the international competitiveness of the rural sector. Woolgrowers particularly have cause to be disgruntled with the Federal Government. The Government has refused to introduce income equalisation deposits-the self-help income stability insurance scheme. In fact, the Government would not even maintain wool promotion at the recommended level. It was left to the industry to help itself in this regard. Considering the fact that the woolgrowers have made the biggest contribution to Australia's performance and to the Budget surplus by paying $1 billion in additional tax, I feel that this is rather poor.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has never had any love for farmers.

—That is right. The Government believes in helping people in the cities, not in rural Australia where, unfortunately, so few live now. People seem to be having such a hard time in rural Australia that they are coming into the cities.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the fact that primary industry is Australia's highest export earning sector, this Government seems determined to squeeze the industry dry. At a time when Australia's major export industries are battling against the subsidised production and export policies of European nations, the United States, Japan and New Zealand, this treatment of our major foreign earning industries is not only sad but quite disgraceful. The Hawke Government has long ignored the tremendous contribution made by the rural sector to the growth and affluence of our nation. But enough is enough. The time has come for the Government to appreciate one of the major sources of its income. The Government must take positive steps to increase the competitive ability of our primary industries.

In keeping with Labor's general attitude of contempt for rural Australians, country students are now to be disadvantaged even further. In addition to the tertiary tax, an assets test will be introduced for Austudy and for the isolated children's assistance program. Messrs Keating and Hawke talk loudly about social justice, but rural people apparently are not part of the social justice program. While total outlays in 1988-89 on all student assistance schemes were forecast to increase by about 12 per cent in real terms, allocations under the program of assistance for isolated children are being savagely cut. The assistance for the isolated children program is being cut back by nearly 17 per cent in 1988-89 compared with Commonwealth allocations for the previous year. This program is aimed at providing some equality of education for bush children as compared with city children. Total allocations for the program in 1988-89 will be $26.9m compared to actual expenditure on the same program in 1987-88 of $32.4m. This will mean a cut of nearly 24 per cent in the number of students being educated through this program-from 19,000 in the calendar year 1988 to 14,500 in the calendar year 1989. What have country people done to be treated this way? I think that it is very sad indeed. I believe that country students deserve every educational opportunity, just as city children do.

On 24 August I addressed a question on this subject to Senator Walsh as the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I noted that total Budget outlays on education in 1988-89 were estimated to rise by 10.4 per cent or $6.3 billion, and that that included an increase in assistance under Abstudy of 21.3 per cent of $16.6m. I then went on to ask Senator Walsh to explain why assistance to isolated children had been so savagely cut. Senator Walsh merely replied that an assets test had been introduced and that this accounted for the reduction in assistance. But, for country people particularly, the assets test is a most inaccurate and unfair system of determining a family's financial status and ability to make ends meet.

Country people were disappointed to see that the pre-Budget speculation of a reduction in fuel excise came to nothing. The priorities of this Government are questionable, to say the least. How can the Treasurer justify cutting sales tax on cosmetics, perfumes and photographs while standing firm against the prospect of any reduction in fuel excise? In fact, fuel excise will increase by at least the projected inflation rate of 4.5 per cent.

Funding for roads is to be cut by $50m in 1988-89 and a further $25.7m in 1989-90. I have no doubt that when the roads legislation comes in there will be lots of senators speaking-that is if we get time before the end of the session-on the problem of funding for roads. Australia's roads are falling apart because of inadequate funding. Federal spending on roads has remained at the same level since 1984-85 but when inflation is taken into account we see that funding has declined in real terms by 25 per cent. I note that the Minister has been saying that these figures are wrong and that road funding has gone up but he is not allowing, of course, for the inflation level. Taking inflation into account, there has been a reduction of more than $300m or 25 per cent in real terms.
