Local authorities are naturally very concerned about the Government's refusal to acknowledge that insufficient funding for roads has become a gigantic problem for a significant percentage of regular road users. Funding cuts have had a major impact in country areas particularly. It has become impossible to keep up with the demand for new and improved roads to cater for the needs of the transport industry and the individual motorist. The funding cuts that were forecast in the Budget will create enormous problems for a significant number of Australia's road users-urban commuters, tourists and the man on the land. More than half the money spent by motorists on petrol goes to the Federal Government. For every litre of petrol or diesel purchased, the Government takes about 30c in tax. Regrettably it returns only about 5.35c to the motorist in the form of road funding. There is certainly a vast difference between taking 30c in the dollar in tax and returning only about 5.35c of that to the motorist.

A safe, reliable road network is of fundamental importance to our nation's economy. Despite that, the rate of construction and reconstruction of the local road system has slowed to a virtual standstill. In rural areas particularly, roads are wearing out far more quickly than they can be replaced. I have had lots of people say to me that bitumen roads are fast turning into gravel roads because councils cannot get enough money to keep the bitumen roads repaired. Recent studies have shown that roads carry 97 per cent of all passenger journeys, 77 per cent of all freight and 83 per cent of all domestic tourism journeys. Studies have also revealed that last year road accidents cost almost $5.7 billion when taking into account property damage, lost wages, and hospital and rehabilitation costs. Better roads mean fewer accidents, and that means fewer Australians killed or permanently maimed every year.

It is quite obvious to me and, I believe, to all Opposition senators and members that the Labor Government should get its priorities right and give increased financial assistance to rural Australia, from where so much of its export earnings come. I certainly support the Opposition's amendment to the second reading motion for the Appropriation Bill (No. 1).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the Appropriation Bills for 1988-89. The process involved in this examination is that Estimates committees examine the Bills before they are debated in the chamber. Each Estimates Committee consists of six senators. It is my pleasure to chair Estimates Committee A, the first of the Estimates committees. I would like to mention a number of points in the report of Estimates Committee A. First, I would like to refer to the examination of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. In discussing the offsets and partnership development program the Committee said in its report:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee draws attention to what appears to be a disturbing tendency, exemplified by these programs, whereby former departmental officers involved in framing quite complex systems to implement government policy subsequently take up positions in the private sector advising industry on the very systems or policies they helped to frame.
The Committee went on to say:

While recognising the rights of individuals to move between the public and the private sectors it may be necessary in the future for governments to consider the American practice of requiring former government employees to undergo an appropriate e.g. two year prohibition period before they are able to take advantage of their inside knowledge.

I agree very strongly with that recommendation of Estimates Committee A because I believe that we have to be concerned that departmental officers can be hired by the private sector. One could use even stronger wording and say that there have been examples of people in the public sector literally having been filched by the private sector so that it could use the knowledge that these people have obtained. I have looked at the American legislation which provides penalties for officers who divulge the information they have gained in their public capacity to private organisations within that two-year period. I noticed that there was a report in the Australian Financial Review of last week concerning this problem in the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce-a department which has been in the forefront of change. I think that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) must be commended for the very active role undertaken by his Department under his leadership. The Australian Financial Review report said that the loss of senior staff is a significant problem and that there is a morale problem because of the pressure of work in that Department. We can understand that because it is headed by a Minister and a Government determined to change the face of industry in Australia. We have to watch this Department's situation carefully. We know that it is a dynamic department, but we must make sure that no more officers are taken from it. This problem applies to other ministries, but it highlights something that I commend the Government to consider.

The second matter to which I wish to draw attention is very topical. In the report of Estimates Committee A on the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce reference is made to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). The Committee stated in the report:

The Committee noted with concern the difficulties CSIRO is undergoing with respect to obtaining funding for purchase of capital equipment and endorses the Minister's remark where he stated ``I hope that the Government would be in a position to improve the budgetary situation of CSIRO in the future and I hope that the outside earnings and the targets for outside earnings which have been set for CSIRO will be made; and I have every confidence that they will.

I have raised within the Government my view that, despite the attempt by the Government to achieve those outside earnings and an expansion generally of CSIRO, there is a need to extend the funding of that organisation. It is too important to all Australian industry for it to be in difficulty. I appreciate, of course, that the Government is concerned that the private sector has been very lazy, indolent, in its attempts to develop research in this country. There is an attitudinal problem. The `she'll be right' attitude in many sectors of industry has meant that not enough money has been spent in this area. A couple of nights ago there was a major scientific development in this city. Scientists demonstrated their belief that more money should be given to the CSIRO. I have no problem with that as a trade unionist. It is high time that people in this situation showed their concern. The democratic process of complaining about the way science must take off in this country and the fact that it is not going ahead sufficiently is something that I hope will be rewarded in the next Budget.

In referring to Estimates Committee A I refer to the reservation expressed by Opposition Senators Bishop, Alston and Chapman. They have contributed probably a record reservation in that it is 13 pages. It should get into the Guinness Book of Records because it is larger than the report itself, which is nine pages. I draw attention to the fact that the Senate committee system works on a give and take basis, with a general preparedness of honourable senators to sit down and come to a position slightly different to that which they started off with. If these minority reports continue-and there have been several from Estimates Committee A-I fear that there will be a Government senators' report and an Opposition senators' report. Unfortunately, not enough effort is being made to reach genuine compromise, at least on Estimates Committee A as I see it. I draw the attention of the Senate to that because if the practice continues we will be presented with a different sort of report to that which the Senate has before it today.

In drawing attention to the positive side of an Estimates committee report, I point out that one of the things we looked at was this Parliament itself. I do not intend to dwell on this, but I commend the reading of the report on the Committee's examination of the new Parliament House. The Committee noted with concern a number of matters related to the new building which, although raised during its consideration of the estimates of the parliamentary departments, are in reality matters for resolution by the Parliament House Construction Authority. I will mention only the headings in the report to illustrate our concern. We are critical of the way in which television cabinets were purchased and their inadequacy. We referred to many practical things such as the sound and vision system and even the door closing mechanisms in committee rooms. Very large doors are thumping closed during hearings and the witnesses, officers of the various departments and members of the Committee cannot always be understood. Even the inadequacy of the cleaning arrangements that has been manifest in the new Parliament House was raised. The Committee carefully drew attention to a whole range of miscellaneous matters that are of concern. We hope that they will be resolved fairly quickly.

The other major matter I would like to look at is the real matter before us. Senator Chaney and a whole host of Opposition senators have berated and criticised the Government. I remind the Senate of the other side of the story. At the same time as the Government is creating record employment growth and maintaining Labor's long held commitment to a comprehensive and effective social security system, it has created over one million new jobs. Everything we have heard this morning denies the basic fact that over one million Australians have been taken from the unemployment pool or have been given the opportunity to fulfil themselves. This particularly applies to women in our society. This is a singular achievement of this Government. We have had the highest job growth of all the countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. A better, more fair and effective, social security system is being created, aimed at helping the most disadvantaged people in the community.

In these appropriations, in this Budget, we have seen increases in the family allowance supplement which help over one million children from low income families to have a higher standard of living. This is the answer, yet we hear nitpicking from the Opposition this morning. So much for the Opposition's criticism when one million children of low income earners are facing a far better situation than they were previously. This Government is setting out to achieve a qualitative change and to remove poverty as it affects children. That is our contribution to the family. It is not a phoney use of the word `family', as so often happens with members of the Opposition, which says that everything is done in the name of the family. We well remember the way the Fraser Government treated families as it added to the unemployment pool in 1981-82.

Rent assistance payments are being progressively restructured and will rise to $30 a week for larger families by June 1990. I particularly mention two new programs in the social security portfolio which reflect the Government's commitment both to our electorate and to providing long term economic independence through the employment of all Australians. These two new programs are the New Start program and the jobs, education and training (JET) program. The New Start program will provide adult long term unemployed with 25,000 places for reskilling and training. An amount of $100 will be paid to each of these trainees to help with the costs of starting a new job. The JET program will help single parents in a similar fashion. Improved counselling services and child-care places for up to 12,000 people will be provided.

These types of programs reflect our commitment to assisting the most disadvantaged, in particular the long term unemployed, through appropriate restructuring of education and training. This is just one aspect of a program involving massive changes in our economy. The Australian Labor Party has steered the country through the most difficult period in our postwar history. We are in transition from an economy based on digging up Australia and selling it to an economy which is becoming more diversified, more export oriented, more export replacement oriented and much more competitive. This Government realises that, unless it tackles what has been termed a deep-seated malaise of manufacturing industry, the long term future of the Australian economy is bleak indeed.

The Labor Government's success in the process of modernisation and revitalisation has rested on many factors. One of the most important is the agenda it has set for labour market and industrial relations reform in Australia. This was demonstrated when we examined the Department of Industrial Relations in Estimates Committee A. A few years ago nobody would have believed that management, unions and employees in Australian companies would be able to discuss, let alone cooperate in, the remarkable changes in the workplace that have started to occur. Nobody knows that better than you, Mr Acting Deputy President, as a person who has had long experience in industrial relations. This has happened because the accord between the union movement and the Labor Party has allowed the Government to tackle the structural crisis, with the involvement and help of unionists and their organisation.

This Government has set an agenda for labour market and industrial relations reform in Australia. High on that agenda is award restructuring, which reflects the rapid change that is occurring in industry. This goes hand in hand with the development of a more skilled and adaptable work force and the introduction of more flexible forms of work organisation and management. This year's Budget included a number of important new measures aimed at quickening the pace of workplace reform, particularly award restructuring. I emphasise award restructuring because it has always been an area of entrenched interests. People are fearful of change, and that is understandable.

I have mentioned the new Parliament House. I know that a lot of parliamentarians were a bit unhappy about the changes that have been part of the move. Industrial relations are particularly important. This Government set out to create a supportive and positive atmosphere in management and labour in which people can shed concepts they may have which are not relevant to the present. I am very proud of the fact that the unions have led the way in the modernisation strategies that are emerging. Many unions recognise the importance of award restructuring in order to promote skill formation to reduce significantly labour market segmentation and to provide better career structures, and of course this is absolutely vital for women in Australia.

In these appropriations there are a number of initiatives that I am very pleased to be associated with. The Government's workplace reform will sponsor research and special projects. It will assist union employer bodies to employ special advisers in workplace reform. It will provide advisory and consulting services for firms involved in the process of re-establishing and improving competitiveness. Workplace resource centres are to be established and will provide a range of technical and human resource services. The Government will also undertake a major survey of Australian workplace industrial relations. It is incredible in a country where everything is surveyed, where people in the street are accosted all the time and asked their attitude in polls on the order of political life, that we are so ignorant of the basic things that occur in our factories and workplaces. This initiative will provide trade unions, employers and the Government with the comprehensive information that is essential for long term success in workplace reform.

I am pleased to say that the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, with which I am associated, has recently brought down its own report on manufacturing industry revitalisation and is about to study the related matter of the various forms of management organisation. This Government also recognises that people need to want to learn a new range of skills so that they can confidently and happily perform a broader range of functions.

The new Federal industrial relations legislation will enable much greater flexibility in workplace negotiating. While I do not want to be controversial, as some other senators have been, the reality is that this is being done in a realistic way. Unions are having an input into this process, change is occurring, and of course we have rejected the New Right ideologues. Senator Bjelke-Petersen, as the last speaker for the National Party of Australia, was bemoaning the wage increases that workers are entitled to receive next year. I suppose one could understand why Senator Bjelke-Petersen, being a senator from Queensland and associated closely with the discredited Queensland Government, should plead for woolgrowers at a time of record prices and bemoan the assets test. She probably wants the rich cockies to get their snouts in the public trough once again. She talked about education, when everybody knows that the Queensland education system under the National Party is the worst in Australia. I suppose we have to expect that from people associated with the National Party Government in Queensland, which is discredited in every possible way, but in no greater way than in its poor contribution to the education of the Queensland people.

I conclude by referring to the industrial relations legislation, which contains new processes of certified agreements and broadens the scope for negotiation on wages and conditions. The parties to a dispute will now be able to reach their own terms of settlement under the umbrella of the Commission's general wage fixing principles. Unlike the Opposition's proposal for so-called voluntary agreements, there are safeguards against exploitation. The unhappy industrial relations situation that exists in Queensland is an example of how the Opposition's voluntary agreements process works in practice. There is an unequal situation where employees are at a great disadvantage compared with employers. Through the changed legislation and the proposals in this Budget, this Government is continuing a process of allowing the devolution of power so that all people in industrial relations can meet, discuss and resolve problems as adults. They can democratically make arrangements so that they know exactly what they are doing. We know that that is the way to go forward. It is only when people freely engage in agreements that we can release human creativity and develop the human resources which Australia so sorely needs to compete with other countries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Government's Appropriation Bills. Australia is a country which is resource rich. Yet our economy is not just stagnating; it is going backwards, while around us in the South East Asian region we have seen a most incredible growth rate-firstly in Japan, followed by Taiwan and Korea. As most people are aware, the next economic cab off the rank will be Thailand. It is worth mentioning that all of those countries are resource poor, except in the attitude of their people and the sense of direction of their governments.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of capitalising on this resource richness and using it to introduce value added type products of our natural wealth, Australia still relies on three industries: primary industry, which Senator Childs kicked to death a minute ago; mining; and, more recently, tourism. I am sure that everyone agrees that each of those industries is subject to the vagaries of international markets and is somewhat fragile. Thus, while we rely entirely on those three industries-I think that those industries are terribly vital to us; without them we would be in a shocking mess-our terms of trade will be subject to cyclical roller-coasters. There is an absolutely urgent need to develop our manufacturing industries both for import replacement and exports.

In the 1960s and 1970s, tariff protection of import industries was used as an incentive. It proved to be a failure. Yet it was a technique which was highly successful in those countries in South East Asia to which I have referred-Japan, Taiwan and Korea. There are many reasons why it did not succeed in Australia. The most significant was that that protection enabled militant and centralised trade unions to impose wages and conditions which did nothing more than make our industries inefficient and ultimately caused the loss of jobs. Mr Bob Hawke was President of the trade union movement at that time and we remember well the pantomimes and shows that went on, the solving of disputes after people had been brought to their knees. Business was also at fault because it was inward looking and was interested only in production for domestic purposes. Thus it could afford to give in to union militancy and we were paid more than could be afforded. In fact, I can recall statements by the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when he was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) that, if necessary, to gain these massive wage increases at the expense of the country he would use the devil himself. Honourable senators might remember that comment. The day of reckoning had to come and come it did.

So much for some brief history. We must look to the future. We are competing in a world and, having seen, we must learn from the past so that we can pick up the pieces and provide an environment and a framework which will ensure a better Australia and higher standards of living for future generations of Australians. I would say that unless we respond to that, our young people, the people who should be of great concern to this Government but who have been neglected by this Government, will end up with very menial tasks. I do not want my children or grandchildren to face a future of being shoeshine boys. Unless we do something about it, that is where we will go.

The three major industries must be supported because, as I mentioned earlier, without them we will be in an absolutely shocking mess. If we do not move quickly into competitive manufacturing, using our natural resources, it will be only a matter of time before our standard of living deteriorates and we will become one of the poor countries in our region of South East Asia. The great questions are: Can we lift our game and will Australians respond under the right conditions which have not been present in the last five years? I am sufficient of an optimist to say that it can be done and I share with Senator Button the frustration as to why it is not being done and why it is so infintesimally slow.

The Government tried the so-called J-curve, the theory being: if we collapse the dollar, export incomes will rise, the price of imports will go up and that will provide the incentive to import replacement and exports of manufactured goods. The theory did not work, except in some very few cases. Yet an undervalued currency was, once again, a great success in the rise of Japan. The question must be asked why it did not work. There were many factors that this Government could not or would not address. The reasons are fairly well known. Why, for example, do individuals put their savings into real estate rather than into the wealth creating manufacturing industries, which would assist in our balance of payments problems and create jobs?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because they got burnt in the stock market crash.

—Senator Cook will be aware that in other countries when things are bad there is a move towards gold. When there is political or economic instability people move into gold because they see it as holding its value and also being readily tradable. Because of this Government's policies and actions, which have acted as a disincentive to savings and investment, we in this country have moved into real estate. So there is a gold mentality here but we see it in a different light. People think to themselves, `How can we protect our hard earned savings?' The only thing they can think of is, `Let's get some real estate.' That has the effect of pushing up the price of real estate. In addition, this Government has brought incredible interest rates upon this country over a sustained period-not the little pips that Senator Walsh used to refer to when he talked about the Fraser Government, but sustained interest rates-which are about double what people in other parts of the world have to pay.

SPEECH.PARA: Why is it that people overseas prefer places such as Korea, Taiwan and now Thailand rather than Australia? Yet, as I mentioned earlier, we are a resource rich country. We have an intelligent, reasonably well educated population. Why do people prefer those countries? All the glossy brochures and missions will not make one iota of difference to investment in Australia in wealth creation. Until our serious and apparently entrenched structural problems are addressed nothing will happen. I think it is worth referring to comments made by Greg Clark, who lives in Tokyo-he was very much associated with the Labor Party-in a recent article in the Australian. He said:
For more than two years now, Canberra has been bombarding Japan with glossy materials touting Australia's high-tech abilities and Japanese investment missions have been lured into tours of Australia.
Canberra has even relied on that ultimate weapon in its armoury-the High Level Mission.
But there is no change to the structural problems we have. He went on:
Dozens of businessmen and bureaucrats, not one of whom speaks Japanese-
I did not take much notice of that because, having dealt with that country for a long time, I realise it is useful but not entirely necessary-
and almost none with any business experience in Japan, are shipped there at great expense to hold cocktail parties and seminars to spread the good word.
And the results to date? Almost zero.
The Japanese may not have great economists but they do have common sense.

What a criticism. What has been the response? We have not had that sort of investment. We need that investment. Why do they not come here and share their technology in joint ventures? I even heard the President of my Party, Mr Elliott, the other day complain that Japanese investment in real estate should be diverted to manufacturing industry. While the incentive is not there to go into manufacturing, what is happening is inevitable. We cannot blame the Japanese or anyone else for investing in the areas we do not want them to invest in-there is no attraction. That is the problem.

We must look at two areas. Firstly, we must capture what is left of the savings of Australians after the Government got at them and encourage Australians to get into those investments. To do so the structural problems I have just referred to must be addressed. The trading banks' prime rate of interest in this country is about 15.5 per cent and rising. Let us compare that with the Japanese rate of 5 to 6 per cent. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) says, `Our economy is overheated; let's lift the interest rate up'.

A lot of people ask why we have to increase the interest rate to 15 or 16 or 17 per cent at great expense, not only to business but to the ordinary person with a house mortgage, when in Japan, which has a rate of 5 to 6 per cent, the economy is not overheated and when in the United States, with interest rate of 8 or 9 per cent, the economy is not overheating. We have to go to 16 or 17 per cent to curb so-called overheating. The answer is that this Government has not done anything to control inflation. Our inflation rate on an annualised basis is 7.3 per cent. It looks to be locked in at about 7 per cent. The inflation rate in Japan is 0.6 per cent. I can quote a host of other figures, whether they be from West Germany, Japan, the United States or wherever. So much for the accord. There is great uncertainty about the dollar. Secondly, we have the restrictive work practices, a centralised industrial relations system and a perception of industrial anarchy. Senator Childs said in his speech that there had been great improvement under the accord.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are doing your best to talk it up. That is really an inspired idea.

—I am quoting the facts and describing to Senator Cook exactly why we are having difficulties and how they can be resolved. Senator Childs said that the accord had been a great success, that there had been a reduction in industrial disputes and that there was cooperation at various levels. I question that. Certainly, when looking at the October monthly economic and social indicators we find that the number of disputes has come down. Let us look at the number of working days lost. That is what counts. That is what affects people, local or foreign, when they decide whether they are going to put their money up. In 1983-84, 1.27 million working days were lost because of industrial disputation. In 1984-85 the figure was 1.3 million and in 1985-86 it was 1.46 million. It came down in 1986-87. That was around the time of the `banana republic' comments. In 1987-88 1.689 million working days were lost by industrial disputation. What a great success! What an encouragement to get this country out of its mess. So much for domestic investment. Why do people go into real estate-this is what I call the gold mentality-instead of the wealth creation areas? I do know that. Investment in real estate does not contribute much, if anything, to the economy, except to push the price of real estate up.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at overseas investment. Why are people not coming here? They have a plus: their interest rates are less. The inflation rate in Australia is at least double the rate of the European Economic Community, which is a problem. There is continuing uncertainty about the exchange rate, as there is with the domestic rate. Anyone who invested in an import replacement or export industry when our dollar was worth US60c or US65c, which Senator Button said was about the right level, would now be dead in the water. I was surprised the other day at the lack of understanding shown by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. In answer to a question, he said that if those people are in trouble-this is what he implied-it is their own fault and that they could have purchased forward cover. I ask: for how long? For three months, for six months? It would not be enough; they would still be dead in the water.

As I mentioned, the number of days lost is a disincentive to domestic and foreign investment in Australia. Compared to our near neighbours, our level of disputation and our level of uncertainty are totally unacceptable. That is the perception. Senator Cook might say it is not right, but I am telling him that that is the perception; that is the real world. It will not be corrected until people in the union movement get responsible runs on the board. We recently had the Australia-Japan Coal Conference. The coal people are already in difficulties because of the rise in the dollar, as are a lot of our export industries. I have a newspaper article which states:
The Managing Director of Nippon Steel Corp, Mr Toyohiko Ohno, warned that appalling industrial relations placed Australian coal producers in a `very disadvantaged position'.

We recently had the iron ore problem at Mount Newman which Senator Cook would know a lot about. The unions bucked the orders handed down by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. According to that article, the chief executive of that corporation, the leader of the delegation, warned:
. . . appalling industrial relations placed Australian coal producers in a `very disadvantaged position'.
At the end of the article we read:

Meanwhile, two BP Coal Australia mines in NSW remained inoperative yesterday in a dispute over management plans to introduce more continuous rosters, although talks in search of a solution were in train . . .
The President of the Miners Federation said:
. . . plans to escalate the dispute to support the 600 striking miners were drawn up yesterday and will be put to a meeting of union branch presidents today.

What impeccable timing: right in the middle of-in fact, on the same day as-the discussions between the Australians and the Japanese on the future of our coal exports! One wonders about these people's motives. Are they really interested in the future of their Australian colleagues? Are they really interested in the development of our export market? Continuing restrictive work practices, wildcat strikes, inflexibility and the perpetuation of a `them and us' attitude all add up to a lack of productivity. That is really what we are talking about; we must increase productivity per worker. We live in an increasingly competitive world.

I was taken the other day by some remarks by Sir Bruce Watson, who made an interesting analogy when he pointed out that a person who won a gold medal in the Los Angeles Olympics just over four years ago would not have got a place in the Seoul Olympics. It is exactly the same with the level of international competitiveness. I note, as others have, the remarks of Terry McCrann in the Brisbane Sunday Mail and in other papers. He simply put it this way: `We are not earning our way. We are going backwards in an increasingly competitive world'. He went on to cite our increase in gross domestic product and then the changes in the gross domestic product (GDP) per person employed, which has been going down, and the changes in GDP per hour of work.

We desperately need investment, both domestic and foreign, in our manufacturing industries, but we will not achieve it while these structural problems are out of kilter with those of other countries. They must all be addressed; but by far the most critical, from a foreign investment point of view, is what is perceived to be our permanently inflexible industrial relations system. There is no way that this Government will face up to this problem. Until it does, the other structural problems will not be corrected. When I go around Australia I am surprised to see how few people realise that no Australian citizen can become a Labor senator or member of the House of Representatives unless he or she is a member of a union acceptable to the ACTU. So all Labor senators and members, from the Prime Minister down, are here by the grace of the ACTU.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—What union is Senator Cook a member of?
—I am a member of a union, but what you have just said is not true.
—In what way?
—Order! Honourable senators will not carry on a conversation.

—Who calls the shots? It is the people who put them here. These people do not represent their electorates; they represent the ACTU, the peak group. This Government could never address this major problem which is holding this country back because, by doing so, it would be reducing the power of its political masters.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Maguire, in his speech, criticised my previous remark that this is the highest taxing government in Australia's history. He did not dispute the claim; he just did not like my saying it. We have a domestic surplus, and the question is: how was it achieved? It was achieved by taxing everyone and everything in sight.

I would like to give honourable senators a list of the sorts of increases that have occurred since this Government came to power. In 1982-83 income tax on individuals-in the main, pay as you earn tax-was $23 billion. In 1988-89, that figure has gone to around $48 billion, an increase of 107 per cent, a burden on the backs of the ordinary Australian family man, the ordinary Australian worker. Company taxes, including the fringe benefits tax, have gone from $4.8 billion to $11.2 billion, which is an increase of 132 per cent. The Government reckoned that it was not going to introduce a consumption tax, but it has done it by stealth. Everything from milkshakes to whatever is now included under sales tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Everything that affects the family.

—As Senator Knowles says, everything that affects the ordinary family person battling out there to survive with high interest rates. Now the Government has hit that person with an increase in sales tax. Sales tax has gone from $3.4 billion in 1982-83 to $8.6 billion in 1988-89, an increase of 147 per cent. Income tax has gone up by 107 per cent; company tax has gone up by 132 per cent; and sales tax has gone up by 147 per cent. And-guess what?-the consumer price index, the inflation rate, is up by 51.6 per cent. I might just say in passing-and going back to the remarks I made earlier-that for the full five-year period the increase in Japan was only 6.5 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: What a great job this Government has done! We have a punitive taxation regime which penalises savings. Is it any wonder that people are protecting their savings by going into real estate? What is needed is a regime which encourages savings and investment. In recent days, with the issue of the report on Forward Estimates, the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) claimed a reduction in government spending compared to GDP, so that in three years it will be at its lowest level for 20 years. That is very interesting. Let us look closely at the figures. They claim that things are going so well that inflation will be 4.25 per cent next financial year, and will then fall to 3.5 per cent in the following two years. Nothing short of a miracle will bring that about. The way this Government is running the economy has nothing to do with miracles; it is a disaster. As mentioned a few times previously, the rate of inflation is 7.3 per cent, which was also the rate for the last financial year and, in spite of rhetoric to the contrary, there is every chance it will remain high for some time.

If we look through the various Budget figures, we find that the Government has not reduced its own spending. Sure, it reduced its payments to the States and things like that, but its own spending has not gone down one iota. It is also interesting to note that the Government attributes the fall in spending partly to a 5.6 per cent cut in unemployment benefits by 1989-90. Unemployment is currently around 7.8 per cent and for 1988-89 it is projected to be 7.4 per cent. The high youth unemployment figure of 1984 was 21 per cent. That figure has fallen to 15.6 per cent, which unfortunately is still a very high figure but is an improvement. I notice a curious coincidence. I do not mind this, but I just wish the Government would be honest about it. With the fall in youth unemployment, the numbers receiving Austudy have risen from 175,000 in 1984-85, with a payout of $333m, to a projected 335,000 in 1988-89, with a payout of $785m.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not suggesting that they transfer them from the unemployed to Austudy, are you?

—Thank you, Senator Lewis: yes, I am. In fact the Government has now said, `You do not get unemployment benefits if you are 15 to 18 years of age or thereabouts, but we will pay you if you go to school'. That has been a nice little sleight of hand-and we are used to that with this Government-so that it can crow about how it has reduced unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, time is going to beat me. The people of Australia are not gullible. They know that the balance of payments deficit has not, as the Treasurer said, been caused by a manufacturing boom. With all the rhetoric of this Hawke Government, with its calls for belt-tightening, what has it achieved over five years? It has achieved an incredible reduction in the standard of living and a bleak prospect for the future. The Government will not address the major structural problems confronting this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government has developed and endorsed a national conservation strategy; it has acknowledged land degradation and the greenhouse effect as two of the greatest problems facing our society. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) has pointed out on nationwide television that the greenhouse effect is evidence that continuing abuse and overuse of the earth's finite resources must stop. Yet, when it comes to supporting such a sensible change in direction of our national use of resources in the Budget, environmental issues are pooh-poohed and dismissed as single issue demands-despite the Commonwealth's clear responsibilities in the areas of energy policy, soil conservation, resource use such as forests, and the conservation of the Australian natural heritage through the Register of the National Estate.

SPEECH.PARA: Energy trends are an important indicator of the world's economic and ecological health, and they are not yet on a sustainable course. In fact, according to the Worldwatch Institute in its publication the State of the World 1988, energy trends are at the root of some of the world's most intractable environmental problems. The nuclear fuel cycle is a continuation of this trend, not a solution to it. The key to resolving the coal-nuclear conundrum is simple but radical: greatly improved energy efficiency, emission controls, and stemming deforestation in the short term, complemented by renewable energy in the long run. What better credibility for the Australian Government to influence the elimination of nuclear weapons than by demonstrating safe, cheap energy alternatives-alternatives which do not undermine the international monetary system, do not pollute the atmosphere, do not encourage wasteful, high consumption life-styles, and do not generate intractable wastes, and which stimulate innovation, employment and sustainable economic development?

It is no coincidence that the Western Australian Government Minister who lobbied the hardest for a deregulated uranium policy earlier this year was the same Minister who cut out funding for the Solar Energy Research Institute in Western Australia, better known as SERWA, the only research, testing and information centre for renewable energy in my home State. It is a pathetic situation when creative solutions are discarded in favour of perpetuating the problem.

The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), the best qualified government research body in the land, must beg and scrape simply to restore the funding cuts which have been undermining its programs since 1983-84. It has now been granted $1m per year for solar energy research-non-polluting, renewable energy-as compared to the $8m granted for coal research. Further pleas by CSIRO this week for a mere $15m to begin to address other Australian environment problems are evidence of an international disgrace and an insult to the growing community concern about unsustainable resource use. It is interesting that even scientists-some of whom have never before taken to the streets to do so-demonstrated their concern when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) opened the new science institute here in Canberra the other day. Obviously the cuts are affecting so many of our top scientists who are now part of the brain drain overseas, which is a waste of a very valuable national resource.

It was pointed out to me by a constituent in the business of energy management that our Government provides no incentives for increased energy efficiency. In fact, incentives usually work in the opposite fashion. This trend is consistent with that of the United States, where nuclear energy was pioneered. In 1979, researchers Yergin and Stobaugh from the Harvard Business School estimated that distortions in the pricing of coal and nuclear energy systems from tariffs, subsidies and unaccounted costs to the environment were in the order of $50 billion per year. The failure of the United States `superfund' to adequately deal with intractable wastes generated since the Harvard Business School calculations attests to the long term consequences of natural resource abuse.

It was interesting to hear our State Minister for Transport in Western Australia defend current transport policy at a greenhouse seminar held in Perth last May. In response to an observation by a member of the audience that our metropolitan transport system encourages the use of private automobiles and carbon dioxide emissions, the Minister insisted that a balance must be kept between commuter convenience and atmospheric protection. At what point do the public good and survival of the planet override individual convenience? That time is fast approaching.

Some implications of ignoring the warning signs that sustainable limits to development have been exceeded were explored in The Bulletin's May 1988 edition on the ozone problem. The author, Ben Sandilands, describes the difficulties in dealing with larger-than-life issues which, despite their apparent distance from everyday experience, would change daily life forever. He states:

[These issues] confront political systems, which have attention spans of a few years at most, with problems that need action over decades or even centuries. They may lead to crisis in which authoritarian figures arise offering solutions beyond the will or ability of free enterprise economies or normal democratic institutions to provide.

While ozone depletion may be a relatively recent concern for most of us, other environmental and social justice issues continue to receive only token support by this Government. Witness our nation's soil erosion and salinisation and the continuing support for fossil fuel research, development and consumption, despite solemn acknowledgments of the imminent costs of perpetuating the greenhouse effect.

This politically easy deregulatory path which the Government seems intent upon following does not augur well for our environment. Faith in market-place economics will not save the ozone layer or our topsoil, because until the Government actively promotes the sustainable use of renewable resources, they will continue to confront institutional barriers to compete in the market for our custom.

This means looking critically at the energy demands created by large scale developments such as the current proposal for a petrochemical plant in Western Australia. Its purported contribution to our society is to use up so-called surplus natural gas, thus diverting it from more appropriate energy uses, to produce more disposable plastic products. Unfortunately, a lack of public participation in environmental management is something of a tradition in Australia. Since colonial times, the government has been the source of information, knowledge and resources, resulting, as James Colman, town planner, points out:

. . . [in] a strong local tradition of intolerance, suspicion and distrust towards freethinkers, radicals, outsiders and nonconformists. In spite of the great Australian respect for mateship and the independent spirit, as a community we are ever ready to indulge in a knee-jerk reaction whenever we are confronted with a nonconformist or unorthodox view. Those who hold such views are peremptorily labelled ratbags, lunatic fringe dwellers, commos, public enemies, knockers, eco-nuts, greenies and (most derisive of all) intellectuals.

How true that is. Fortunately, awareness of the need for environmental care is growing in the general community. A poll commissioned by the West Australian newspaper in July showed that 85 per cent of West Australians oppose mining in national parks. A nationwide poll conducted this month, by Frank Small and Associates, showed that three-quarters of the Australian community identified the breakdown of the ozone layer as the most significant problem requiring urgent action, 73 per cent of Australians are concerned about the disposal of nuclear wastes, 67 per cent of Australians are concerned about the use of pesticides on crops, and 63 per cent think that forests are being cut too rapidly. These are not the opinions of radical greenies. They are views held widely in the Australian community.

Public attendance at the Greenhouse 88 conferences held around the country at the beginning of this month exceeded expectations. The level of support by participants for immediate action to curb atmospheric pollution was also a surprise to the organising authorities, at least in Perth. Awareness of the public concern for environmental management has also reached the most mainstream news magazines. Time and the Bulletin now feature regular sections on the environment. Significantly, this week's edition of Time is devoted to national environment issues and the role of the voluntary conservation movement in monitoring government commitment to resource management. TALK.START.PARA: —For some years the lack of access to child-care in the Parliamentary Triangle, which is visited literally by millions of people each year, has been regarded as a problem. With regard to what Commonwealth action can be taken, I would have thought that the people of Australia answered that some time ago when they rejected the referendum that we put forward. That is now a domestic matter for Queensland to resolve. I note that Queensland was the closest of any State to agreeing to that referendum question.

ANSWER.PARA: The only way that malapportionment and gerrymandering will be dispensed with in Queensland is when a State Labor government is elected. There is no question in my mind or in the mind of anyone else that if there is a coalition government after the next Queensland State election, the wimpish Liberal Party will cave in again. What they are after is just a share of power.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are just trying to entice us.
—Senator Chaney has some great allies up there. It is a while since he said he wished he had been born in Queensland because if he had he might have done something about the situation up there.
—I said that were I in Queensland I would be arguing for change.

—Well, the honourable senator is not going to Queensland now, thanks to the commissioners. But one never knows, there can always be late swings there. So I say to Senator Chaney that he should not burn all his bridges-he might be looking for one up there yet. The Liberal Party might even have a chance in Queensland. The reality is that the only way to get rid of the gerrymander and malapportionment in Queensland is through a Goss led Labor Government. We know that the Liberals, on their past track record, do not have the strength to stand up to their allies until 1983-the National Party in Queensland.

—I preface my question to the Minister for Finance with an assurance that there is no intention to delay or deny Supply. I assure the Minister that this is a genuine request for information. For how long can the Government continue to meet its obligations without the money that will be authorised by the passage of the Appropriation Bills?

—I do not have completely up to date information on this. I think it was two days ago that I got some information from the Department of Finance. It will be necessary for the Appropriation Bills to be passed by 1 December. I understand that there is probably just enough money, including some drawings on the Advance to the Minister for Finance. —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the new revelations yesterday at the Brisbane corruption expo from ex-Queensland Minister Russ Hinze that Sir Robert Sparkes had `told me, not asked me' to contribute to the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation if he wanted `to get anywhere' in politics. What is the tax treatment appropriate for blackmail?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation has been claiming that it is a charity or a benevolent institution, which I think is the term used in the Income Tax Assessment Act, and therefore whether contributions made to it are eligible as a deduction from taxable income. But in the light of the revelations-I was going to say of the last few days, but really I should say of the last few months or the last year or so-I will ask the Treasurer to refer that question to the Australian Taxation Office.

ANSWER.PARA: It is hard to believe that the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation is a charity or a benevolent institution. Indeed, it is very hard to believe that Sir Robert Sparkes is a modern-day Robin Hood blackmailing his National Party colleagues for charity. I think it is far more likely that he was blackmailing them for some much less worthy purpose. I would have thought, too, that there was some question of contempt of parliament in making such a threat to a Minister, as Mr Hinze then was, in the Queensland Government.

If the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation is a wholly political fund, and if members of the National Party are being blackmailed and told that they will not get anywhere in politics unless they make a contribution to it, it could be argued that that contribution was an expense necessarily incurred in the earning of income.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the position taken on Labor levies on members of parliament?

—That is a permissible deduction. I do not know about other people, but I have claimed that deduction and it has never been queried. If Senator Chaney wants to draw an analogy between the Australian Labor Party and the bunch of crooks who have been running Queensland for the last couple of decades, he is drawing a very long bow because the decision about the requirement to pay levies--

—Mr President, on a point of order: I suspect that if I ever said that the Labor Government of Western Australia, with its involvement with big business and Rothwells, was a bunch of crooks, that would be regarded as a breach of the Standing Orders. I draw your attention to the fact that a general allegation has been made against the Government. I think that is, in all the circumstances, against the Standing Orders and that the Minister should withdraw.
—Order! It was a clear imputation against members of Parliament. I ask Senator Walsh to withdraw.

—I withdraw, Mr President. I note for the record that Senator Chaney is quite happy to align himself with the highly respectable and reputable members of the National Party who have been running Queensland for the past several decades.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. An allegation has been made against Senator Chaney. All he is doing is upholding the Standing Orders of this chamber. I require the Minister to withdraw his allegation against Senator Chaney. All we are trying to do is to keep honourable senators opposite honest.
—I ask Senator Walsh to withdraw the allegation.

—I withdraw, Mr President. I notice that members of the Liberal Party have disowned the National Party members from Queensland who are their colleagues in the Opposition coalition. They cannot have it both ways.
—Mr President, on a point of honesty, my Liberal colleagues have not dissociated themselves from me. I ask you to require the Minister to bear in mind relevance and honesty.
—There is no point of order.

—Senator Chaney, who purports to be a man who stands up for some sort of principle, had the audacity to suggest that the levy that the Labor Party expects its members of Parliament to pay in, I think, all States, something which has been carried publicly in open Labor Party conferences--
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The Minister is clearly misrepresenting the position which I adopted a little while ago.
—There is no point of order.

—Mr President, I am sorry but I will get to the point of order in a moment. The Minister is giving an answer which relates to the matter of the tax deductability of certain payments by politicians. By way of interjection I reminded him that compulsory deductions have applied to Labor Party members of Parliament. That is a public matter, as the Minister has said. The Minister in his response is clearly trying to smear me and anybody else who raises any matter in this regard. I ask you, Mr President, to listen carefully to what the Minister is saying. This Minister is an expert at smear and innuendo and you have a duty to protect the Senate from him.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Walsh has attempted at least three times to explain his attitude to the levy that Senator Chaney put on the record through disorderly interjection. Does Senator Chaney not want to hear the answer to that?
—Order! I have asked Senator Walsh to withdraw on two occasions. He is debating the issue at the moment; he is not out of order. There is no point of order.

—Senator Ray is absolutely correct, of course: a disorderly interjection from Senator Chaney asserted that the blackmailing by the President of the Queensland National Party of Queensland Ministers, done in secret-the clandestine blackmailing--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Boswell

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order, I draw your attention to standing order 418, which says:

INTERJECT.PARA: No Senator shall use offensive words against either House of Parliament . . .
I consider that a reference to the blackmailing of a Minister is an offence under standing order 418.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Mr President, the blackmailer was not a member of the Queensland Parliament but the President of the Queensland National Party.
—Order! There is no point of order. I do not think Senator Walsh was referring to a member of Parliament when he used the word blackmail.

—If Senator Chaney can see no difference between the practice conducted in public, known by everybody who was interested, of the Labor Party and the allegations made by Mr Hinze about the practice of the Queensland National Party, I suggest that his moral development is comparable with that of William Patrick Quick, to whom I referred a couple of days ago. So as far as the Income Tax Assessment Act is concerned, there would be no direct applicability to the relationship between Mr Hinze and the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation if Mr Hinze's claim that he had given not one dollar is correct because, if he made no donation, obviously no deduction could legitimately have been claimed. However, it seems that Mr Hinze has a double standard on these issues. He believes that it is quite okay to be the recipient of a political pay-off but not to be the contributor to it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Why is the Australian Taxation Office delaying for many weeks and in some cases many months-certainly, later than last year-the tax rebate cheques to which hundreds of thousands of honest Australian taxpayers are entitled and covering multimillions of dollars, despite the simplified self-assessment system now operating and despite the increase in staff numbers granted to the Australian Taxation Office this year by the Government? I ask whether the Minister is aware of recent letters from the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in New South Wales blaming the Hawke Government for these delays, which he admits exist, by in one instance saying:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . at this time last year, our resources were such that we were in a position to provide a quick turnaround time for most salary returns that were lodged. This year, however, considerable resource constraints imposed on us as part of the Government's budgetary process has meant that the same situation no longer applies.

The simple fact of the matter is that here in Sydney we have been given a budget to achieve our corporate goals which is considerably less than we would have liked. A consequential outcome is that we are unable to provide the same level of service this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish that Senator Michael Baume had the same level of indignation about dishonest taxpayers ripping off honest taxpayers as he has about the allegation that the Government is ripping off honest taxpayers. I was not aware of the letter that he says has been written by the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation for New South Wales.
—Would you like a copy of it?
—Yes, please, and of any specific cases which the honourable senator has of complaints about alleged unreasonable delays.
—Don't you try to intimidate him.

—I certainly would not try to intimidate Senator Walters. She would not understand intimidation because she lacks the capacity to do so. If Senator Baume has any other specific complaints about individuals I would be pleased to look at those as well. —Read the letter.

—I said that I do not find it very credible, prima facie. Particular circumstances may apply in New South Wales. As Senator Baume himself said in the question, there has been a very significant enhancement in the staff of the Australian Taxation Office not just this year but over a number of years, in marked contrast to the situation which applied in the final years of the Fraser-Howard regime.

—Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of reports that Nelson Mandela will not be returned to prison following his recent hospitalisation? Will Australia continue to press for Mr Mandela's unconditional release?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As most honourable senators will have heard, in a reported statement this morning South African Justice Minister Coetsee announced that Nelson Mandela's improved health will soon allow him to be released from a private clinic in Cape Town and that he will not be returned to prison but to guarded quarters with better facilities, allowing improved access by members of his family. But Minister Coetsee also reportedly said that Mandela could not be released because of the alleged risks or threats to his safety. No information was provided as to what these alleged risks were or what the Government was doing about them, nor did the Justice Minister give any indication whether Mr Mandela's own wishes or views were being taken into account. These must be considered paramount.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government would be most concerned if unsubstantiated alleged risks to Nelson Mandela were to be used as an excuse to delay his release indefinitely. The Government firmly believes that Mandela's unconditional release could help to heal the deep divisions among South Africans and thus help to break that cycle of violence and encourage movement towards a realistic resolution of the country's crisis by peaceful political means. The Government will continue to urge the South African authorities to release Mandela and other political prisoners unconditionally, to repeal current repressive laws, to allow free political expression and organisation, and to negotiate now with authentic black leaders on a non-racist democratic political system based on equality and dignity for all South Africans.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. It arises out of what appears to be widespread concern about the transfer of responsibility for defence service loans from the Defence Service Homes Corporation to the Westpac Banking Corporation. I preface my question by saying that I am sure the Government will have had representations about this in view of the volume of representations I have had in my electoral office from people who are worried about the implications of the sale of the loan portfolio to Westpac, some of whom are quite angry and who believe that their loans are at risk of increased interest rates. Is the Government aware that, in advance of the legislation passing through this Parliament, Westpac is contacting existing loan holders and seeking from them details which many of those concerned feel they should not have to provide to the bank as all of the information is held by the Defence Service Homes Corporation? Is Westpac entitled to make such inquiries at this stage? Will the Minister give an unequivocal assurance that the interest rates now paid on defence service mortgages will not be increased because of the privatisation of the loan portfolio? Finally, will the Minister let us know why the information is being sought by the bank when, presumably, it is held by the Defence Service Homes Corporation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney gave notice of the general nature of this question. I thank him for that, but there are a number of issues in the text of the question that will have to be taken on notice. Nevertheless, Minister Humphreys has advised the following: Existing borrowers will not be disadvantaged in any way by the transfer of the defence service home loans to Westpac. Existing loans have been taken over by Westpac on the same terms and conditions as at present. In particular, the interest rate and monthly repayments will not increase and all ancillary benefits currently available under the present scheme, for example, the widows' relief scheme, will be maintained. The General Manager of the Defence Service Homes Corporation has written to every existing borrower to explain these provisions and to emphasise that the new arrangements are dependent on the passage of enabling legislation by the Parliament. Enclosed with this letter was a letter from Westpac and a form inviting borrowers to nominate the most convenient branch of Westpac with which they could deal. I understand that it is this form which is causing confusion to some borrowers in that it is being seen as seeking their consent to the transfer of the loan, which is not the case. The Westpac letter was intended merely to facilitate that smooth transfer.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney asked me in the chamber before Question Time why the Government had not handed over the information to Westpac. I have tried to seek an answer on this and the response at this stage is that a comprehensive press release has been issued on this. If inquiries have been made to Senator Chaney's office or indeed to other senators' offices, a further press release could be issued. If there is still confusion, we should take the matter up with Minister Humphreys.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Can the Minister confirm that the training allowance for people with disabilities who are undertaking vocational or on the job training was cut back in the 1988 Budget? If so, what was the justification for this, given the Government's stated commitment to providing increased independence and employment opportunities for people with disabilities? What is the amount of the training allowance now? What conditions apply to the payment of this allowance? How does this differ from the amount and conditions applicable before August 1988? How many beneficiaries receive the training allowance? How many of these beneficiaries are women? Is the Minister aware of a report entitled Breaking In and Breaking Out which was produced in 1986 for the Department of Community Services and which showed that disabled women were disproportionately disadvantaged with respect to access to rehabilitation services? Does he deny that the cuts in the training allowance further compound this situation?

—Changes to the rates of the training allowance paid by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service to clients undertaking formal vocational courses were announced in the recent Budget. I am sure Senator Dunn is referring to those changes. The changes are to bring the allowance into line with those paid by the Department of Employment, Education and Training. The training allowance is primarily an incentive payment to encourage clients to undertake vocational training. It is in addition to income support paid in the form of rehabilitation allowances. All other costs associated with clients' rehabilitation programs are met by the Department of Community Services and Health. Clients affected by the new rates received three months advance notice of changes. The new rates-I think this was one of Senator Dunn's questions-from 1 January 1989 are $30 per week for full time courses and $20 per week for part time courses. If any clients believe they are using their training allowance to pay for essential costs associated with their studies, they should discuss the matter further with their local rehabilitation unit. Senator Dunn asked whether I am aware of the report Breaking In and Breaking Out. I am aware of that report and its contents.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to reports that consideration is being given to changing the rules of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) to make it easier for the Prime Minister to be elected as Director-General in due course by allowing the present Director-General, Mr Blanchard, to continue in the position beyond the expiry of his term in February. What will be the attitude of the Australian Government representatives at the ILO to such rule changes? Are they being actively sought by the Australian Government? Who was responsible for initiating the move to change the rules? Is the Prime Minister still keen to treat the ILO as his escape hatch from Australian politics when either the voters reject him or he is overwhelmed by the ambitions of his faithful Treasurer?

—I do not know where that story comes from. It is totally unrelated to the assumptions on which it is asked. If the rules of the ILO are changed in any sense to accommodate our Prime Minister, about the year 2000 will do for us.
—You seem to have had a conversion.
—It is a conversion on the road to Damascus, Senator. I have never heard of this stuff, but I will find out for the honourable senator.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Local Government. Is it true that local government in far north Queensland is now cooperating with the Federal Government in carrying out community projects funded as part of Senator Richardson's generous compensation package? How has this been achieved when the Queensland Government has threatened councils not to deal with the Federal Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Burns for his question. I am pleased to have this opportunity to pay tribute to my colleague Senator Graham Richardson for the work he has done in relation to the listing of the wet tropics in north Queensland. A number of myths abound about the cooperation of local government. For example, for nearly 12 months Senator Boswell has been speaking in this place and elsewhere about how local government is distressed and how local government will not talk with Senator Richardson or me or officers from our respective departments. Nothing could be further from the truth. It is certainly correct that local councils and their representatives do not necessarily agree with World Heritage listing. That is their right in a democratic country. However, unlike the Queensland State Government, local government has been responsible enough to continue, on an ongoing basis for over 12 months now, to work very closely with the rainforest unit and with the Office of Local Government.
—I thought it was called blackmail.

—Senator Boswell interjects `blackmail'. Well may he talk blackmail, because in actual fact it was the Queensland Government that told local councils that they were not to do business with Senator Richardson or me, because it is the Queensland Government that is being intransigent and uncooperative in this regard. Of course, we have worked quietly away behind the scenes talking with local government about opportunities for its communities, and at last, in the last 10 days or so, we have finally reached agreement. I announced in Ingham only last week the first of the community initiatives projects, and I will be announcing later today the second of the community initiatives projects for none other than the tableland region. I had an interesting conversation with a journalist from the tableland up there who said, `How can these councils agree to go ahead with your community initiatives project when they are so opposed to World Heritage listing?'. I said, `Well, you had better ask the councils that'. The reality is that the councils are pragmatic. They are concerned about the needs of their communities, and they are very enthusiastic about the way the community initiatives project can assist their people. They know that our community initiatives project is based on the very successful two-year pilot program of the country centres project. They know that this approach brings the community together, identifies new opportunities, and brings new investment to a region, and that it is a very appropriate form of structural adjustment for an area undergoing considerable changes.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is appropriate that I should be placing on record the support that local government has given and the fact that this is in total contrast to the Queensland Government, which has not been prepared to negotiate and has spread impossible rumours, such as saying that great vigilance is necessary because we are going to set up new local authorities in the region-which is an absolute furphy and goes totally against local government legislation in Queensland. Yet persistently the Hon. Jim Randell and Geoff Muntz are putting out press releases saying that the Federal Government will create new local governments in north Queensland. What nonsense! That is what the issue of constitutional recognition of local government was all about-that only State governments have control over any amalgamations of local governments.

So I commend local government. I think that it has been a great pleasure to work with it and I look forward to ongoing cooperation with local government and between Senator Richardson's Department and my own.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories whether his attention has been drawn to an article appearing on the front page of this morning's Australian newspaper which, in part, states:

QUESTION.PARA: Senior government sources yesterday confirmed the region-
here referring to the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests-
would be nominated for listing because it gave the Government `more direct influence' over the forests in order to secure their protection.
A source said: What we want to ensure is protection of those areas.

Is it the intention of the Government to proceed to nominate the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests areas for World Heritage listing without consultation with the Tasmanian State Government? When will a final determination be made on all outstanding issues arising from the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to the article. Although I have not read it, I have been told about it. I take Senator Puplick's word for the quotes that he read out. In fact the journalist concerned, I am told, did come around to my office last night and was assured by at least two members of my staff that the story she wrote was not true; she wrote it nonetheless. We will be having a meeting with Mr Gray on Monday afternoon to discuss those two courses of action.
