TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to you, Mr President. I refer to an article published in the November edition of Labor Review in Queensland referring to the recent death, at the age of 84, of Miss Margaret Fisher, or `Peg' as she was affectionately called, who was the daughter of the great Australian Prime Minister Andrew Fisher, who served Australia as a Labor Prime Minister between 1908 and 1915. In view of assertions in the article written by Larry Noye, that Mr Fisher's portrait, originally in King's Hall in our former House, was subsequently relegated to a spot near the old post office and since our moving to this place is unhung anywhere, I ask: is this in fact the case? If so, will the President take urgent steps to ensure that this great Queenslander is recognised for his past endeavours by having his portrait hung in a place of prominence?

—I thank Senator Jones for drawing my attention to the circumstanc es surrounding the portrait of Andrew Fisher. I have been advised that the portrait of the former Prime Minister is one of the very large portraits-2.7 metres by 1.8 metres-which have been extremely difficult to display in this new building. Apparently there are 12 portraits which are of this scale. However, I have instructed the relevant parliamentary officers to take the necessary steps to display these large portraits on a rotational basis in the Members Hall area. I can assure Senator Jones that the portrait of Andrew Fisher, a distinguished Prime Minister, will be among the first of these larger portraits to be displayed.

—The Minister for Community Services and Health would be aware that from 1 August 1988 the prescription quantity of the drug Melleril, which is on the national health list, was increased from 100 to 200 tablets. Is the Minister aware of the dangers of increasing the availability of larger dosages of this drug, given that the major users of this potent tranquilliser are psychiatric patients, the aged and manic depressives who, in many instances, abuse their medication? Will the Minister review this decision?

—I thank Senator Watson for his question and his descriptive introduction to the uses of the drug he has referred to. I think that question requires an opinion of the Minister. I will seek that and advise the honourable senator in due course.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask: What is the Government's reaction to the commuting of the death sentences passed on the Sharpeville Six? Are executions nevertheless continuing in South Africa? If so, what is the Government's attitude to the imposition and carrying out of the death sentence?
—What is this-be kind to South Africa week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Something we can never expect from Senator MacGibbon is an appreciation of what is going on in that country.
—Order!

—As the Prime Minister made clear in the House of Representatives yesterday, the Government very much welcomes the decision of State President Botha to commute the death sentences against the Sharpeville Six. Also-this might be a little more to the taste of Senator MacGibbon-the Government naturally welcomes the decision by the President to commute the death sentences of the white policemen. Australia also made representations in those cases. It might come as some surprise to Senator MacGibbon and the fellow squawkers on the benches opposite to appreciate that we are consistent in our approach because we are absolutely opposed to capital punishment imposed on anyone because of its cruelty and inhumanity.

ANSWER.PARA: The decision in relation to the Sharpeville Six must be regarded as something of a victory for international public opinion in view of the many calls for the reprieve of the six, including personal appeals by the Prime Minister to the South African Ambassador. Our Ambassador in Pretoria made renewed representations on behalf of the six as the Court of Appeal refused leave to appeal and before the death sentences were commuted. Of course, relief at the news has to be tempered by the lengthy prison terms that the six have been sentenced to-up to 25 years. Those sentences seem particularly onerous in view of the highly controversial use of the common purpose doctrine in this case. The relief that most of us at least feel about the reprieve of the six has also been very much tempered by the further news received this morning that several more people have been hanged in South Africa in the last 24 hours since the reprieve of the six.

The ugly reality of the matter is that, in addition to all the other offences against fundamental human rights that the South African Government perpetrates, that country hangs more people in terms of population than any Western country. Between 1983 and 1987, 627 people have been executed in South Africa. And the number is increasing. Last year there were 164 executions-the highest number in 75 years.

Finally, on 11 November the Australian Ambassador in Pretoria, at my direction, made representations to the South African Government over the very frequent use of the death penalty in that country and we will continue to voice that concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the article in yesterday's Australian Financial Review concerning proposed new remuneration arrangements for senior public servants? Can the Minister confirm the substance of this article? Is the Government, as part of its proposal to introduce a performance based salary system, also considering movements downwards in salaries in the case of public servants not performing their duties adequately and a greater use of contract employment to provide increased flexibility in the Public Service? Are these proposed new arrangements going to be referred to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and be tested against the Commission's wage guidelines? When does the Government propose to introduce the new payments system to stem the tide of Public Service resignations and to improve the performance and professionalism of the Service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the detail of the article in question which Senator Messner referred me to, or any comment made in that article, but I am able to answer some of the points which he raised in his question and, if there are any shortcomings, I will try to supply an additional answer. The Government has indicated that, consistent with its emphasis on increased public sector efficiency, consideration is being given to developing a new approach to remuneration for the most senior levels of the Public Service. These matters are still being given careful consideration by the Government in light of overall wage policy.

ANSWER.PARA: However, the Government has agreed that departmental secretaries and Senior Executive Service (SES) officers at level 3 and above-that is, division heads and deputy secretaries-be given private use of the government cars they currently drive to and from work, which will bring conditions of service for senior Public Service managers into line with their private sector counterparts. A personal financial contribution to offset the private use will be required and, during working days, cars will continue to be available to departments for official use.

The Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Peter Morris, also announced on 22 November an early retirement scheme to allow some staff in the Public Service over the age of 50 to take advantage of early retirement. That is consistent with the Government's ongoing reform to ensure that the Public Service is effective and responsive to requirements. The scheme will be administered by departmental secretaries who will be able to invite staff who are over 50, in the levels immediately below the SES, who are not coping fully with the nature and pace of change in the Public Service to retire. They will be entitled to the standard voluntary retirement benefits that apply in redundancy situations.

This proposal has been the subject of consultations with relevant unions, which have been supportive of it, and there are to be further staff consultations on the detail of the scheme. It is entirely voluntary. There will be no pressure on staff to retire if they do not wish to do so. But, by allowing staff who are coming closer to retirement and, in some cases, are anxious to retire, to retire early with appropriate benefits, the scheme will allow for an infusion of new talent and energy at the middle management level of the Service.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The Minister made a statement about the proposed Australian Capital Territory (ACT) casino, as recorded at page 1961 of the Senate Hansard of 3 November, in the following terms:

QUESTION.PARA: The new self-governing ACT obviously should have the last say on how this project will proceed.

Can the Minister assure the Senate that any area of land in section 19 of Canberra will not be sold or otherwise disposed of to developers until such time as the incoming ACT legislature has had time to examine the issue? STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) BILL 1988

The main purpose of this Bill is to set in place the next four years of the Government's historic eight-year general recurrent funding scheme, by providing guaranteed real increases in general recurrent funding for both government and non-government schools for the 1989 to 1992 funding period.

The Bill also appropriates funds for 1989 for the specific purpose and capital programs at the same real level as in 1988. The ethnic schools program continues to receive funding at the same money level as in 1988.

As announced in the May statement, from 1989 there will be changes to some elements of the Government's planning and funding policy for new non-government schools designed to ensure the best use of available resources and a co-ordinated approach to planning. The new minimum enrolment requirements have already been determined under the former Act and will continue under this Bill. For established schools not covered by sections 6c (1) or 7c (1) of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1984, the minimum enrolment requirement will be one for each level of education provided by the school. In addition, new non-systemic schools will be funded at categories 1 to 6 only and establishment grants will be discontinued from 1989. Schools currently receiving establishment grants, however, will continue to receive them under the previous arrangements.

The Bill also implements the Government's decision that requests for a review of recurrent funding category will be considered only on the ground that there has been a significant change in the need for financial assistance resulting from factors outside the school's control.

There has been a significant simplification to the language and structure of the schools legislation. The former Act has proved to be unnecessarily complex and has made difficult the efficient administration of the Commonwealth's programs for schools.

One effect of this has been the removal of the detailed financial conditions which have appeared in the legislation to date. The Bill now requires States and non-government school authorities to enter into an agreement with the Commonwealth before payments can be made. These agreements will include the normal accountability requirements that were previously included in the Act.

Under the previous Act, resource agreements with State governments and with non-government school system authorities have only applied to the real increases in general recurrent grants provided since 1985. This Bill will provide the flexibility to enable agreements from 1989 to apply to the total general recurrent grant each year and to reflect more closely the educational objectives of the Commonwealth, the States and non-government school authorities.
Some concern has been expressed about the nature of the objectives to be included in agreements and possible penalties for failure to meet those objectives.

School authorities can be assured that the form and content of the agreements will be fully negotiated. For government schools, the Minister has already had detailed consultations with State Education Ministers. Broad national goals for schooling are being identified and these will serve as a basis for cooperation and collaboration and will assist in the further development of specific objectives and strategies by each government school system. Agreements with the States will reflect this process.

There have also been detailed consultations with non-government school authorities on the form and content of agreements. These agreements will reflect the above-mentioned broad national goals for schooling. They will, however, recognise that non-government schools have their own objectives and priorities. Schools and systems will be asked to provide a statement of their objectives and priorities and the strategies they will be adopting to address those objectives. There will be no question of schools being penalised for failing to achieve their objectives.
The explicit process of identifying objectives and articulating strategies will lead to better education for Australia's children.

This Bill also recognises that schools and systems are being faced with real increases in their operating costs arising from the implementation of the 3 per cent productivity superannuation agreement and provides appropriate supplementation to grants to assist in meeting these costs.

The financial impact of this Bill will be to appropriate an estimated $1,913m for 1989 programs, $1,533m for general recurrent grants in 1990, $1,574m for general recurrent grants in 1991 and $1,611m for general recurrent grants in 1992.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988

The primary purpose of this Bill is to adjust 1988 grants to government and non-government schools in the States and Northern Territory, in line with the Government's policy or providing retrospective cost supplementation for the Commonwealth's programs for schools to meet price increases that have occurred during the year. Included in this adjustment for price increases is an amount of $5.6 million which will be allocated to those non-government schools and systems which have had an increase in their operating costs in 1988 arising from implementation of the 3% productivity superannuation agreement.

The Bill also implements the decision announced in the May Statement that proposed new non-government schools no longer need to be able to demonstrate that they have reasonable prospects of financial viability prior to receiving approval.
The total amount of supplementation to be provided by this Bill is $21.6 million.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
STATES GRANTS (TECHNICAL AND FURTHER EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 1988

The States Grants (Technical and Further Education Assistance) Bill 1988 gives effect to the Government's budget decisions on Commonwealth assistance for TAFE in 1989 as announced in TAFE 1989 Commonwealth Programs and Priorities which was released on 24 August 1988.
The purpose of the Bill is to provide the legislative basis for the distribution of Commonwealth funds for technical and further education in the States and the Northern Territory for 1989.

The Bill provides $313.152m for technical and further education for 1989. The allocation of these resources reaffirms the Government's commitment to the directions set out in Skills for Australia in 1988 and reflects the new agenda for technical and further education and the Government's continued commitment to establish a framework for the future development of TAFE.

Against the background of the macro-economic reforms already in place, and the increasing focus on structural adjustment policies, the Government's broad objectives for technical and further education are to achieve:
further increases in participation in vocational education and training;
improvements in the relevance of TAFE provision;
productivity improvements and efficiency gains in the use of existing resources;
greater industry involvement in TAFE; and
an enhancement of the labour market prospects of the unemployed and other disadvantaged groups.

In 1988 the Government moved from a system of earmarked grants for TAFE to the provision of a general recurrent grant subject to resource agreements with the States. The Commonwealth maintained a substantial infrastructure program, providing around 65 per cent of the total Australian investment in TAFE buildings. The negotiation of resource agreements provides as mechanism for an integrated approach to Commonwealth and State priorities for TAFE, a new flexibility in the use of Commonwealth funding and a new emphasis on performance and outcomes. In 1989 the Government will continue to place a strong emphasis on the national development of TAFE, through both the General Recurrent Program and the Infrastructure Program.

Expanding participation in vocational education and training is fundamental to the Government's plans for economic growth and social justice. While TAFE's role as a significant provider of further training, designed to facilitate the development and maintenance of a highly skilled and efficient labour force will continue, emphasis in 1989 TAFE funding will be given to expanding opportunities for Australians to undertake entry-level education and training in pre-vocational, trade, certificate and para-professional courses.

The Government will continue to emphasise also the importance of strengthening relationships between industry and TAFE in relation to curricula, staff development, delivery arrangements, equipment and use of facilities. The Joint Venture Equipment initiative introduced in 1988 will be enhanced in 1989 as a means of providing an increased incentive for industry to contribute to the purchase of equipment for TAFE and generally promoting links with industry.

Despite significant developments during the past five years, the access of disadvantaged groups and women especially sole parents, to education and training remains a problem. In 1989 the Government will, consistent with its other Budget measures, begin an attack on two of the major barriers to the participation in TAFE of Aborigines and women with children, particularly sole parents. During the next three years the Government will commit $10m from the Infrastructure Program for the construction of facilities directed towards enhancing the participation of Aboriginals in TAFE. The provision of child care has been identified as one of the barriers to the participation of women in TAFE. Accordingly the Government will commit $6m from the Infrastructure Program during the next three years to expand the provision of child care facilities for TAFE students.

The Government will provide for 1989 an Infrastructure Program of $186.065m. Within this program the Government will give consideration to projects that meet its priorities for economic and social development, in particular those that:
generate additional capacity in areas of strategic economic importance;
are directed towards the training of Aboriginals or provide additional child care facilities; and
enhance the capacity of TAFE to respond to the training needs of young Australians, including trainees under the Australian Traineeship System.

The Commonwealth will continue to provide a level of recurrent funding for TAFE that meets about 9% of the total recurrent expenditure. The Bill provides for a General Recurrent Program of $120.434m. This includes funds to maintain those courses provided by the New South Wales and Queensland TAFE authorities that were previously funded under higher education arrangements.

Special grants for advanced English language courses for migrants will be maintained in real terms at the 1988 level to enable TAFE to continue the provision of courses which migrants will need to develop the more advanced English necessary for occupational purposes or for further study. Grants for adult literacy and for non-government adult education are also maintained in real terms.

The Bill also provides for the subsidies payment provided to non-government business colleges; it gives effect to the phasing out of the scheme as detailed in TAFE 1989 Commonwealth Programs and Priorities and also provides an additional $1.5 million to assist colleges in the first half of 1989 to adjust their financial bases following the withdrawal of the subsidies and meet commitments already made to students in respect of 1989.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING BILL 1988

In the 1988-89 Budget context the Government released A New Commitment to Higher Education in Australia, which marked the culmination of an intensive twelve-month process of discussion and review of the future of higher education in Australia. The Statement addressed this Government's plans for substantial growth in higher education over the next three years, the associated resource requirements of the higher education system, measures to improve equity of access to higher education, and the means by which the total resources required for growth can be provided.

The expansion and funding strategy, the cornerstone of the Government's Higher Education package, is one of the most significant in the history of Australia's higher education system, ensuring that the system will have been substantially expanded over the 1989-91 Triennium. The Higher Education Funding Bill 1988 gives effect to the decisions announced in the Budget statement, with adjustments to take account of the Government's policies on cost supplementation.

To support its growth plans, the Government will significantly increase in real terms the funds available to higher education institutions over the next triennium. Funds will be increased over 1988 grants by $141 million in 1989, $275 million in 1990 and $427 million in 1991. This represents a total real increase in resources over the next three years of $843 million.

The main thrust of the Higher Education Package is the creation of more higher education opportunities, particularly for young Australians. Taking into account pipeline effects of funded increases, an additional 49,000 places will be created by 1991.

Special recurrent funds have been earmarked to promote access and equity. The Higher Education Equity Projects Program, first introduced in 1985 and currently expending $1.2 million each year, will be boosted by a further $2 million in each year of the new triennium. $1 million will be used to provide seeding grants to assist institutions to incorporate proven pilot initiatives into their programs. A further $1 million will be used to provide additional child care places for higher education students.

Provision has also been made to earmark 200 of the annual intake increases over the triennium for Aborigines under the Aboriginal Participation Initiative, bringing to around 3,000 the total number of higher education places for aboriginal students by 1991.
The growth in higher education planned by the Government will need a substantial increase in capital facilities. As a result there will be a significant injection of capital funds during 1989-91.

Capital funds will rise from $78.5 million this year to $126.7 million in 1989, $145.4 million in 1990 and $177.2 million in 1991. Included in the 1989 grant is a special injection of $19 million for the urgent renovation of higher education buildings.

Institutions will also be assisted by the introduction of rolling triennial funding, enabling them to undertake long term planning with confidence. The introduction of a single operating grant to replace the existing general recurrent, equipment, minor works and special research grants will enhance institutions' flexibility in the use of their recurrent funds.

To help finance the substantial expansion in the funding of higher education that was announced in the 1988-89 Budget, the Bill makes provision for the establishment of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS).

HECS will apply to study in award courses undertaken in higher education institutions from 1 January 1989. People who benefit from participation in higher education will be required to make a small contribution towards the cost of their study. The scheme will replace the existing Higher Education Administration Charge (HEAC) which required a payment by students on enrolment.
The key features of HECS are:
an annual course charge of $1,800 per year of equivalent full-time study for study in award courses;
pro rata charges according to the actual proportion of an equivalent full-time load being undertaken;
payment arrangements based upon personal capacity to pay; and

a choice between lump-sum payment with a 15 per cent discount at the time of enrolment each semester or payment through the taxation system once a person's taxable income reaches $22,000 (i.e., around the level of average earnings in the Australian workforce).
If people choose to pay through the taxation system, the required annual repayments of HECS liability, once the Scheme is fully operational, will be:
nothing for personal taxable incomes below $22,000;
1 per cent of personal taxable income for incomes of $22,000 to $24,999;
2 per cent of personal taxable income for incomes of $25,000 to $34,999;
3 per cent of personal taxable income for incomes of $35,000 or more; and
no further payment once debts are discharged.
These repayment rates will be halved for the current financial year in view of the introduction of the Scheme on 1 January 1989.

The annual course charge, the outstanding debt and the personal taxable income levels above which payment is required will be indexed to keep pace with inflation. These arrangements will ensure that those paying the charge will pay the same amount in real terms, regardless of how long they take to do so.
The Scheme will cover all higher education students (both new and continuing) and study undertaken from 1 January 1989, except for:
students enrolled in fee-paying postgraduate courses;
students in non-award courses;
students in recognised bridging and supplementary courses;
overseas students who are fully sponsored under a foreign aid program, who are subject to full fees or who are otherwise subject to the Overseas Students Charge arrangements;

students enrolled in basic nurse education courses will be exempt until 1993, when the Commonwealth takes over full responsibility for funding these courses (unless State and Territory governments ask the Commonwealth to collect the contribution on their behalf before 1993);
students undertaking industrial experience as part of a course will not be liable for that proportion of their course spent in industry;
students receiving a postgraduate scholarship exempting them from liability; and

students enrolled at Marcus Oldham College of Farm Management and students enrolled in courses at Avondale College, McAuley College or Signadou College of Education that are not funded by the Commonwealth.
Adult and continuing education students and TAFE students, including those studying higher education courses provided wholly by TAFE institutions, are not covered by the Scheme.
With those exceptions, the Scheme will apply to all students enrolled in higher education institutions from 1 January 1989. There is no liability for studies undertaken prior to 1 January 1989.

To encourage participation in postgraduate courses, especially those relevant to the national research effort, a system of postgraduate scholarships will be introduced providing exemption from liability under HECS for a given year of study. To be directed particularly at full-time higher degree students, these scholarships will be allocated by institutions in accordance with Government guidelines. Institutions have already been advised of their allocation of scholarships for 1989. A special allocation of postgraduate awards will be incorporated under this arrangement to assist in the professional development of teachers.

The Government will establish a Higher Education Trust Fund to receive all HECS funds collected by the Australian Taxation Office. These funds will help finance the expansion of the higher education system.

The Trust Fund will operate as follows. The Commonwealth, under its `benefits to students' power, will make direct payments from the Trust Fund to higher education institutions each semester to fully discharge students' outstanding course charge liabilities for that semester. These payments will amount to about 20 per cent of total operating grants to institutions. The Trust Fund will be financed in part from HECS payments made by students through the taxation system, and in part from a reallocation of general operating grants for higher education which would otherwise be paid to institutions via the States. The remaining 80 per cent of total funding will continue to be paid via the States in line with current arrangements.

All students who are liable under the Scheme will be offered a choice of payment arrangements each semester. They may choose to pay their liabilities in a lump sum directly to the institution, in which case a discount of up to 15 per cent will apply. Alternatively, they may ask the Commonwealth to pay their contribution to the institution and agree to repay the Commonwealth through the taxation system. Students who thereby incur higher education debts to the Commonwealth will also be required to notify the institution of their current tax file number or where they do not have one, make written application for a tax file number.

The provisions of this legislation relating to the use of tax file numbers for purposes of the Scheme are based upon, and are generally consistent with, the corresponding provisions in the government's general Tax File Number legislation currently before Parliament. Normal taxation secrecy provisions will protect the privacy of a student's taxation information, including the tax file number. In addition, the provisions of the Government's Privacy Bill relating to the use of the tax file number generally will apply equally to the use of the tax file number for purposes of this Scheme.

The Higher Education Contribution Scheme is an essential part of the Government's plans for expansion and development of the higher education system. In financial terms it will raise more than one-third of the additional funding for the 1989-91 triennium allocated to higher education in the Budget. The size of this contribution will grow in future years. Just as important, the Scheme will increase the fairness of funding arrangements for higher education, ensuring that the total burden of funding does not fall entirely on the taxpayer.

For these reasons the Government believes that the introduction of the scheme must be a pre-condition for implementation of the other aspects of its higher education package. It has framed its legislation accordingly. In the event of significant amendments or outright rejection of those provisions of the Bill giving effect to HECS, the Government will have no alternative but to curtail its plans to expand higher education. Without HECS, the higher education administration charge will be retained and indexed, and the funding of higher education institutions for the next three years will be held at a level consistent with the maintenance of 1988 funding levels in real terms together with pipeline effects for funded intakes prior to 1989. The unfortunate consequence would be that many Australians would then be denied the opportunity to participate in higher education.

The Budget announcements on higher education were followed by a series of consultations between officers of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, individual higher education institutions and State authorities. This process, which enabled the Commonwealth to identify priorities for the allocation of resources according to State and regional needs, and the agreed educational profile of each institution, continued during September and October. Advice on these matters has also been sought from the Higher Education Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training.

As the Government's policy statement on higher education made clear, Commonwealth support will be directed mainly towards those institutions which form part of the unified national system of higher education. The letter of invitation to all higher education institutions requested a response by 30 September, but the Commonwealth agreed to accept a response by 30 October in line with the publicly expressed wishes of some institutions for more time for consideration. Decisions on final membership of the unified national system will be made during November.

Because of the timetable for consultative processes and membership of the unified national system, the Government was faced with severe time constraints in the drafting of funding legislation for the 1989-91 triennium. As a result, while this Bill incorporates system-wide funding levels, it has not been possible to include details of the allocation of grants to individual institutions. The Government proposes instead to table before both Houses of Parliament this session a report which will give details of the majority of institutional grants for each year of the 1989-91 triennium. The Government will then table determinations in early December which will give legislative effect to its decisions on institutional grants.
HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1988

The second reading speech introducing the Higher Education Funding Bill 1988 outlined the Government's proposals for funding of higher education during the 1989-91 triennium. It also made clear the Government's intention that successful introduction of the new higher education contribution scheme should be a pre-condition for the program of expansion and development which was announced in the 1988-89 Budget.

Consistent with this intention, the Higher Education Funding Bill itself makes no provision for the appropriation of funds to finance the growth initiatives covered by Chapter 3 of the Bill. Subject to successful passage of that Bill, however, this Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill is designed to amend the provisions of sections 115-119 of the principal Act to allow for the payments authorised under chapter 3 to be made out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund or the Loan Fund, as appropriate.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1988

The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the Overseas Students Charge Act 1979 to fix the overseas students charge rates for the 1989 academic year. The levels of the charge are indicated in the Bill.

Charges for higher education courses will remain at the current percentage rate of the full average cost of a place to the Commonwealth. Charges for TAFE courses will remain at the current percentage of the Commonwealth contribution to a TAFE place. The actual increases in the charges reflect the increase in cost to the Commonwealth. The increase in the secondary charge reflects the movement in the consumer price index.

A further purpose of this Bill is to extend charge liability to an overseas student who is enrolled as a casual higher education student undertaking miscellaneous studies not for award. This is expected to raise $3.6m in 1988-89.
The overseas students charge raised $56.7m in 1987-88 (higher education administration charge not included) and is expected to raise $70.3m in 1988-89.
The Bill also makes some changes to terminology to be consistent with that of the Employment, Education and Training Act 1988.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Overseas Students Charge Collection Act to extend charge exemption to a tertiary student who enters Australia under an approved reciprocal organisation exchange. This will bring exemption provisions for tertiary exchange students into line with current provisions for secondary students and is estimated to cost around $200,000 in 1988-89.

A further purpose of this Bill is to ensure that an overseas student enrolled as a casual higher education student is subject to the same provisions as an overseas student enrolled in a prescribed course.
The Bill also makes some changes to terminology to reflect current administrative arrangements and to remove sexist language.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the revised explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The creation of the Australian Sports Commission in 1985 is now history and it is pleasing to reflect on some of its achievements. Since it commenced operations the Commission has addressed a variety of issues of importance to developing sporting opportunities for all Australians at the community level. A fine example of this has been the development of a major children-in-sport program-Aussie Sports, which although launched as recently as April 1986 has now been implemented in over 1,700 primary schools and reached over 500,000 children.

The Commission has been actively involved in the drugs in sport campaign, and has established a national program on drugs in sport which has seen the implementation of a program of drug testing during training and at sporting events, and the production and distribution of information kits warning against the use of drugs in sport throughout Australia and to over 40 countries overseas. Perhaps one of its most noteworthy achievements, however, has been the establishment of an Australian Sports Aid Foundation as a public company to raise money from the corporate sector and the community at large to supplement Government funding for the development of Australian sport. In order to maximise such support tax deductibility on donations to the Foundation was approved in June 1986. The result of this initiative has been very encouraging with over $2.3m being donated to the Foundation, and paid out through the Commission, for distribution in support of our national sporting organisations and specific sporting events, such as the defence of the America's Cup, during 1986-87.

In addition to these activities, the Commission has continued to administer the Government's major programs of sports assistance: the sports development program and the sports talent encouragement plan. In 1987-88 the sports development program provided almost $6.3m to 94 national sporting organisations and other bodies to assist with, amongst other things, administration, junior sports development programs, coaching development, travel to international sporting competition, and the drugs in sport program. The sports talent encouragement plan provides direct financial support to individual athletes and teams to help defray costs and loss of earnings associated with training and participation in sporting competitions. This year in excess of $600,000 will be made available to about 300 athletes, the majority of whom are members of the Australian Olympic team.

Following on from this last point, I would like to turn to our elite athletes and the Australian Institute of Sport. When this Government was elected, the Australian Institute of Sport was still in its infancy. There were only 183 scholarship holders in eight residential sports in 1983. Its training and competition facilities had not been completed, it was not fully staffed, and it was still in the process of developing its various coaching and training programs. As the Institute has become increasingly settled, it has been possible to build on the initial base established by the previous Government. A further seven sports have been accepted since 1984. Many of the new sports have been decentralised, and as such the Institute has been able to establish a significant presence in Brisbane with diving and squash, Perth with hockey, and Adelaide with cycling and cricket. The cooperation and assistance of State and local governments and State institutes of sport has been invaluable in this process. Smaller satellite units have also been set up in Melbourne and Sydney. These developments have given the Institute a truly national profile.

With its world class facilities and a highly qualified and professional administrative and coaching staff, the Institute has worked effectively towards realising its major aim of improved athlete performance. And while the international success of any individual athlete or team can be said to result from a variety of factors, the Institute has played an important role in the improved sporting performances of many Australian athletes and teams over recent years. Together the Institute and the Commission have contributed greatly to the development of Australian sport in recent years. The objectives of the two organisations are complementary and are derived from the broader Government objectives of encouraging increased participation in sport by all Australians, promoting equity of opportunity at the community level, and providing opportunities and support for the development of our elite athletes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Equality of opportunity?

—I actually said `equity of opportunity'. We are always about fairness. Beyond the financial support, the facilities, the technical expertise and the leadership they have offered, they have provided for a balanced involvement by government in sport. All Australians, be they high performance athletes, coaches, members of national, State or local sporting bodies, or individuals who have the opportunity to participate in community sports programs or utilise local sports facilities, have benefited from the existence of both organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: With the support of the Commission the sporting community has begun to recognise and take on the responsibility for the further development of sport in Australia. To qualify for continued assistance under the sports development program, for instance, national sporting organisations have had to adopt a more professional administrative approach, and to plan for the individual future development of their respective sports.

We have come a long way since March 1983. The sporting community has a greater appreciation of the fact that it cannot rely on government to shoulder all the responsibility associated with sports development. Similarly, the Australian Institute of Sport and the Australian Sports Commission have made great advances in their relatively brief histories. They, too, have demonstrated a maturity in overseeing the development of Australian sport at all levels.

It is now necessary to consolidate the achievements to date, and to reassess the Commonwealth's role in the development of sport at the national level. In doing so, this Government will ensure the further improvement of an environment favourable to the continued development of sport in Australia. At the same time it must use its resources as efficiently and effectively as possible. A merging of the functions and administrations of the Commission and the Institute and some of the sports program functions of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to rationalise government involvement in sport will achieve this end.
Government Announcement

On 25 September last year, the former Minister responsible for sport, the Hon. John Brown, announced the Government's intention to streamline the Commonwealth's sports administration through the establishment of a single national sport body-to be known as the Australian Sports Commission. The new Commission will assume responsibility for the functions of the Institute and the Commission as they are presently constituted. Since that announcement, as an interim arrangement pending passage of this legislation, the Institute and the Commission have, for all intents and purposes, been informally amalgamated. For instance, the sports talent encouragement plan, previously administered by the Commission, has been transferred to the control of the elite athlete side of the new organisation, while the sport for people with disabilities program and aspects of the cultural relations program concerning sporting exchanges have been transferred from the Department to the Commission. These rationalisations, in addition to producing staffing and servicing savings, will remove the overlap and uncertainty which previously existed in government sports administration at the national level.
Major Features of the Bill

The Bill outlines the objectives of the new Australian Sports Commission, which are to provide leadership in the development of sport in Australia; to encourage increased participation by Australians in sport; to provide support for the development of high performance athletes; to improve the sporting abilities of Australians generally; to foster cooperation in sport between Australia and other countries; and to encourage the private sector to contribute to the funding of sport and so supplement assistance provided by government.

The Bill defines the general functions of the Commission, which include program management, the coordination of our national sporting effort, and the requirement to consult widely with the sporting community. It also outlines the functions of the Commission which will be undertaken under the name of the Institute. The Bill also describes the powers that the Commission will have to undertake its activities. These powers are largely a composite of those described in the pieces of legislation that will be repealed with the enactment of this legislation. As an additional check, the Commission will be required to submit estimates in respect of its proposed budget, and to produce an annual report, an annual operational plan, and a strategic plan tied to the Olympic cycle every four years. Each of these must be approved by the responsible Minister. Its financial affairs will also be subject to scrutiny by the Auditor-General.
Financial Impact Statement

The strategic and annual operational plan requirements are in line with the Government's commitment to overall financial management improvement within the public sector. In its strategic plan the Commission will be required to develop objectives for its programs and activities, to define performance indicators, and to regularly evaluate performance against these indicators. Ministerial endorsement of the plan will be required. Already, as a result of the interim arrangements, the rationalisation of program administration between the Institute, the Commission and the Department has achieved a saving of five staff years. Relocation of all staff at the Bruce facilities has also generated significant accommodation savings.

In addition, under this legislation, membership of the Commission will not exceed 12. This compares favourably with the membership arrangements this legislation will supersede, which allowed for up to 22 commissioners to be appointed to the Australian Sports Commission, and up to 14 members to be appointed to the Australian Institute of Sport Board of Management. The fewer board appointments will produce savings in terms of total remuneration paid to members, reduced meeting costs, and a reduced requirement for secretariat and other support services. Overall non-staff savings are expected to be in the order of $250,000 per annum.

Under the legislation, the Commission will continue to receive funds from the private sector donated to the Australian Sports Aid Foundation-which, incidentally, will in future be known as the Australian Sports Foundation-in order to supplement public funding made available for sports development.
Priorities

I mentioned earlier that since the interim arrangements came into effect in October last year, the amalgamated organisation has continued to operate existing programs and services. It has also continued to grapple with a number of contentious and challenging issues. Foremost among these, perhaps, is related to the need for the sporting community to explain to the Australian community and its political representatives the value of sport to the community and, therefore, why it is necessary to provide continuing financial support. This becomes a particular concern given the pressures in the corporate and business sectors that, of late, have seen a reduction in the level of private funding being channelled into sport.

The Commission, therefore, will work to achieve and sustain the valuable outcomes that can be derived from sport, such as more children playing sport, assistance to coaching to improve the overall standard of sporting performance throughout Australia, the continued fight against drugs in sport, and so on. This, in turn, will mean identifying the resources available, both government and private, and ensuring that they are directed in ways that will maximise their impact and benefit.

But increased funding is not the only requirement of sport, if it is to continue to grow. We also need a sound administrative infrastructure, particularly at the national level. We need efficient and effective management to ensure that what we spend has the most beneficial impact for Australian society as a whole. We need a unified approach to sports administration if we are to undertake the increasingly complex task that is sports development in the late 1980s.

Mr President, the Government is confident that the proposed Australian Sports Commission is a new and improved organisation that will consolidate the considerable gains made by sport over the life of this Government and allow for the continued and organised development of Australian sport into the 1990s and beyond. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1988

Mr President, this is the first of four Bills to amend the sales tax law to give effect to the Treasurer's Budget announcement that significant changes would be made to the sales tax treatment of computer software. At present under the sales tax law, a computer program is subject to sales tax where it is embodied in a storage medium and is imported into, or sold in, Australia. Sales tax is payable whether the program was developed for a single user or for a number of users.

This Bill and the three other Bills that I will be introducing shortly will change the law in two main respects. Firstly, recognising that a large part of the price of customised software can be for software-related services and that identifying the service component of the price can be difficult, programs developed for a single user are, in certain circumstances, to be freed from tax. Secondly, to remove the distortions and avoidance opportunities created by applying sales tax only to computer programs delivered in goods, multiple user programs that are delivered electronically are to be brought into the sales tax base. Both these changes will come into effect from 3 November 1988.

To be exempt from sales tax, a single user program must only contain material developed by the programmer for the sole use of the single user as part of the program or, if it contains other material, that other material must not account for more than 20 per cent of the value of the program. Where the 20 per cent test is not met, sales tax will be payable on the value of the other material.

The Bill will also extend sales tax to computer programs transferred within Australia otherwise than when embodied in goods, that is, when transferred by electronic means. Transfers made free of charge, however, will not be affected. A further change to be made by the Bill will ensure that sales tax applies to parts of computer programs as well as to complete programs.

With the availability of the exemption for single user programs, it is inappropriate for registered taxpayers to continue to be able to quote their sales tax certificate number to buy, free of tax, those goods that are for use exclusively, or primarily and principally, as an aid to embodying tax-exempt single user programs in goods. Consequently, changes to the sales tax regulations to limit the `aids to manufacture' exemption will be submitted to the executive council as soon as practicable.

These changes will also apply to goods to be used exclusively, or primarily and principally, as an aid to transferring tax-exempt single user programs that are not embodied in goods. The changes will apply to goods bought as `aids to manufacture' after 3 November 1988. Some consequential changes to the sales tax regulations in relation to the quotation of sales tax certificates will be needed. Refunds will be made available to overcome any double taxation that may occur before the regulations can be amended.

Finally, the Bill contains two amendments to complement the extension of sales tax, by the Sales Tax Assessment Bill (No. 12) 1988, to computer programs transferred electronically into Australia from outside Australia. The first of these will ensure that any exemption from sales tax available for computer programs that are transferred electronically within Australia are also available for programs transferred electronically from outside Australia. The second will require the recipients of programs transferred from outside Australia to lodge sales tax returns. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SALES TAX ASSESSMENT BILL (No. 12) 1988
Mr President, this Bill complements one of the main measures in the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1988, about which I have just spoken.
By that Bill, computer programs transferred within Australia otherwise than when embodies in goods are to become subject to sales tax.

This Bill will ensure that sales tax is also payable on computer programs transferred, otherwise than when embodied in goods, from outside Australia to a person in Australia who is not registered for sales tax purposes. The buyer of such a program must lodge a sales tax return and pay the tax within 21 days after the end of the month in which the program was transferred.
The new assessment Act proposed by this Bill will contain machinery provisions for the collection and recovery of tax similar to those in existing sales tax assessment Acts.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SALES TAX BILL (No. 12) 1988
Mr President, it is a requirement of the Constitution that a law imposing taxation deal only with one subject of taxation.

In accordance with that requirement, this Bill will formally impose sales tax payable under the proposed Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 12) 1988 on computer programs that are transferred electronically from outside Australia to a person in Australia who is not registered for sales tax purposes.
The rates of sales tax are to be the same as those that currently apply to computer programs embodied in goods-generally, 20%.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SALES TAX BILL (No. 1a) 1988
I move that the Bill be now read a second time.
Mr President, as with Sales Tax Bill (No. 12) 1988, this Bill also is necessitated by the constitutional requirement that a law imposing taxation deal with one subject of taxation only.
The sales tax that will be payable under Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) 1930 on computer programs transferred electronically from within Australia will be formally imposed by this Bill.
The rates of sales tax declared by the Bill are the same as those for computer programs embodied in goods-generally, 20%.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986.
The establishment of the Federal Airports Corporation has been one of the major aviation initiatives of the Hawke Government.
The decision to establish the Corporation recognised a long overdue requirement to put the management of Australia's major airports on a proper commercial footing.
Accordingly, the Federal Airports Corporation Act has provided for the Corporation to have a clear commercial charter and the ability to respond to the infrastructure needs of the aviation industry.

On 1 January 1988 the Federal Airports Corporation assumed responsibility for the operation of seventeen major airports throughout Australia. These included the primary and secondary airports in each of the State capital cities as well as Coolangatta and Launceston airports.
The Government announced in the Budget that it had decided that the FAC should assume responsibility for a further group of airports.
The FAC is to take over the operation of the Alice Springs, Mount Isa and Mackay airports.
It will also assume responsibility for the civil aviation facilities at Darwin, Canberra and Townsville airports.

The Darwin, Canberra and Townsville airports are joint user airports which serve both defence and civil aviation purposes. The Federal Airports Corporation Act currently provides for the Corporation to operate airports which are declared as Federal airports for purposes of the legislation. The Act does not specifically provide for the Corporation to enter into arrangements for the shared operation of joint user airports.
Moreover, the Act requires that Federal airports be on land which is owned by the Corporation.

The Bill before the House provides for the amendment of the Federal Airports Corporation Act in order to provide a framework within which the Government can determine arrangements for the operation, by the Corporation and the Department of Defence of the Darwin, Canberra and Townsville airports.
The Bill also provides a basis on which any future transfers to the Corporation of civil facilities on joint-user aerodromes may be undertaken.

The Corporation will be able to enter into arrangements with the Commonwealth under which the Corporation would participate in the operation of jointly used areas and would be able to levy charges where it has financial involvement in these areas. This provision would have application in circumstances where the primary responsibility for areas such as runways and taxiways is not vested in the Corporation.

The Bill provides for the Minister to determine that ownership of the land on which a Federal airport is located need not be transferred to the Corporation. The Corporation could instead lease the area from the Commonwealth or enter into other arrangements for it to control that area.

The Government considers that the arrangements for the operation of joint user aerodromes for which this Bill provides will enable both the commercial operation of designated areas by the Corporation as well as providing the necessary safeguards to ensure that the integrity of defence operations is maintained.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988
This Bill is an omnibus Bill proposing miscellaneous amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901.
The main proposals contained in the Bill are to:
(i) amend the manner in which the quantity of beer produced is measured for the purposes of assessing both Customs and excise duty (clauses 10 and 33);

(ii) amend the controls pertaining to prohibited exports, so as to permit the Minister for Defence to suspend licences and permissions to export goods from Australia in circumstances where it is in Australia's national interest to suspend such licences or permissions (clause 8);
(iii) extend the duty-free entry to the Australian mainland of goods from Christmas Island to those goods which were 50% produced on the Island (clause 11);
(iv) amend offence provisions contained in section 228 and 234 of the Customs Act 1901 (clause 20 and 23); and

(v) provide, as part of the Government's decision to impose for the first time excise duties on Government instrumentalities, that existing legislative provisions protecting those instrumentalities from excise duty are of no effect (paragraph 29 (b) and clause 30).

In addition, the Bill makes a number of other minor, technical amendments to the Customs Act 1901, the Excise Act 1901 and the Off-Shore Installations (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1982. These amendments are set out in detail in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated.
I shall now outline the major proposals in the Bill.
Clauses 10 and 33 amend the manner in which beer is measured for the purposes of assessing duty.

The dutiable content of bulk vessels containing beer is presently fixed by legislation. For example, the traditional ``kilderkin'' is a vessel with a capacity of between 76.5 and 82 litres, although the dutiable content is set at 79 litres irrespective of the vessel's actual contents.
Technological improvements in the manner in which bulk vessels are manufactured and filled means that it is now possible to measure beer more accurately.

As from 1 February 1989, it is proposed to assess duty on bulk containers, that is, vessels in excess of 2 litres capacity, according to the quantity of beer nominated by the manufacturer as being in the bulk container, providing that the actual contents do not exceed 101.5% of the nominated quantity of the beer.
As from 1 July 1991, the 1.5% overfill tolerance just discussed will be reduced to 1%.

For beer in bottles and cans up to 2 litres capacity that are entered for home consumption as from 1 February 1989, duty will be based on the labelled contents of the container providing the actual contents do not exceed 101.5% of the labelled contents of the container.

I turn now to clause 8 of the Bill which allows for the Minister for Defence to suspend previously granted licences or permissions to export goods from Australia in circumstances where it is in Australia's national interest to do so.

The Government announced in June this year that the existing export controls on defence related goods would be revised so as to reduce constraints on exports where that could be done without prejudice to Australia's national interests and international obligations.

The existing controls require case-by-case ministerial permission for defence exports regardless of lethality or military significance. Case-by-case ministerial permission is also currently required for the export of non-military but potentially lethal goods like sporting firearms or commercial explosives.

The Government proposes introducing a system of licences for recognised exporters of potentially lethal, non-military goods. This system, whilst enabling the Government to stop exports of such goods in particular circumstances, will eliminate the current requirement for case-by-case approval of all such exports. When circumstances require, authorised exporters will be notified that export of these goods to particular destinations will require ministerial approval on a case-by-case basis. Case-by-case ministerial approval will still be required by non-authorised exporters of such goods.

Although the Government wishes to remove impediments to this trade, it recognises that from time to time circumstances may arise which make it contrary to Australia's national interest to continue exports to particular destinations. This proposed amendment to the Customs Act makes it clear that the Government may impose these controls should the circumstances arise.
Clause 11 provides for an extension of duty free entry to the Australian mainland of goods imported from the external territory of Christmas Island.

Currently, provision is made for the duty free entry into Australia of goods from the territory where those goods are the produce or manufacture of the territory, unless similar goods produced or manufactured in Australia are subject to excise duties. To meet the existing requirements of the Customs Act 1901 that deem goods to be the ``produce or manufacture'' of Christmas Island, those goods must either be wholly manufactured in the territory or partly manufactured, where the last process of their manufacture was performed on Christmas Island and not less than 75% of their factory or works cost is represented by the value of labour and/or material of Christmas Island or Australia.

However, as part of the Government's strategy to foster the development of new manufacturing industries on Christmas Island, in the face of an uncertain future for the phosphate mining industry, it is proposed from 1 January 1989 to reduce the local Australian content requirement under the Customs Act from 75% to 50%. This is the same preferential treatment currently applying to forum island countries and Papua New Guinea.

It is hoped that this measure will encourage small industries that will generate local employment and income. The Government considers this measure to be highly desirable in view of the small size of the population, its remoteness from the Australian mainland and its historical dependence on one industry, namely phosphate mining. This measure is consistent with the Government's policy on Christmas Island, namely, to widen and diversify the Island's economic base and improve its financial and management arrangements.
Clause 20 amends the offence contained in section 228 of the Customs Act 1901.

This section currently provides for the forfeiture to the Crown of ships or boats not exceeding 250 tonnes registered tonnage where that ship or boat has been used in smuggling, or knowingly used in unlawful importations or exportations, or is found to be altered so as to allow for the concealment of goods; or where the master of the ship has refused permission for customs to search the ship, or cannot account for cargo deficiencies.

The Government has decided that references to ``registered tonnage'' should be replaced with references to the ``overall length'' of a ship, because the maritime term ``registered tonnage'' is ambiguous, having a number of possible meanings. It is now proposed to move to a basis of the ``overall length'' of the vessel by adopting the definition of the term contained in section 10 of the Shipping Registration Act 1981.

The length of 80 metres has been chosen as the appropriate qualifying measure as it is considered that the master of a ship or boat should be able to exercise sufficient control over a ship or boat not exceeding 80 metres in overall length to warrant forfeiture if one of the circumstances set out in section 228 is established.

The owners of ships over 250 tons registered tonnage which have been engaged in the practices described above are currently subject to a penalty not exceeding $10,000. This penalty has remained the same for many years, and it is light compared with the replacement cost to an owner of a vessel under 80 metres overall length which is forfeited to the Crown. The Bill will increase the penalty for vessels over 80 metres overall length, and engaged in the activities I have mentioned, to $100,000.

Finally, clauses 29 and 30 of the Bill particularly implement a government decision to impose excise liability on government business enterprises (GBE'S), by removing any statutory exemptions from paying excise duty as from 1 July 1989. This complements amendments to the excise tariff proposed in the Excise Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988, recently introduced into the Parliament, which contains the substantive provision giving effect to this decision.

Most Commonwealth enterprises, particularly those in direct competition with the private sector, are subject to the full range of Commonwealth, State and local government taxes and charges. Consistent with the move to place Commonwealth business enterprises on a more commercial footing, the Government has decided that all GBES should be exposed to the same charges as private businesses.

Accordingly, as was announced in the Treasurer's May 25 1988 economic statement, excise duty will be payable by all GBES, the only exemptions being those authorities that have express exemptions to pay excise duty inserted in their establishing legislation as from 1 July 1989.
Financial Impact Statement

The change in the manner in which beer is measured for the purposes of assessing duty is not intended to net the Government any more revenue. If necessary, duty rates on beer may be adjusted for an overall, industry-wide revenue neutral result.

The revenue impact of extending duty free concessions to Christmas Island is difficult to assess, as much depends on the level of exports coming from the Island. However, it is anticipated that the extension of the concession will only lead to a minimal loss of government revenues.
The remaining amendments to the Acts have no direct financial impact.
I commend the Bill to the Senate, and present the accompanying explanatory memorandum.
CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1988

Mr President, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988, which is now before the Senate, contains in its seven schedules a wide variety of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. I will now briefly outline those amendments.

Schedule one to the Bill, operative on and from 1 January 1988, contains amendments necessary to enact tariff changes made by customs tariff proposals in August of this year. These amendments relate to:
walnuts;
large machines imported in separate component form; and
deerskin leather garments of New Zealand origin.
Also contained in this schedule are:

an amendment to restore the rate of duty applying to polyphenylene oxide. This overcomes an anomaly that has emerged following the introduction of the Government's decision on the chemicals and plastics industries; and

an amendment to additional note 1 to Chapter 72 to raise the minimum copper content specification of high alloy steel. This note was prepared some years ago and has been overtaken by changes in the steelmaking industry. The steel industry authority has confirmed that changes in technology have made the restrictions imposed by this note irrelevant to current assistance requirements.
Schedule two to the Bill, operative on and from 22 June 1988, restores a rate of duty of 15 per cent to certain paper cutting machines and parts thereof.

These amendments were previously included in the Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1988 retrospective to the 1 January 1988. The amendments legally establish the date of operation as 22 June 1988. Complementary amendments are also contained in schedule one to the Bill.
Schedule three to the Bill, operative on and from 1 July 1988, also contains a variety of amendments.
The first amendment is necessary to enact a tariff change made by Customs Tariff proposals in August of this year. The amendment relates to aviation turbine fuel.
Also included in this schedule are:

amendments, consequent on the May economic Statement, to provide for the phasing rates of duty and remove the revenue duty applying to certain tariff classifications. A complementary amendment has also been made to Part III of schedule 4 to the principal Act to remove redundant item 42c as a result of the removal of the revenue duty;

the imposition of protective rates of duty on certain raw and refined sugar, consequent on the removal of the import embargo on 1 July 1989, which will phase in accordance with the Government's decision announced in the May economic statement;
amendments to a number of items of schedule 4 to the principal Act, which:
rename the Australian industry participation Program to the Australian industry involvement program;
take account of the new Employment, Education and Training Act 1988; and
make it clear that item 22 covers goods for use in natural gas exploration as well as for petroleum exploration;
the remaining amendments of this schedule implement certain wording changes to align the principal Act with the international convention on the harmonized commodity description and coding system.
Schedules four and five, operative on and from 6 July 1988 and 24 August 1988 respectively, enact tariff changes made by tariff proposals in August of this year, relating to:
fibre glass insect screening; and
beer, which was part of the Government's budgetary measures.

Schedule six to the Bill, operative on and from 1 January 1989, includes amendments relating to the Government's decision on the chemicals and plastics industries. These exclude certain metallic stearates and vinyl wallpaper from duty phasing arrangements.
also included are other amendments which:
accelerate the phasing-out of New Zealand rates for passenger motor vehicles-complementary amendments have also been made in schedule three relating to components for passenger motor vehicles;

adjust certain forum islands and developing country rates to accord with the forum islands and revised developing country preference schemes introduced on 1 July 1986. These rates were not carried through to the harmonized tariff; and
remove redundant item 41d from Part III of schedule 4 to the Principal Act.

Schedule seven, operative on and from 1 March 1989, contains a series of amendments made in the context of the post-1988 assistance arrangements for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries (TCF).

The amendments include changes to TCF tariff and tariff quota arrangements. They reflect recent Government decisions on the TCF plan, the May economic statement changes to the plan, the outcome of a review by the TCF Development Authority on velvet duty rates, new ANZCERTA arrangements, and handicraft textiles and clothing and handmade footwear.

In June 1987 the Government announced the new assistance arrangements for the TCF industries post-1988 TCF plan. The plan commences, in the main, from 1 March 1989 and is aimed at encouraging the restructuring of these industries through a combination of gradual reductions in protection and the provision of special positive adjustment measures. The first of the tariff changes were introduced in legislation in 1987. The proposed legislative changes relate to tariff quota arrangements which will apply from March 1989.
The main changes to the post-1988 TCF plan announced in the May economic statement on the twenty-fifth day of May 1988 were:

a reduction in tariffs of five percentage points for apparel and footwear and for most higher tariff rates for fabrics and footwear parts. Because of this reduction a duty surcharge equal to five percentage points will also be introduced where quota is issued on a past import performance basis and base quota duty rates are being reduced. This surcharge will help maintain the relativities between the base quota and out-of-quota imports which existed prior to these decisions;
the end of the TCF plan on the thirtieth of June 1995, resulting in quota arrangements being abolished eight months earlier than originally announced.

As part of its decision on the TCF plan announced in June 1987, the Government decided that there would be a rationalisation and simplification of textile fabric duty rates. This decision included the duty on imported velvet fabrics being rationalised on the first of January 1988 to twenty-five per cent. A number of representations were received on this aspect of the decision. After analysis and investigation of the concerns by the TCF Development Authority, the Government decided to reduce the duty to twenty per cent in 1989 and fifteen per cent in 1990, and to determine future rates in the mid-term review of the plan.

Also included in this schedule are liberalisation arrangements to accelerate the achievement of full free trade in goods by 1 July 1990. These arrangements were recently decided upon by the Australian and New Zealand governments.
New entry arrangements for handicraft textiles and clothing and handmade footwear will also be introduced.

Finally, included are amendments to remove certain tariff classifications from the ambit of the TCF policy. This action now allows the duties applicable to these tariff classifications to be phased in accordance with the rates alterations reductions.
Financial Impact

The restoration of the ten per cent duty rate for polyphenylene oxide will result in a small decrease in revenue. However, this will be offset in part by the Government's decision to remove the phasing rates currently applying to certain metallic stearates.
The change in regard to the copper content of high alloy steel will result in a decrease in revenue not exceeding $1.4 million as a result of claims for refund of duties.

Revenue implications flowing from the tariff reductions announced in the Government's May economic statement are difficult to isolate accurately. However, it is anticipated that the reductions covered by this initiative, tariffs which are already phasing, the changes to the passenger motor vehicle plan and the abolition of the two per cent revenue duty will result in revenue decreases of $460m in 1988-89 increasing to $900m in 1992-93.
The TCF sector currently provides the Government with revenue from the duties levied on imports and from the partial sale by tender of tariff quota.
It is difficult to estimate with any certainty the future budgetary implications of changes in assistance for the TCF sector because of variables such as:

the phasing out of tariff quotas resulting in a decrease in revenue because of lower tariff rates. However, this will be offset by an increase in revenue resulting from an increase in the volume of imports;
liberalisation of trade with New Zealand;
replacing quota issued on a past import performance with quota sold by tender;
relative competitiveness of Australian production;
changes in consumer demand and consumer preferences; and
significance of developing countries as import sources.

Notwithstanding these complexities, it is expected that the total revenue collected from the implementation of the post-1988 TCF arrangements (including those arising out of the May economic statement and the closer economic relations changes) should increase by over $200 million over the period of the plan. The increase is likely to come largely from the sale of tariff quota by tender. There is expected to be minimal financial impact caused by the other amendments in the Bill.
Details of the amendments contained in this Bill have been included in an explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the information of honourable senators.
I commend the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Hill) adjourned.
