TALK.START.PARA: —I bring before the Senate a Bill to amend a number of areas affecting human services within the community services and health portfolio. This Bill seeks changes under the first home owners scheme to better ensure that assistance is properly targeted at those in need and is not used, for example, for investment purposes. It also tightens eligibility to Medicare entitlements to exclude a range of people such as visa overstayers, illegal immigrants and the like. This is in recognition that Medicare is primarily a health insurance system for Australian residents. As well, from 1 January 1989, Medicare benefits will not be available for overseas medical treatment. Unfortunately, many people have previously travelled overseas without comprehensive travel insurance on the incorrect assumption that Medicare would cover any hospital and medical costs they incurred. This change removes any such confusion. Instead the Government will concentrate on extending its network of reciprocal health care agreements.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will overcome a recent problem which has arisen in Victoria where some private health insurance funds have threatened to cease payment of hospital benefits for certain long stay nursing home-type patients. These patients have been paying contributions to their health funds for many years and have a right to expect that when they are admitted to hospital their health fund will contribute towards their hospital charges. This change reinforces the Government's belief that the funds have both a moral and a legal obligation to continue the long established practice of payment of benefits for nursing home-type patients.

The legislation also establishes the framework for the new Medicare hospital funding arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories. These arrangements not only guarantee eligibility of all Australians to free public hospital treatment, but also will help improve access and throughput for Medicare patients. In addition, the Bill honours Government commitments to provide for a limited number of exempt nursing home beds, and to increase availability and access to respite care services in nursing homes and hostels as part of its aged care reforms, and imposes lodgment and processing fees for appeals against nursing home fees determinations.

This Bill, firstly, seeks to amend the First Home Owners Act 1983. The proposed amendments to that Act authorise the recovery of assistance paid on the basis of an applicant's intention to reside in a dwelling, but where that intention was not realised. The amendments will provide that where a person has not resided in a dwelling and no longer intends to reside in that dwelling, the Secretary shall direct that the person be deemed not to be a prescribed person for the purposes of the Act. The amendments further provide that once such a direction is made, the assistance which has been paid becomes recoverable. The amendments will enhance the Secretary's ability to prevent assistance being paid in relation to homes which are not owner-occupied.

In addition, in cases where only one of two or more owners ever occupies the dwelling, the moneys paid under the first application may be recovered or offset against the remaining entitlement. This leaves the party who never occupied the dwelling free to reapply in relation to another dwelling. This aspect will be of assistance to couples who separate prior to one party occupying the dwelling. There are no financial implications arising from these amendments.

A further amendment involves the definition of an eligible person in relation to Medicare entitlements. For some time now the Government has been reviewing the key elements of Medicare eligibility. The major focus of the review centred upon the principal eligibility issue-that is, who should have access to the Australian health care system. Since its inception in February 1984, Medicare eligibility has been conferred on all Australian residents. An Australian resident is generally defined in the Health Insurance Act 1973 as a person who resides in Australia, including a person domiciled in Australia, but not including diplomatic-consular staff, or their families.

The effect of the existing definition is that in addition to conferring eligibility on bona fide Australian residents-that is, persons who have a legal entitlement to reside in Australia-it also unintentionally permits access to a range of categories of other people on whom Medicare eligibility should not be conferred; for example, visa overstayers, illegal immigrants and the like. The new definition limits Medicare access to persons who have a legal entitlement to remain in Australia permanently. The change of eligibility for Medicare benefits made by this amendment is consistent with the changes of the eligibility for social security benefits and veterans' entitlements that were made by the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Act 1987.

In addition to the principal definition, there remains in the Act a discretionary power available to the Minister for Community Services and Health to confer Medicare eligibility upon individuals or classes of persons in exceptional or unusual circumstances. Consistent with that discretionary power and with other measures being taken administratively, and the repeal of section 21 of the Act relating to the payment of benefits for overseas treatment, it is the Government's intention from the date of effect of this amendment that non-residents of Australia, whether they be Australian citizens residing abroad or long term visitors from overseas, shall henceforth be excluded from Medicare eligibility. Only people who actually reside in Australia legally should have access to Medicare. This proposed amendment is not expected to achieve immediate savings. Moderate savings in Medicare benefits are, however, expected in the future. The Bill also repeals section 21 of the Health Insurance Act 1973.

Since the inception of Medicare in 1984, Australian residents have been able to claim Medicare benefits in respect of the cost of medical services incurred overseas. Where there is an equivalent item in the Medicare benefits schedule, such medical services have attracted benefits at the Australian schedule fee rate. No financial assistance is available in respect of hospital costs incurred overseas. The average Medicare benefit paid in respect of medical services rendered overseas represents approximately 40 per cent of the actual cost of the service provided. Australian travellers are thus required to pay about 60 per cent of the cost of the medical services, and if hospitalised they are responsible for 100 per cent of these costs. In some countries, the Medicare benefit is only a small proportion of the costs.

The Government has decided to discontinue the payment of Medicare benefits for medical treatment received overseas, which in practice is often very little more than a token payment against very high costs, and to extend the network of reciprocal health care agreements (RHCA) with other countries. Such agreements provide Australian residents with access to both medical and hospital treatment on the same basis as residents of the host country. Reciprocal agreements are therefore a more appropriate and effective means of providing health care cover for Australian travellers abroad. Australia is currently party to agreements with the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Malta and Italy. Agreements with Sweden and Portugal are close to being finalised and I expect them to be operational in the near future. Negotiations are also under way with several other European countries.

Health costs overseas are often high, particularly in the United States of America, where hospital charges in excess of $2,000 a day are not unusual. Thus, a 10- to 15-day stay in hospital can result in a devastating outlay of $20,000 to $30,000 for the patient. It is the responsibility of the individual to purchase appropriate travel insurance cover, just as it is to make arrangements covering all other aspects of overseas travel. The former availability of Medicare benefits provided what was at times quite a false impression in the minds of travellers that they were adequately protected against such costs. Henceforth, from 1 January 1989, medical benefits will not be available for overseas medical treatment, and the Government will focus its efforts on further developing reciprocal arrangements with countries which have health systems which are compatible with, and comparable to, Medicare. This amendment is expected to save approximately $5m a year in Medicare benefits from 1 January 1989.

A further purpose of the Bill is to establish the framework for the new Medicare hospital funding arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories. Of course, the cornerstone of the Federal Government's contribution to the improvement of Australia's health care delivery system has been the introduction of Medicare, our universal health insurance scheme which is now nationally and internationally recognised for its social and economic successes. Not surprisingly, Medicare's social and economic advantages to Australia are reflected in the level of community support for the health insurance system.

One area in which substantial future enhancement is now being undertaken is the Medicare public hospital funding arrangements, under which the Commonwealth is entering into new five-year agreements with the States and Territories from 1988-89 to 1992-93. The proposed amendments to the heads of agreement under schedule 2 of the Health Insurance Act allow definition of the purpose for which funding is provided--

There is a statutory obligation on the Minister to consider these requests for review. However, to address the current extraordinary volume of appeals will involve the diversion of significant departmental resources from implementing other necessary Government reforms in aged care, some of which have been requested by industry associations, to handle many non-genuine appeals.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no way of distinguishing between protest or vexatious appeals and those which are genuine. It is in the interests of the taxpayer and nursing home proprietors with genuine grievances, to free up the nursing home fees review mechanisms by ensuring that only those cases which are genuine become the subject of review and that those appeals are expenditiously handled. There is a further need to prevent the situation from worsening by avoiding future protest or vexatious appeals against fee determinations. The Government considers the introduction of a lodgment fee of $500 and an additional processing fee of $500 for each half-day a committee meets to consider an appeal, will achieve those objectives. Administration of these arrangements-for which provision is made in clause 29-will be facilitated by fees being deducted from payments due to a nursing home under part 5a of the National Health Act on authorisation by the proprietor. To safeguard the position of genuine appellants both lodgment and processing fees will be refunded in full where a request for review is wholly or substantially successful. Provision is also made for the lodgment fee to be refunded in full to a proprietor who withdraws a request within 84 days following a decision by the Secretary.

As indicated previously, the Government is committed to the provision of respite care services as part of its strategy of responding positively to the needs of the aged and to the needs of the often forgotten husbands, wives, relatives and friends who care or assist in the caring for aged persons in their own homes. Respite care is essential to assist aged persons to live for as long as possible in the community. The Government's program of reform in aged care seeks to increase the availability and accessibility of respite care services in nursing homes and hostels. The long term objective is to provide two respite care places per thousand persons in both hostels and nursing homes with an additional 4,000 places available by 1995. Clause 42 of this Bill allows regulations, which are subject to disallowance by the Parliament, to be made which allow the formulation and implementation of a scheme for providing respite care in nursing homes. The scheme being developed, and which is to be defined in the regulations, is expected to be implemented in the second half of the 1988-89 financial year.

Honourable senators also will be aware that the Government has introduced a major reform program in aged residential care to overcome serious criticisms of the nursing home program which have been made by representatives of the industry, aged people, unions, Commonwealth parliamentary committees and other representative bodies. The reform program has been phased in to ensure that the process of adjustment is smooth and avoids disruption of the care of the 110,000 frail aged residents and the employment of the thousands of people providing that care.

The reforms to the nursing home funding arrangements introduced on 1 July 1987 and 1 July 1988 will result in non-government nursing homes for the aged being phased to a standard fee and standard benefit arrangement by July 1991. The standard fees and benefits will embody funding for uniform nursing and personal care staffing levels linked to service needs of residents and a standard aggregated module for infrastructure costs.

Currently, approximately 26 per cent of residents across Australia are required to contribute more than the minimum statutory contribution towards the fees set by the Commonwealth. The minimum statutory contribution is equivalent to 87.5 per cent of the sum of the maximum single rate pension and rental assistance. Under the arrangements introduced on 1 July 1988 these additional contributions will be gradually eliminated so that by July 1991 no resident will be required to contribute more than the minimum statutory contribution.

Previously, in introducing the amendments to the National Health Act to enable the implementation of the reforms to the nursing home funding arrangements from 1 July 1988, including the phasing out of the excess amounts over the minimum statutory contribution, the Government advised that the only exception would be in relation to residents of exempt homes. It was also foreshadowed that, in these sittings, legislation would be introduced to enable the exempt nursing homes arrangement to be implemented.

The Bill also amends the National Health Act 1953 to enable the introduction of an exempt nursing homes arrangement, under which a number of non-government nursing homes for the aged will be permitted to charge their residents fees which are higher than the maximum that would otherwise apply. The amount of Commonwealth daily benefit payable under this arrangement will be reduced by a minimum of 50c in the dollar for each dollar by which the fee charged exceeds the fee otherwise payable. The exempt nursing homes arrangement will provide scope for a small proportion of residents, who so desire, voluntarily to buy a higher level of accommodation and services than that provided by non-exempt homes. It is proposed that only a small proportion of nursing homes in each State-comprising initially up to 6 per cent of beds-be granted exempt status.

Clause 24 of the Bill inserts a new provision in the National Health Act empowering the Minister to grant exempt status to a nursing home for a specific period following consideration of a proprietor's application for such status.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill 1988 gives effect to the Government's decision to sell the assets of the Defence Service Homes Corporation to Westpac Banking Corporation and to put in place arrangements for the delivery of Commonwealth-subsidised housing loans by that bank. This major change in the way benefits under the Defence Service Homes Act 1918 are delivered is of the greatest importance to the Australian veteran community and to present and former members of the Defence Force. In this context, representatives of the veteran and service communities have been involved over the last two years in looking at ways of improving both the benefits available under the defence service homes scheme and their delivery to the client group. There has been close consultation with these groups during development of the revised arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: The arrangements with Westpac involve the sale of the interest of the Defence Service Homes Corporation in its portfolio of about 134,000 mortgaged and terms contracts for an amount equal to the face value of those assets. At 31 October 1988 the face value was approximately $1.39 billion including accrued interest. In addition, Westpac will pay a premium of $100m to participate in the defence service homes scheme. Under the new arrangements, Westpac will take over responsibility for all future lending under the scheme; this will include delivery of certain ancillary benefits such as instalment relief and special loans for windows in hardship.

For several years the Government has been unable for budgetary reasons to make necessary changes to the defence service homes scheme including: removal of the 10-month waiting period for loans to buy homes, now costing borrowers several thousand dollars in bridging finance interest charges; and an increase in the maximum first mortgage loan from the present level of $25,000, set in 1980, to a more reasonable proportion of the cost of acquiring a home.

There will be no waiting period for Westpac loans which will be repayable over a period of up to 25 years and will be portable from one home to another. Home buyers will be able to borrow in excess of $25,000 as a first mortgage with the Commonwealth subsidising the repayments on the first $25,000 of any loan; borrowers will also save by not having to meet two sets of loan establishment charges or pay second mortgage interest rates on the amount borrowed in excess of $25,000.

The revised arrangements will remove the need for a statutory corporation and the Defence Service Homes Corporation will cease to exist once the handover to Westpac is complete. The future administration of the defence service homes scheme will be undertaken within my portfolio. It is estimated that under the revised arrangements there will be resource savings of up to 360 staff and $11.5m per year.

The revised defence service homes scheme will involve the assessment and determination of the entitlement of eligible persons for benefits under the scheme; and the payment of subsidy in relation to both the assets sold to Westpac and those new loans made by Westpac. The subsidy will be an amount paid to the bank, not the client, on a monthly basis, reflecting the difference between the interest paid by clients on their loans-6.85 per cent on new loans and various rates below that rate on mortgages sold to the bank-and an agreed rate of return to the bank. It is estimated that the subsidy cost in a full year will be $145m. The revised arrangements agreed with the bank do not involve any change to the status of people who are already eligible under the Defence Service Homes Act. Any of these people who have not previously sought assistance under the scheme will be able to apply for the new benefits. The Bill will give effect to the Government's decision that persons who enlisted in the Defence Force after 14 May 1985 will not become eligible for benefits under the scheme. The form of housing benefit to be provided for these persons is being considered.

The defence service homes insurance scheme is not included in the business sold to Westpac-this business will continue as a self-funded cooperative home insurance scheme, being operated by the Commonwealth and administered within my portfolio. Other benefits under the scheme will continue to apply and be delivered by the Commonwealth or the bank as set out in the agreement which is attached as schedule 1 to the Bill. When announcing the proposed changes to the scheme the Government promised that eligible persons and borrowers would not be disadvantaged under the new arrangements. The agreement with Westpac and this Bill provide for a considerable improvement in the range and quality of benefits available under the scheme. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

This Bill contains amendments to the Social Security Act 1947 and minor consequential amendments to other Acts. The amendments are to implement decisions announced in the 1988 May Statement and the 1988/89 Budget Speech, and to introduce certain other minor amendments.

The amendments to the Social Security Act include further, major steps in implementation of policy changes flowing from the Social Security Review established in 1985. These steps, relating to payments for children, sole parent programmes and the long term unemployed are further tangible evidence of the Government's commitment to a fairer distribution of income in Australia.

It was the Hawke Labor Government which placed the abolition of the need for child poverty on the political agenda of this country-no other political grouping was pressing it as a priority. This Government deliberately chose not simply to make the attack on child poverty a priority-we invited the Australian people to judge us on our performance in delivering on that priority.

This Bill contains a range of further measures in the progressive implementation of the centrepiece of our attack on child poverty-the Families Package. That Package draws on the work of the Social Security Review in its first issues paper: ``Assistance to Families with Children''.

Rates of Family Allowance Supplement and child payments to pensioners and beneficiaries will rise in December 1988. For each child younger than 13, families will receive $24 a week, an increase of $2. For each child aged 13 to 15, a payment of $31 a week will be made, up by $3. 600,000 families with 1,200,000 children will be better off as a result.

The Bill will implement the first steps to achieving an integrated child payment. Family Allowance, Child Disability Allowance, Double Orphan's Pension and Family Allowance Supplement (including Rent Assistance) are to be integrated to achieve the one fortnightly payment for children. Next year we will take the further step of integrating the additional benefit paid for children with this fortnightly payment.

The integration of Family Allowance, Child Disability Allowance, Double Orphan's Pension and Family Allowance Supplement (FAS) will avoid the possibility of FAS becoming a marginal welfare payment-as occurred with the old Family Income Supplement.
There will be the one payment, payable in respect of 80% of Australian children, the rate of which will vary depending on factors such as:
the number of children in the family;
the income of the parents;
the special difficulties faced by families caring for children with disabilities, or those whose natural parents are not able to care for them; and
the costs faced by families who have young children from a multiple birth.

The basis for income testing of FAS will be changed. Currently the income test, which operates on income received in the previous four weeks, encourages perceptions of the payment as a welfare measure. It is difficult to administer and creates anomalies for many low paid workers whose income fluctuates.

The Bill will implement an income test based on the taxable income of the claimant and her or his spouse. This change will substantially simplify understanding of the payment and enable simpler administration. The change highlights the importance of FAS in our tax transfer system-making FAS, in every sense, as good as a tax cut for low income families.

The move to taxable income as the basis of income testing from 29 December 1988 effectively indexes the income test threshold for FAS. Payments in 1989 will generally be based on taxable income for the year ending 30 June 1988.

As from 1 January 1990, the threshold for this income test is to be indexed in line with the CPI increase in the previous financial year. This will ensure that income increases that match price increases will not erode child payments or contribute to work disincentives and poverty traps. 179,000 families including 430,000 children will benefit from this constructive measure.
The Bill contains three measures to ensure that child payments are directed to those families in most need by improving targeting and reducing the scope for abuse of the system.

First, an assets test is to be introduced in establishing entitlement to Family Allowance Supplement. Like the income test, the assets test will take CPI increases into account. From the last payday in 1988 FAS will not be payable to a person when the value of the assets of the person and her or his spouse exceeds $300,000. Property excluded from the pensions assets test (such as the family home) will also be excluded from the FAS assets test.

Second, Family Allowance Supplement will not be payable in respect of any child who has unearned taxable income in excess of the tax free threshold which is currently $416 p.a. This will prevent parents from qualifying for FAS by divesting themselves of income in favour of their children and ensure proper targeting of the payment.

Third, payment of additional benefit and Mother's/Guardian's Allowance to an unemployment or sickness beneficiary who is contributing to the maintenance of a child who is not in his or her care will cease. It is both more efficient and more equitable that such payments be made directly to the custodian through the pensions, benefits or child allowance systems.

In its third issues paper. ``Bringing Up Children Alone'', the Social Security Review highlighted the difficulties faced by sole parent families-difficulties of unfair and inaccurate stigmatisation, of inadequate income and labour market barriers.

The Government has addressed these problems in a systematic way. We have introduced the Child Support Scheme and will proceed, next year, with Stage 2 of that scheme. The Families Package has delivered major increases in payments for sole parents.

In the Budget the Government announced the introduction of the JET scheme-Jobs, Education and Training for Sole Parents. JET will provide comprehensive advice, assistance, labour market training, education and child care. The JET scheme is designed on the basis that sole parents usually receive pensions for relatively short periods-until they find work or repartner. It will be targeted to those sole parents most at risk of long term dependence on pension or benefit; teenagers, those whose youngest child has just commenced school and those whose youngest child is 14 or over.

This Bill contains changes to complement the introduction of JET. The Supporting Parent's Benefit and Widow's Pension Class A will be replaced by a uniform Sole Parent's Pension. This change rids the social security system of categories of benefit based on moral judgments of the worth of individuals and provides a pension which acknowledges the present need for support of sole parents, regardless of the cause of the sole parenthood. The Sole Parent's Pension will be available to all those to whom Widow's Pension Class A or Supporting Parent's Benefit would have been available.

The new pension will also extend support to a small number of people who had previously been ineligible for benefit because of the requirement for them to have legal custody (such as some grandmothers). However, this extension will be limited to those who have cared for a particular child for twelve months or more-in order to ensure that the availability of Sole Parent's Pension does not distort established patterns of foster care or otherwise unduly encourage single people to take on the care of children for whom they have no formal responsibility.

In Issues paper No. 4, ``Income Support for the Unemployed in Australia-Towards a More Active System'', the Social Security Review dealt with the unemployed. Flowing from that paper, in the Budget the Government announced the implementation of New-Start, a comprehensive programe to assist unemployment beneficiaries who have been receiving benefit for 12 months or more.

New-Start will consist of a number of policy and legislative elements which together recognise the need to overcome the self-perpetuating situation of joblessness, poverty and dependence often encountered by people who remain out of work for long periods. Their job skills become eroded or irrelevant, employers are increasingly reluctant to take them on, their self-confidence and motivation evaporate and they become enmeshed in a cycle of financial hardship and dependence on social security payments.

New-Start introduces through this Bill an Employment Entry Payment of $100 which will be payable to people in this category when they return to full time employment. It is to help them meet the short term costs of moving into and retaining full time work, such as clothing and transport costs and union membership, and is payable only once within a 12 month period.

This group of people will also benefit from a waiver of the waiting period which currently applies should they need to claim unemployment benefit again within 3 months of the cancellation of their last benefit. This reduces the disincentive of moving from benefit to short term full time work or work of uncertain duration.

Unemployment beneficiaries will also be able to undertake a wider range of activities which promote employability while still retaining eligibility for benefit. By allowing them to participate up to certain limits and with CES approval in full time training courses or voluntary work, the barrier to people attempting to improve and maintain their job skills will be reduced.

New-Start is an imaginative strategy for improving the prospects for the long term unemployed to reintegrate into the workforce. It will deliver real opportunities to a group of people who have been excluded from the benefits of the massive job growth we have seen in Australia over the last five years.

Job Search Allowance is paid to unemployed young people aged 16 and 17 subject to an income test on both their own and their parents' income. This Bill increases the threshold for that parental income test by $950 to $16,950 a year and introduces indexation of the threshold in line with increases in average weekly earnings. This action prevents the undermining of the entitlement through routine income increases while still maintaining the intention of the income test. Children in authorised foster care will be exempted altogether from the application of the parental income test on Job Search Allowance entitlement.

The Young Homeless Allowance which is payable to young unemployed Job Search Allowance recipients is to be increased in this Bill by $27.85 a week so that the two allowances combined will be the same rate as that paid under AUSTUDY to 16 and 17 year old students who are independent and living away from home.
Certain student children who attract the payment of defined allowances will be deemed to be covered by the Family Allowance provisions in 1988 so as to retain Family Allowance Supplement entitlement.

This Bill introduces a measure to provide special support to newly released prisoners on their reintegration into society. To meet the special adjustment problems of newly released prisoners, especially urgent housing, food, clothing and transport costs and the like, a double payment of Benefit will be made in respect of their first week after claiming. Compassionate considerations aside, it is simply not in society's interest to have released prisoners reoffending because of lack of immediate support. In conjunction with this measure the Government is consulting the states to achieve effective co-ordination between prisons and the Department of Social Security to ensure released prisoners obtain the income support they need when they need it.

An important segment of the Bill in terms of the Government's high priority for protecting the rights of the individual in the social security process is the one dealing with the gathering and disclosure of information.

This segment introduces a clearer statement of how the Department of Social Security's information gathering and disclosing powers are to operate. The measure is in response to a perception by some in the community that the current powers can trespass upon the privacy of individuals, especially those who are no longer clients of the department. The powers to compulsorily obtain information will be limited by provisions of the Bill. These limitations will be additional to those already contained in the legislation. Further, the powers conferred by the Social Security Act in this respect will be exercised in accordance with the Principles of the Privacy Bill. Compliance by the department with the limitations inserted by this Bill and with Information Privacy Principles will be subject to audit by the Privacy Commissioner.

The circumstances in which the Secretary to the Department of Social Security may authorise the disclosure of information held by the Department to third parties on public interest grounds are to be clarified in guidelines to be issued by the Minister and tabled in both houses.

The Bill will end the sexist distinction currently embodied in the Class C category of Widow's Pension. That pension will be replaced in March 1989 with a Widowed Person's Allowance. This will remove anomalies in the coverage of income support to people without dependent children who have been recently widowed, including inconsistencies in the treatment of widowed males and females.
The remainder of the Bill deals with administrative reforms and minor amendments which will improve the quality and consistency of service provided to social security clients.

Directions to be issued by the Minister and tabled in Parliament will make clearer and more consistent the exercise of the power to waive or write off debts owed to the Commonwealth under the Social Security Act.

Debts owed to the Commonwealth under the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs' assurances of support scheme are to be brought into line in their handling with debts arising under the Social Security Act. This will be done by providing a mechanism to recover from an assurer who has, for whatever reason, failed to adequately support a migrant under the assurances of support provisions any Special Benefit paid to the migrant under the Social Security Act.
Overpayments of Formal Training Allowance will be made recoverable from continuing social security payments.

Refinements are to be made to the provisions governing the portability of Australian social security payments overseas. From May 1989, payment of Family Allowance will cease where the recipient has been overseas for 3 years or longer. From February 1989, pre-departure certificates will be required for all pensioners who leave Australia to enable continuation of payment of pension overseas after 6 months' absence. And recipients of the existing Supporting Parent's Benefit or Class A Widow's Pension, or the new Sole Parent's Pension (other than de jure widows), will have their overseas payments limited to 12 months from their departure from Australia if this was on or after 1 July 1988, or ceased on 1 July 1989 if they were already overseas as at 1 July 1988.

The Bill removes anomalies in the provisions covering the payment of entitlements to people who are treated as unmarried and paid at the single rate because they are separated while still living under one roof, or where Child Disability Allowance is paid to only one of the people in respect of a child formerly dependent upon them both.
The reciprocal social security agreement with Canada will come into effect and be incorporated as a schedule in the Social Security Act.
Certain New Zealand and United Kingdom payments, which are similar in nature to Australian payments that are exempt from the definition of ``income'', will also be treated as exempt income.

Fortnightly reporting requirements for benefit will be relaxed for people living in remote communities, and married people separated owing to ill health will be entitled to twice the unmarried rate of Remote Area Allowance where one spouse is dependent on the other.
Members of the Defence Force Reserve will be exempted from the application of the work test on Unemployment Benefit while attending annual camp.

A beneficiary who has not yet completed the 26 week waiting period for Rent Assistance and who has a short break in entitlement due to short term employment will not have to serve another full waiting period for Rent Assistance.
In presenting this Bill I record the Government's appreciation to Professor Cass and those who have worked with her on the Social Security Review.

The process of reform in social security is by no means complete. The Social Security Review has recently released a paper on disability issues which will form the basis of policy development for assistance to people with disabilities. Consultation on disability issues is indicating a fundamental shift in attitude about the range of activities that should be available for people with disabilities so they too can have a greater choice in their lives including greater access to employment and training opportunities.

Soon to be released is a paper titled `Towards a National Retirement Incomes Policy' which will assess the overall adequacy, equity and incentive effects of the current system of retirement incomes. This paper will propose longer-term directions for reform and is due for release within a few weeks.

As a result of the work of the Review, we can look forward to developing more flexible approaches to retirement, including opportunities for part-time work in addition to retirement income and long-term care and social support systems for the elderly which encourage them to remain within the community.

The culmination of the immensely valuable work of the Social Security Review will be the Final Report due for release early next year. Professor Cass's final report will address future directions in social security policy including how to simplify the system as well as options for a payment structure which is more tailored to the specific needs of disadvantaged people according to their stage in the life cycle and their capacity to participate in economic activity.

Further reform in the social security area will be dominated by the need to achieve a more active labour market orientation of income support programs, not just for those who we may expect to be in employment but also for sole parents, for some older people and people with disabilities. Taken together, these measures will provide a significant impetus ensuring that all Australians have an opportunity to participate in this country's economic and social life.

The major achievement of this Government in the social security area has been to align social policy objectives more closely with economic policy objectives, to support the broader process of structural change, and to ensure that Australians have adequate opportunities to participate in economic and social activities by equipping them with the necessary skills and training and by providing opportunities to all Australians to participate in economic recovery.
This Bill is a significant step in that process.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

This Bill contains amendments to the Social Security Act 1947 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to implement several decisions announced in the 1988-89 Budget Speech, to make minor amendments to the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act and to revise the social security reciprocal agreement with New Zealand.
This Bill contains the most fundamental restructuring of the system of rent assistance since its introduction for pensioners.
For the first time the rent assistance system will acknowledge the additional housing costs of families with children.
For the first time that system will acknowledge the additional costs of larger families-families with three or more children.
There will be parity in levels of rent assistance for pensioners and beneficiaries.

Among low income individuals and families, those who rent in the private market are the least well off. As part of a far-reaching housing assistance package and in special recognition of the plight of families in the private rental market, the maximum rate of rent assistance for people with dependent children is to be increased by a special $5 child add-on. This increase will apply from June 1989 to families who qualify for family allowance supplement or additional pension or benefit payments for their children.

Further rent assistance increases will be introduced in December 1989 and June 1990. In December 1989, beneficiaries without children will receive a $5 increase to bring their entitlement to the same $15 a week level that is payable to pensioners without children-providing parity of treatment for pensioners and beneficiaries.

Then, in June 1990, the maximum basic rate of rent assistance payable to all recipients will rise by $5 a week and the child add-on component will be raised to $10 a week where there are three or more dependent children. People without children will then receive a total of $20 a week, those with one or two children will receive $25 a week and families with three or more children will be paid $30 a week.

The rent assistance threshold will also rise in June 1989 from $15 to $20 a week. This threshold is the minimum amount of rent a person must pay before becoming eligible for rent assistance. The increase means that more assistance can be given to people in greatest need paying higher rents.

From June 1989, rent assistance eligibility is to be modified to remove an anomaly whereby the payment is currently available to pensioners and beneficiaries in respect of the rented premises that they occupy, although they may also own a home which they do not occupy. Certain homeowner groups will remain eligible-people who move into nursing homes or other approved institutions, those who sell their homes and are likely to use the proceeds for re-purchase within 12 months and those who pay for the use of a site or mooring of a mobile home or vessel.

The eligibility of people who acquire a right or interest in a principal home in a retirement village from today may also be affected by this rent assistance modification, depending on how much they pay for their right or interest. They will be ineligible for rent assistance if they pay an entry contribution of more than the difference between the assets test limits for property owners and non-property owners. This is an indexed amount currently standing at $64,000. An acquisition of this type and amount gives a person security of tenure broadly comparable to that of someone living in his or her own home. People paying $64,000 or less will still be eligible for rent assistance. This change removes the incentive for village promotors to deny security of tenure to residents even though they have made substantial investments.

From June 1989, pensioners and beneficiaries who apply for rent assistance in respect of their board and lodging accommodation will have their assessable rent calculated on the basis of two-thirds of their board and lodging costs rather than the full amount. Existing board and lodging rent assistance recipients will be phased into the new arrangements-they will continue to receive the same amount of rent assistance they would have received before June 1989 had the new $20 threshold applied, until they either stop boarding and lodging or become eligible for payment at a higher rate under the new conditions.
These wide ranging amendments will enable a redistribution of rent assistance support to the areas of greatest need.

To complete the housing measures and in recognition of their special circumstances, ex-prisoner rent assistance claimants who have no children will have the 26 week waiting period during which they would normally have had to be receiving unemployment benefit reduced by the length of time they have spent in prison.

A cornerstone of this country's social security system is a fair means test. An essential element of a means tested system is an income test with integrity. An environment in which some in the investment industry have developed and marketed products for the purpose of enabling avoidance of the income test requires constant monitoring.

This Government has given a clear undertaking that it would act to counter devices or schemes designed to circumvent the income test for pension and benefit eligibility. This Bill closes a significant loophole in the income assessment of certain investment products in the interests of a fair and equitable income test which does not favour one group of investors over another.
Growth on market-linked investments, which is currently assessed on realisation or maturity will now be assessed on an ongoing basis.

From 1 December 1988, pensioners and beneficiaries who, on or after 9 September 1988, invested or invest in institutionally managed market-linked investments which yield capital growth will have a rate of return calculated on their investments and counted as ongoing yearly income.

There will be a statutory rate of return on all market-linked investments of 11% or such other lower rate not below zero % as is specified by the Minister from time to time. Any such specified rate lower than 11% is to be subject to disallowance by Parliament.

In fairness to investors, the costs necessarily incurred by an investor in establishing and maintaining an investment will be taken into account-by deducting them from the amount determined by applying the rate of return to the amount of the investment.

This change from a realisation basis to an accruals basis for the income test removes a significant disincentive for retired people to access their savings, helping to achieve a more rational retirement incomes system.

Applying the flat, deemed rate of return is the only point at which the investment is subject to the income test-investors can be confident that the realisation of their investments will be irrelevant to the operation of the income test: there is to be no double counting of the return on an investment.

The fact that the system is based on a flat, deemed rate of income provides a strong incentive for fund managers to improve their products' rate of return to attract investors in this category-any improved return over the specified rate will not affect the pension or benefit.

The Secretary of the Department of Social Security will be able to decrease the deemed rate of return in respect of particular products either on his own volition or following a written application by the fund manager or a natural person who is an investor in the fund. If satisfied that the rate of return on the particular product is at a lower level than the specified rate, and if that lower level is clearly assessable, the Secretary will determine a new product rate of return for that product. The Secretary will not then, however, be obliged to determine a further variation within a period of 3 months.

The fund manager of a particular fund or a pensioner or beneficiary who has invested in a particular fund will have a right of appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal against the product rate of return deemed appropriate by the Secretary in respect of that product.

The Government recognises the need for certainty in the provisions determining eligibility for pensions and benefits. It also recognises that any system which has gaps in eligibility criteria enabling people to make investments the returns from which avoid the income test before they are cashed in or mature is unfair and, in the longer run, economically irresponsible.

The procedures and rules to apply under this Bill have taken account of consultations with pensioner bodies and investment fund associations. The Government will keep in close contact with these groups once the new provisions are in operation.

The procedures and rules should lead to a situation where pensioners, potential pensioners, fund managers and investment advisers will see clearly what the applicable rate of return is for each investment product. Variations in the rate will depend on the performance of the particular product.

The Bill will make some amendments to the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. These amendments are necessary to correct minor errors which occurred in the drafting of the Act earlier this year and to ensure that the Act, when it comes fully into operation on 1 December, correctly reflects the intentions of Parliament.

This Bill also revises the reciprocal social security agreement with New Zealand. Since 1973, Australia has paid its pensions into New Zealand under domestic law. However, as New Zealand does not pay its benefits into Australia, a financial imbalance developed in the agreement. This imbalance has been exacerbated by recent large increases in the number of people moving from New Zealand to Australia.

Following negotiations earlier this year, the New Zealand Government agreed to reimburse Australia for pensions paid to former New Zealand beneficiaries. It will reimburse the cost of all Australian age, invalid, wife's and widow's pensions paid to people in Australia who leave New Zealand on or after 1 April 1989 and who were in receipt of New Zealand national superannuation, invalid's or widow's benefits when they left New Zealand.

The reimbursement payment will be made annually in advance between 1 April and 30 June and is estimated at around $A8.8m cumulative per annum. This amount, less a small administrative expense, will represent a direct reduction in future Australian social security expenditure.
I commend this Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

OZONE PROTECTION BILL 1988

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the provisions of the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer: Australia can then ratify the Protocol. Also, the legislation will put in place measures whereby the emissions to air of substances that deplete the shield of ozone gas in the upper atmosphere will be substantially reduced beyond the minimum requirements of the Protocol, thereby safeguarding to the maximum practicable extent human health and the environment.

Protection of the ozone layer is one of the Government's highest environmental priorities. While the Montreal Protocol requires a fifty per cent reduction in the use of ozone depleting substances over ten years, the proposals contained in the Bill should enable Australia to achieve those reductions in half that time.

Senators are undoubtedly aware that small amounts of ozone gas in the upper atmosphere shield living things on earth from the harmful ultraviolet radiation present in sunlight. Emissions to air of some synthetic chemicals-certain chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and halons are the main ones-can break down this ozone shield, with serious implications for human health and the environment. CFCs are also powerful greenhouse gases and would be worthy of control on this account even if there were no concern about ultraviolet radiation.

Emissions of CFCs arise from their use in about 20 per cent of aerosol sprays, in refrigeration and air conditioning, in some plastic foams, in some dry cleaning machinery and as degreasing solvents in the electronics and other industries. Halons are used in specialised fire protection. Most industries, notably aerosol filling and foam packaging, are already converting to ozone-safe alternatives.

The main body of scientific advice shows that there has been a global decrease in stratospheric ozone of between two and three per cent over the last nine years, approximately half of which is not attributable to natural causes.

The seasonal decrease in stratospheric ozone over Antarctica is now well known. In 1987 the `ozone hole' was the worst ever-with around a 50 per cent reduction from normal levels of ozone. Although this year's rate of depletion is not nearly so strong, there is, nonetheless strong evidence that links the presence of CFCs to this phenomenon. The unique meteorology during winter and spring over Antarctica sets up an isolated air mass, the polar vortex, which is accompanied by very low temperatures. The low temperatures lead to the formation of stratospheric clouds which appear to greatly increase the potency of CFCs to destroy ozone.

Protection of the ozone layer is an environmental issue of world importance which requires urgent action. The implications for Australia arising from ozone depletion are especially important in terms of a possible increase in the already high incidence of skin cancers, possible damage to primary industries, and our interest in preservation of the Antarctic environment.

In 1987 Australia became a party to the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer. In June 1988 Australia signed the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer. The Protocol which is due to take effect from 1 January 1989 establishes a requirement to limit the domestic supply of the specified CFCs according to a tightening program which will freeze supply at the 1986 level, with effect from mid-1989; reduce supply by 20 per cent from 1993; and reduce supply by a further 30 per cent from 1998. The Protocol also requires that the supply of halon gases be frozen at the 1986 level, with effect from 1990. (The commencement date for the first control action for both the CFCs and halons will be delayed if the Protocol does not enter into force on 1 January 1989.)

The Protocol also provides for periodic reviews of its control requirements based upon scientific, technical and economic considerations. The first review is to be completed by 1990. Recognising that the latest scientific findings indicate that chlorofluorocarbons are responsible for the Antarctic ozone hole and are also implicated in the small global losses already identified, it is likely that the Protocol will be significantly strengthened after the review is complete.

The provisions of the Bill have been the subject of extensive liaison between Government and industries which manufacture, import and use CFCs and halons. For example, in May this year Senator Richardson met with industry representatives. As a result of that meeting, a series of action plans were produced and the Bill's provisions reflect the recommendations of those plans. Liaison has also been maintained through an interdepartmental working group on ozone and with the industry group, the Association of Fluorocarbon Consumers and Manufacturers. State governments and consumer and conservation groups have also been consulted. I am advised that industry supports the proposals in the Bill.
The Bill provides for:
a system of licences and tradable quotas for the production, import and export of scheduled substances, and
controls on the applications of scheduled substances so as to limit, so far as is practicable, the emissions of these substances to the air.

The licence and quota provisions relate to Australia's obligations under the Protocol. Licences will be granted to persons who produced, imported or exported scheduled substances during the year 1986. Quota will be granted to the same persons according to their market share in 1986. Once they have their quota, they will be free to buy and sell their share of quota on the open market. Total quota on issue will be adjusted according to the provisions of the Protocol.
The second category of restrictions gives effect to the Government's determination to take all reasonable steps to exceed the minimum requirements laid down in the Protocol.
These controls on applications include:

prohibition from 31 December 1989 of the manufacture or import of aerosol sprays containing scheduled substances, except for some limited essential uses where there is no practicable alternative; for example
a limited range of medical, veterinary, defence, industrial safety or public safety purposes
applications where CFC-powered aerosols are the only practicable way to meet legal requirements
the calibration of warning, measuring or scientific equipment
(It is the Government's intention that an expert committee will be set up and consulted when considering applications for exemptions under this provision)
prohibition from 31 January 1989 of the manufacture or import of `do it yourself' kits for recharging automotive air conditioning systems
prohibition from 1 July 1989 of the manufacture or import of disposable containers, 5 kgs or less, of scheduled substances for recharging air conditioning and refrigeration systems
prohibition from 31 December 1989 of the manufacture or import of extruded polystyrene packaging produced with or containing a scheduled substance
prohibition from 31 December 1989 of the manufacture or import of extruded polystyrene insulation produced with or containing a scheduled substance
prohibition from the date of effect of this proposed Act the manufacture or import of dry cleaning equipment which uses a scheduled substance.

But these controls are only the beginning. It is the Government's firm intention to continue with the joint industry/government working group so as to develop practical measures to reduce further Australia's consumption of scheduled substances. Additionally, a representative of the environment movement will be appointed to the working group to ensure that environment interests are kept abreast of developments and to ensure their views are taken into account in future action plans to limit further applications of these substances.

The Protocol generally has no controls on exports and in fact allows production to be increased by up to 15 per cent under certain circumstances. However, the Government proposes that exports first be frozen and then gradually reduced by 5 per cent a year. If this was not done, industry could simply convert production for domestic consumption into exports.

The Bill has no continuing financial implications as fees will be levied on each kilogram of scheduled substance manufactured or imported to recoup the costs of administering the legislation. Until the scheme is operational three positions have been funded at a cost of $185,000 for the first year within the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories.
Mr President, Australia has always been at the forefront of international action on this issue and I believe this Bill continues to show the way to the rest of the world.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
OZONE PROTECTION (LICENCE FEES-IMPORTS) BILL 1988
The purpose of this Bill, when taken with the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Manufacture) Bill, is to recover to the Government the costs of administering the Ozone Protection Bill 1988.
The fees are to be payable quarterly and will be based on the amount of scheduled substance, weighted for its ozone depleting potential, that is produced in a quarter.

It is proposed that the Regulations will set out a scale of the fees such that between the two licence fees Bills the estimated cost of administration of $185,000 per year in present terms will be recovered in the course of a year.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

—This afternoon we are discussing a very important subject which, clearly, the Opposition does not want to have discussed. The acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) may yet become the Black Death of the twentieth century. The actual and potential seriousness of this disease is still not fully realised, either by the public or by most politicians. The consequences for the whole community of its almost inexorable progression through the homosexual community, to intravenous drug users, to heterosexuals, to women and, finally, to children is far from being fully appreciated. Yet if we fail to understand and respond appropriately to this rapid increase in numbers and to the sequence of infection, which I have just outlined, it seems likely that few will be immune from infection in just a few short years. The human immune deficiency virus is one which has emerged very recently as a human pathogen. Since its first detection the number of infected people has increased rapidly.

SPEECH.PARA: The acquired immune deficiency syndrome was first reported in the United States in 1981. One case only was reported in Australia in 1982. That person is now dead. Six were reported in 1983, all now dead; 42 in 1984, 41 of whom are now dead; 113 in 1985, 96 now dead; 224 in 1986, 174 now dead; 345 in 1987, 160 already dead. In short, the number of AIDS cases has been doubling every six months since 1982. At that rate, another 15 doublings would have the whole Australian population afflicted and that would take just 7 1/2 years. I say `afflicted' because the number of human immunodeficiency (HI)virus infected is perhaps 20 to 30 times the number showing symptoms of AIDS. Thus the number of HI positive people in Australia probably already lies between 10,000 and 40,000.

It is suggested that all those who are HIV positive will sooner or later develop AIDS. Of those 1,023 who have developed AIDS in Australia, 511 have already died. Ninety per cent of those diagnosed in 1985 and 98 per cent of those diagnosed in 1984 are now dead. So far in Australia most of the cases and most of the transmission has been in homosexual men. This is merely the first phase. The HI virus is spread very effectively through shared unsterilised needles. The virus has no natural predilection for men. Through intravenous (IV) drug use it is being spread to the female and the heterosexual male population. Infection of intravenous drug users is the second phase now developing. This phase provides the link to the heterosexual community to women and thence to the newborn. It is this intravenous drug link which must be broken. New York provides a picture of what will occur here if we do not act now. Of New York's 200,000 intravenous drug users it is estimated that 60 per cent carry the AIDS virus. In Australia the figure is still probably about 4 per cent but rising rapidly.

It is necessary to say something about the human immunodeficiency virus. It is an RNA virus. Most cells are DNA as their genetic library. DNA is reproduced with a high degree of sequence integrity and the translation of DNA into RNA for purposes of cell metabolism is also a process of highly faithful translation. Mutations in DNA leading to new genetic strains are not common. The same is not true of RNA viruses. These viruses must back translate their RNA into DNA using a reverse transcriptase enzyme. That is why they are called retroviruses. This process of reverse transcriptions is highly error prone, leading to rapid mutation rates and large numbers of genetic variants. Indeed, the gene coding for the reverse transcriptase enzyme is also subject to mutation, further increasing the mutation rates. This has several very important consequences. The possibility of making an effective vaccine is remote. Indeed, in a single patient several quite distinct zero types have already been identified, indicating the rapid changeability of the virus. Moreover, it is not inconceivable that a genetic variant could arise which was transmitted much more readily by non-sexual means or without the need to share needles. Without doubt the virus poses an extremely serious threat. It is spreading rapidly and for that reason a rapid and effective response is essential.

This motion calls on the Federal Government to provide intravenous drug users with their drugs of addiction in ways that do not involve the sharing of needles and the consequent risk of the spread of the AIDS virus. As I shall argue later, this would have a number of other benefits, both for the drug users and for the community as a whole. We must think about drug use and especially drug addiction as a public health problem. We must think of addicts as people needing help, not as criminals to be punished, and of a society in which more people turn to drugs as a sick society needing treatment, not one merely needing more gaols and stricter penalties for the victims of its social and economic ills.

We must conceptualise drug addiction-AIDS as a medical problem, not as a criminal one. A survey conducted early this year showed that 5 per cent of adult Australians or 80,000 people had injected drugs at some stage in their lives and that 2 per cent or 30,000 had done so within the last 12 months. Thus, intravenous drug use ranges from the once only experiment to the occasional user, through to those who may inject themselves up to eight times per day. Thus, we are not talking just about drug addicts. The majority of drug users are occasional users. While drugs remain illegal, these occasional users are most likely to obtain their drugs through sharing with those who are more regular users. It is estimated that some 3 per cent to 5 per cent of gay and bisexual men are intravenous drug users. Sharing needles is a much more effective way of transmitting the HI virus than either homosexual or heterosexual intercourse. There are a number of causes of death among intravenous drug users. The most common by far will soon be AIDS.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, would you instruct the honourable senator not to read his speech, in defiance of Standing Orders? If he knew anything about this subject, he would not have to read his speech.

—If this is a point of order, I will pay attention. Senator Coulter is providing some technical material and he may need to refer to papers, but I would ask him to address the Senate. I believe he is doing so.

—There are a number of figures which, I must say, I cannot give off the top of my head, so it is necessary for me to refer to those figures. Only about 2 per cent of intravenous drug users died each year from their drug use pre-AIDS. In New York 20 per cent to 30 per cent of intravenous drug users will develop AIDS within five years and will then live for less than one year. The greatest risk to the intravenous drug user is not the drug but the risk of getting AIDS. The greatest health risk posed to the community by the intravenous drug user is the risk of spreading AIDS.

SPEECH.PARA: AIDS also places on the community a large and growing financial burden. There is no cure. Nursing care and hospitalisation are expensive. The only treatments are palliative, not curative. AZT presently costs $10,000 per year per patient, and when the other treatment costs are added it appears that the 1988 costs of treating and caring for the present 500 or so living AIDS victims in Australia, plus the associated AIDS dedicated expenditure by the Commonwealth, are approaching $50m. If no effective action is taken now, this figure is likely to be about $1 billion in five years' time. If this money is not found the quality of care will deteriorate and our efforts to control the further spread of AIDS will falter. By then it will be too late.

We now have a short period in which we can make, on this disease, a very significant impact. On a per capita basis Australia has the fourth highest incidence of AIDS in the Western world. We are perhaps only 18 months behind the United States in its spread and only a few years behind some African communities, where already 50 per cent of all pregnant women have AIDS. The policy discussion paper: `AIDS: A Time To Care, A Time To Act', released only a few days ago, lists three objectives of a national AIDS prevention strategy, the first and most important of which is to minimise transmission of the human immunodeficiency virus.

The urgency motion this afternoon proposes that injectable drugs be supplied to intravenous drug users through facilities which may be either stationary or mobile and clean, non-threatening, friendly, and non-judgmental. This extends the concept of the needle exchange program for drug addicts. Preferably, the drugs would be used in the facilities and would not leave those places, or, as a second best, they could be provided in non-reusable single dose syringes. There is evidence that the use of intravenous and other drugs is principally influenced not by supply but by fashion and peer behaviour. Heroin use in the United States peaked in 1970, and has since declined. Cocaine use has also peaked in the United States and has now declined in that country. Supply limitation has not been responsible for these behavioural changes. Most Western countries, despite very considerable efforts by Customs and police agencies, have been markedly ineffective in damming the flow of the drugs.

Injectable drugs are relatively readily available. Those people who wish to inject themselves will do so. Should we not attempt to ensure that when those people do so they pose the least threat both to themselves and to society at large? The damage done to society by drug abuse extends also into the areas of minor and major crime, the costs of attempted crime prevention, criminal investigation and prosecution and punishment. It is well known that many drug addicts in Australia must obtain $100 to several hundred dollars per day to buy their drugs. Many drug addicts, both male and female, turn to prostitution to earn this money. This provides one direct route between homosexual and heterosexual people in the community via the intravenous drug use. Many other drug users turn to theft to provide money to buy drugs. A growing proportion of house breaking and theft of money and salable items is related to drug addiction. Experience seems to indicate that the capacity of our police forces is already inadequate to deal with this growing minor but very costly crime. This was something Senator Crichton-Browne referred to just yesterday, I believe in regard to Western Australia.

Some indication of what lies ahead is again given by United States experience. In some cities in the United States, 50 per cent of all criminal work is made up of drug indictments. Prisons are full and overflowing. Convicts must be released early to make way for new arrivals. It is no secret that intravenous drugs are available in gaols and that homosexuality is also reasonably common. Prisons are therefore likely to become a major source of spread of the AIDS virus back into the community.

Drug use and addiction must come to be viewed as a medical-social phenomenon requiring medical and social management, not criminal sanctions. There is good reason to believe that the same cultural restraints--
