SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to follow Senator Coulter in speaking to the urgency motion he has moved in the Senate this afternoon. At the outset I would like to make clear that the Government has no intention of legalising illicit drugs at this stage, although it would clearly see today's debate as a contribution to the community debate on this matter-a debate which it supports. However, I cannot possibly support the terms of Senator Coulter's motion. I was interested to hear his contribution because, to my surprise, he seemed to talk more about acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) than what I thought was the main thrust of his motion. The first part of his motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: The requirement for the Federal Government as a matter of urgency to supply injectable drugs to intravenous drug users so as to-

Then there follow four points. First, I wonder whether this is really a matter of urgency. An examination of the Government's record would convince anyone that this matter is something that the Government has taken very seriously over a number of years. There is a national campaign against drug abuse well established in this country. It covers many of the points alluded to by Senator Coulter. There is an AIDS program which is a fine example, if not an exemplary model, for other countries to follow in addressing the question of AIDS. There is the excellent strategy for all Australians to address AIDS in the policy discussion paper `AIDS: A Time To Care A Time To Act' which was tabled I think in both Houses this week. It fully canvasses the whole issue relating to AIDS and takes up many of the points that Senator Coulter has raised.

The Government's record in the community services and health portfolio of preventive and public health measures also indicates the way in which this Government has handled this question. Whether we are dealing with the drug problem or the related problems of health care, they are all matters that have been seriously addressed by government and are being seriously addressed. So I cannot allow the opening line of the motion which states that it is a matter of urgency: it is a matter of serious concern which is currently being addressed and has been addressed for quite some time and will continue to be addressed.

Senator Coulter asks that as a matter of urgency the Federal Government supply injectable drugs to intravenous drug users. Again, even without hearing the honourable senator's contribution I have to object to such broad terms. Is he talking of heroin? Is he also talking of cocaine? Would he include amphetamines? All of these drugs can be called injectable drugs and are certainly provided in that way. I have to object to the general terms of the motion because they are too vague. What is an `intravenous drug user'? Does the honourable senator mean occasional users? Does he mean addicts? I understand from what I know of the honourable senator that he distinguishes between an addict and an occasional drug user.

Again, I indicate why I do not support the motion. It is too vague. Even from a layperson's understanding of it, it is still open to disagreement. I do not believe, and neither does the Government, that at this stage any of the points that the honourable senator has alluded to and which I want to move to, can be properly addressed by making currently illegal drugs legal, though that is a matter of serious concern and both the National Advisory Committee on AIDS and the National Health and Medical Research Council are seriously addressing the problem. I will return to that point shortly.

Senator Coulter claimed that one of the reasons for proposing this motion is that taking these steps would help make drugs more safely available. Certainly, it should be of concern that if people are using drugs they use them safely. But the safe use of dangerous substances must not be confused with encouraging illegal activity. If people choose to become users of intravenous drugs we have to say first that we hope to encourage, treat, counsel and assist those people to change that choice and to go off drugs. But if they are using them we would like to see them used safely. I do not believe that is promoted necessarily by making currently illegal substances legal.

The point about the spread of AIDS which is particularly relevant to intravenous drug use is not what drug is being used in the syringe but that the syringe be clean. It is the passage of the virus by intravenous drug users, or needle users, no matter what is contained in the needle, that is the concern. For this reason the Government has placed very serious consideration on the points the honourable senator made-not about the substance but about the proper and clean use of all intravenous equipment, needles, materials, et cetera. The Government provides for the exchange of needles for drug users precisely to address the very points that the honourable senator so properly raised in this debate. I think we can distinguish between encouraging the clean and wholesome use of needles and so on by intravenous drug users so as to prevent the spread of AIDS and encouraging people to use intravenous drugs at all. We have to draw a very fine line. The Government is trying to manage that and I support the emphasis that it makes on this point. I endorse all the honourable senator's points about the spread of AIDS. It is a very grave matter. I do not believe everybody in the community is fully aware of that or of its potential to spread further in this country. We must also appreciate that, while IV drug users contribute to the spread of AIDS, that is certainly not the only way in which the AIDS virus is spread. To the extent that we can contain the spread by providing clean needles and assisting people to have clean equipment and so on, that is something the Government encourages. That is to be distinguished from legalising the currently illegal substances that go with the needles or are used in that way.

Senator Coulter alluded to major and minor crime. Both of those issues are very important and are clearly matters of concern. Any examination of this AIDS document, for example, let alone the drug campaign, will make it quite clear how comprehensively the Government is addressing this issue. Legal concerns and crime prevention are certainly part of both the drug campaign and the AIDS question. Again, there is very little evidence to suggest that if we made illicit substances licit we would reduce major crime. A lot of evidence suggests that major crime shifts to another area or another substance. I do not know that we can hold our breath on this and assume that even if it were done it would make an impact on major crime, although I expect that it would make some contribution to reducing minor crime.

There is a lot of evidence that people who turn to crime to maintain a drug habit have certainly committed crimes before they became drug users. That evidence is cited in some of the reports I have read prior to today's debate. It is also true that even if we did reduce the amount of minor crime associated with intravenous drug use that would not make a very big hole in minor crime in our country. I do not dispute Senator Coulter's points on that at all. If we can do anything at all to reduce crime that is to be encouraged. I do not believe that legalising currently illegal substances would make a major inroad into either major or minor crime. I am not sure that, even if it did, it would be sufficient to justify legalising those substances at this point.

My final comment in relation to this motion is to highlight the importance of bringing drug users into contact with treatment and counselling services. That is something I strongly endorse, but I dispute that this is the only or the best way to do it. To provide treatment services to people when they come to seek the substance that is causing their illness, at least in my head, creates a contradiction that is very difficult to get around. Certainly we should put people in touch with counselling services. The Government is aware of the importance of treatment and counselling services for drug users to the extent that some $56m has gone into increasing the number of such services on the ground in the community. The improved provision of services does have its effect. It is accepted particularly by those who are trying to deal with the problem of AIDS, for example, by working with people in the drug treatment and counselling area. Those community services have a very significant role to play not only in containing the spread of AIDS and assisting people with proper advice but also in trying to help people who decide to reduce their drug usage or to come off drugs altogether.

Again, I know the seriousness of this issue and I know of Senator Coulter's seriousness in trying to address it. I just have to say that ultimately I am not persuaded, one, that it is a matter of urgency or, two, that by legalising these substances we would make much impact on the points the honourable senator raised. Please let me make it clear that I strongly endorse the seriousness of the points Senator Coulter has brought to our attention in this debate, points that I hope my comments have supported. They will have to continue to be addressed because, as Senator Coulter properly pointed out, the problem of AIDS, let alone drug usage, is not going to go away. In fact, there is a lot of evidence that it will only increase in the next few years.

The Government, because it has seriously and comprehensively addressed these issues, has been able to anticipate the spread of AIDS in the next few years. I think that already we can see a slowing of the spread, even though one would be guarded in making that as an absolute claim. Australia's record in this area is something which we can be pretty proud of. One of the reasons it has been so good is that the Government has resisted the temptation to try to find simple or one-line solutions to a very complex area. That AIDS strategy clearly highlights just how many areas of government, how many areas of life and how many areas of the community are touched by the problem. They range from employment to economic management, insurance, occupational health and safety at work and superannuation, apart from all the issues of care and concern and provision of services for people as they become ill or discover that they are carriers. It is no easy problem to deal with and I do not believe that we should be tempted to find one-line solutions, or even small solutions as part of a very complex problem. I prefer to endorse the Government's approach, so at this stage there is no likelihood of endorsing illicit substances. The Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, at the Third National Conference on AIDS, stated:

You will all be aware of the current debate being conducted about the pros and cons of legalising illicit drugs, particularly heroin. While I believe this public discussion is healthy and should be encouraged, it is important that this not be allowed to confuse the AIDS and intravenous drug use issue. Again, it is not use of the illicit drug which causes someone to become infected by the virus, but the use of contaminated equipment to administer the drug. Legalising heroin is not a simple answer to this problem, and discussion of the issue must not be allowed to cloud the overriding need to educate intravenous drug users to abandon needle sharing behaviour.

I draw the Senate's attention to a press release issued by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) which addressed this issue. At that stage the Chairman of the NHMRC, Professor John Chalmers, was concerned that there had been a misunderstanding of what the NHMRC's recommendations had been in this area. He expressed concern that there was an understanding that the NHMRC had recommended legalisation of heroin as a means of controlling the spread of AIDS among intravenous drug users. He wanted to make it clear that the NHMRC had not said that. What it had said was:
Council endorsed a package of measures proposed by the Australian National Council on AIDS to address the problem of the spread of AIDS by IV drug users.

The package includes more education, counselling and rehabilitation programs, greater availability of syringes and needle exchange programs, making syringes, needles and bleach available in prisons, compulsory urine testing for drugs in prisons, AIDS testing of prisoners before release and the assessment of single use syringes.
One of the elements of the package is a study of the use of injectable drugs in a controlled situation. The nature of the drugs to be used and the design of the trial have not yet been determined.

In other words, any prospect of moving towards what is proposed in Senator Coulter's motion is down the line. It is being considered only as a prospect for a pilot study. I wanted to reinforce those remarks and that concern for adequate understanding of what was said by the NHMRC in this contribution to the debate. I take Senator Coulter's point that this is a serious matter. I believe that what he and others have said in this debate might be part of that continuing discussion in the community on this issue. It will not stop now. In fact, it will continue, I think, for many years. However, at this stage the Government will not support Senator Coulter's urgency motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This so-called urgency motion of the Australian Democrats has, unfortunately, like so many other issues raised by the Democrats, very much missed the mark. It is rather sad that they have moved such a motion today when only this week the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and the shadow Minister for health came to a bipartisan agreement in terms of what needs to be done for acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). We do not oppose the motion because we do not consider the AIDS issue important; in fact it is quite the reverse. We are most concerned about the whole AIDS blow-out. But giving more drug users more drugs to abuse is not a way of solving it. Sadly, Senator Coulter has made the assertion that if an injectable drug is freely available to abusers it will limit the spread of AIDS. What Senator Coulter fails to remember-Senator Crowley also reminded him-is that it is not the drugs that give people AIDS; it is the syringes that people use when injecting the drugs. Senator Coulter has alleged that such an initiative will reduce major and minor crime. Where is his evidence? There is no such evidence. Some professionals working in the area are expressing concern that it may actually do the reverse.

SPEECH.PARA: Intravenous (IV) drug abusers have been given access to the needle exchange programs. Those programs are particularly important. In some respects they go much further than many people in the community would see as desirable. The proposition creates concern about where it would stop. If authorities are going to provide free heroin, will they prevent the free supply of other injectable drugs, which I will not list again because Senator Crowley has listed them already? Still by far the greatest incidence of AIDS is found in the homosexual and bisexual community. This group constitutes 88 per cent of cases, and IV drug users only 0.9 per cent. I am not too sure why the Democrats and the Government are zeroing in on this side of it, as opposed to encouraging people to change their lifestyles and to try to get off drugs. Surely we as legislators should be doing more to encourage people to use drugs less and finding methods of getting users off their addictions as opposed to proposing a course of action that could do the reverse.

It must be recognised that a consequence of the free heroin proposal may well be the spread of drug abuse. That is the last thing that we want. I believe that it is wrong to make the assumption that once IV drug abusers are supplied with injectable heroin they will have less occasion to resort to illegally obtained drugs or to share needles. As with so many other assertions, there is no data to support the proposal that abusers would stop obtaining drugs illegally.

Another difficulty associated with the proposal is who decides what the abusers really need. It is quite conceivable that many abusers would overestimate their need and thereby obtain supplies of heroin which they may then sell illegally. This is particularly the case of take home doses. If they are to be permitted, the option is then available to share the oversupply. On the other hand, if the prescribing doctor underestimates the abuser's need there is still the incentive to obtain a supplement illegally. The fact behind that assertion is that that is exactly what is happening with some people on the legally provided methadone treatment program. That treatment is supplemented with illegally obtained heroin. There is also the logistics of the problem, which I do not think Senator Coulter addressed at all. Heroin is a relatively short acting drug. There may well be the necessity for abusers to get more than one dose, or shot-call it what we like-per day. That creates its own difficulties. In addition to that nothing has been said as to how the injecting of these drugs would be supervised. If it is not supervised the drugs could well be shared or given to others. Surely that is not what Senator Coulter is saying is highly desirable.

The other million dollar question is: How would such abusers be identified and do we give all abusers a free go or do we selectively choose, remembering that there are many positive users who are not, and many who will not be, identified? On the other hand, what would prevent every IV drug abuser from seeking to qualify for the free treatment? What really concerns me is that there seems to be a progressive approach to making drug prevention less important than making drug use safer. To me that opens a Pandora's box with absolutely frightening consequences.

It is interesting to note that the Director of Alcoholics and Narcotics Anonymous, Dr Jean Lennane, doubts the likely success of a free heroin campaign and is concerned about the consequences for the individuals involved. That is a particularly valid argument, considering that it leads towards people never being forced to solve their addiction without being confronted with the consequences of it. A number of specialists working with drug addicts and people generally in the community see this whole proposal as equating to giving alcoholics a free keg of beer on a daily basis. Once again, I do not think anyone would be stupid enough to come into this place and suggest that was the remedy for alcoholics. The essence of this motion has the potential of prolonging a person's addiction instead of combating it. Professor David Hawks, Director of the National Centre for Research into the Prevention of Drug Abuse, argues that users may obtain a supply of drugs that they would then sell illegally. He also went on to say in this month's issue of the Medical Journal of Australia:

. . . unless we can assume that intravenous drug users will share their needles less often if they are provided with heroin in an injectable form, the `cost' of making heroin available to some intravenous drug users may well outstrip the benefits.

I think that really sums it up, because the whole dreadful problem of AIDS is not going to be solved by quick fix methods which really amount to bandaids on the bucket. The subject needs more and more research and a much harder approach that is not influenced by apologists for any one section of the community. I consider the research expenditure to be not only desirable but essential and it is therefore of concern to me that the Federal Government has rejected calls for more funds by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC), with the Minister, Dr Blewett, simply saying that it too had to wear the responsibility of economic restraint. I might add that Dr Blewett also was forced to concede in a somewhat contradictory statement that financial cuts could have impact on the NHMRC, while the Council itself has predicted grave consequences.

I do not believe that Australia can any longer afford to pander to special interest groups, and nor should we for the sake of the health of this country. Drugs are well known to cause enormous suffering in our community and the use of such drugs should never be seen to be condoned by the Government. We should learn from the experience of other countries such as Britain and redirect our thinking toward a more comprehensive public education program.

This motion before the Senate today is not only grossly premature; it is ill thought out when put side by side with the facts as we know them. That is the great tragedy of it, because I think the Australian Democrats are very much unaware, even though Senator Coulter did refer to the discussion paper, of what is really involved with such a discussion paper. The discussion needs to take place in an unemotional climate and without foolish recommendations such as giving more drugs to drug abusers or, as I said before, such as giving more alcohol to alcoholics. The Opposition will not be supporting this motion. Considering the importance of this motion, I now move:
That the question be now put.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I presented to the Senate a petition praying that the Senate request the Australian Government to use its diplomatic influence to cease the oppression of Albanians in Yugoslavia and to bring peace to that nation. That petition was signed by only four petitioners. The four were all Australians of Albanian origin, and they are members of the Committee of the Albanian Community in Australia. But those four people had in fact collected over 2,000 names of other Australians of Albanian origin on the same petition. However, a meeting of the Committee decided not to hand to me for presentation the petition forms with those 2,000-plus signatures because the signatories feared reprisals against themselves and their families here in Australia from Australians of Yugoslav origin.

SPEECH.PARA: That such fear can exist in this nation of ours is almost unbelievable, and, much more to the point, it should surely be a matter of gravest concern to all Australians that such fear can exist amongst citizens of this most peaceful of nations. I urge the Government to look into this matter. It is of the gravest importance that we do all that is necessary to prevent the development of fear-ridden racial or ethnic minorities in Australia who bring to our soil the internal conflicts of their countries of origin.

However, that having been said, Australia, as a nation with a deservedly high reputation for human rights, cannot turn its back on gross violations of human rights in other nations. It is for this reason that I willingly presented to the Senate today the petition urging the Government to express its concern to the Government of Yugoslavia about the violation of human rights of Albanians in Yugoslavia. In addition to its human rights elements, the matter has direct relevance to all Australians in the sense that for centuries the Balkans has been a powder-keg which, when the fuse has been lit, has exploded on the whole world. One has only to recall Sarajevo and the resulting First World War to demonstrate that point with great force and clarity.

The evidence that I have indicates that for at least the past seven years the Albanian minority in Yugoslavia has been subjected to persecution and oppression by the Yugoslav authorities. The problem is centred on the province of Kosova, where the majority of the population is Albanian. Albanians are in fact Illyrians, one of the oldest European races, who have lived in the Balkans for more than 4,000 years. There are in the Balkans some six million Albanians. About half of these live within the boundaries of Albania proper, whilst the remainder live within the borders of Yugoslavia. In 1981 Albanian students at Kosova University took to the streets to protest against their living standards and what they saw as a lack of freedom for Albanians in Kosova province. The authorities called in the police and the armed forces and hundreds of students, including, I am told, small children, were killed. I am also told that since then oppression has continued unabated. Albanians, both within and outside Yugoslavia, have been assassinated, and the living standards of the Albanians have continued to fall and are now quite deplorable.

Albanians make up about 10 per cent of the population of Yugoslavia but, according to Amnesty International, 80 per cent of all political prisoners in Yugoslavia are Albanian. It was alleged recently in the Zagreb weekly paper, Danas, that 72 Albanian school children are in prison for political crimes. A member of the European Parliament recently stated:
The physical safety of every Albanian man, woman and child in Kosava is being put at risk.

An article in the Melbourne Age of 15 October last said that the Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic's anti-Kosava style is, according to his critics, `reminiscent to a Hitler or a Mussolini'. It is further alleged that since 1986 Albanian mothers in Yugoslavia are forbidden by state decree to have more than two children and that any more pregnancies are forcefully aborted. Today's press reports that public meetings have now been banned in Kosava and that this is aimed directly at the Albanians.

There are many other allegations of oppression, including the prevention of the teaching of the Albanian language and of the re-writing of history texts to exclude any Albanian history. The highly respected paper, the Christian Science Monitor, believes that there is a real danger of Yugoslavia `turning into Europe's Lebanon', in large part because of the situation with the Albanian minority.

Some of these allegations and others that I have not mentioned are contained in a letter written to the Secretary-General of the United Nations on 17 September this year by the Inter-Committee of the Albanian Community for Victoria. I seek leave to have the letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
To the Secretary General
of the United Nations
Dear Mr Secretary General,

The Albanian community in Australia have taken the liberty of addressing the highest Office of the United Nations Organisation, respectively, bringing to the attention of the Secretary General the following:
THE GENOCIDE OF THE GREATER SERB CHAUVINISM UPON ALBANIAN PEOPLE IN YUGOSLAVIA

More than seven years ago, Albanian Students in Kosova University, Prishtine (Yugoslavia), took to the streets to protest against the miserable living conditions and for more freedom for themselves and for the Albanian population. They were chanting: ``WE WANT BREAD'', ``TREPCA IS OURS'', ``KOSOVA REPUBLIC''.

Yugoslav authorities, instead of talking to them, and to find out the reasons for this discordant ordered the special police units and the armed forces with tanks, helicopters, gunships and machine guns who killed hundreds of unarmed students, even school children.

Today, seven and half years later, this killing has not stopped, but only changed the strategy of torturing and killing Albanians throughout Yugoslavia in the most mysterious way and assassinating Albanian intellectuals outside Yugoslavia (in exile).

After the peaceful demonstrations, Yugoslav authorities begun a campaign of mass arrests, jailing thousands and thousands of Albanians, sentencing them for up to 20 years imprisonment. According to Amnesty International, of all political prisoners in Yugoslavia, 80% are Albanians. On a wider scale, they follow the so-called POLICY OF DIFFERENTIATION which resulted in opening a new front in the field of crimes by Belgrade hegemonists upon defenceless Albanian inhabitants, manifested in the loss of their jobs, of thousands of Teachers, Professors, and workers, with the endeavour of provoking the Albanian people, the Belgrade ``Communists'' showed their true arrogance, and went thus as far as changing the Albanian National Flag, which is the greatest insult to the Albanian people and their history.

Oppressions against Albanians have surpassed even the ill-famed Rankovic era. School text books and courses have been revised, so that instead of learning the Albanian history and culture, they are now forced to learn Serbian history. Albanians in Macedonia, are being imposed to attend mixed classes with Macedonian speaking students, in this form, suspending their constitutional right to learn the Albanian language, to sing Albanian songs and to wear Albanian National Costumes.

Today, seven and half years after the bloodiest oppression of this tragic event which has no parallel in Europe since World War Two, the condition of more than 2.5 million Albanians in Yugoslavia, in the contrary the oppressive strategy of the Belgrade expansionist and opportunistic practices against Albanians has taken new perspectives and Montenegrians are gang organised by the greater Serb leaders in flaming a hatred against Albanian people using hysterical slogans such as ``DEATH TO ALBANIANS'', ``WE WANT WEAPONS'', WE ARE GOING TO KOSOVA'' and ``EVERY SERB MUST KILL AN ALBANIAN'' cursing Albanian mothers.

Two months ago a mass rally was organised in the Montenegrian Capital, Titograd, where more than 5,000 people, in front of the `Communist' leaders, drew their revolvers and showing them to the TV cameras . . . In so-called Communist Yugoslavia creating scenes like in the wild western movies and chanting continuously `DEATH TO ALBANIANS'.

By contrast, non-Albanian demonstrators in Belgrade in 1968 and these today against the Albanian people, did not result in the use of armed forces and brutal violence, but political compromise, once again however when Albanians conducted peaceful demonstrations for the status republic for Kosova in 1981, Albanian demonstrators were met by army torture and murder of hundreds of brothers and sisters. The non-Albanian participants in the former demonstrations, share heritage, language, culture and are well represented in the National Government. Albanians share none of the above, and thus are forced to function outside the system, or inside the Yugoslav prison walls, as such as the Kosovar Albanian writer Adem DEMACI, whom is serving over 26 years jail (Europe's MANDELA). As a result a potentially explosive situation has ensued as Serbians are calling for a return of practices of the ill-famed Rankovic's era and Albanians are becoming increasingly disillusioned with the policies of the State. Governmental discriminatory practices are exemplified by Yugoslavia's system of justice. Amnesty International reports that close to 30% of Yugoslavia's prisoners of conscience, person convicted of `verbal crimes'. (Something in Australia or America and many other countries, we would refer to as the practice of the inalienable right of free speech), are Albanians of the 35 prisoners put to death in Yugoslavia from 1981 to 1985, more than half were Albanians. Yet Albanians constitute only 9% of the Yugoslav population. Of the former convictions, many were based on Orwellian-like crimes: remarks in conversations and letters; drawings; joke telling; and even for singing. Typically prison terms for these `crimes' have ranged between one and 20 years. Indeed, Adem Demaci, a prominent Albanian author, has spent the last 27 years of his life in prison, for simple act of writing a pamphlet calling for the creation of the republic of Kosova. An extremely harsh sentence for a man who as a US Congressman Joseph DioGuardi describes, `never held a knife or gun, but only said what was in his heart'. Belgrade chauvinist oppression of Albanians extends beyond its borders, into foreign countries such as West Germany.

Where the Yugoslav secret police, the ill famed UDB-a, assassinated four Albanians including two brothers Jusuf and Bardhosh GERVALLA. The existing horrors in Yugoslavia have not gone unnoticed, in the United States of America however, as members of Congress, led by Joseph DioGuardi in the House of Representatives and Senators Bob Dole and Paul Simon in the US Senate, have introduced a resolution formerly protesting Yugoslavia's violation of human rights. This resolution calls for compliance with the Helsinki Final Act, which Yugoslavia signed and demands it take steps `To ensure that human rights and fundamental freedoms . . . are respected in regard to persons from all National and Ethnic Groups'. We the Australian citizens and residents of Albanian background, plead with the Australian Government and any other Government that gets this Memorandum to take example to the United States Congress and Senate. Violation of human rights in any nation whether adversary or orally should be condemned. As the member of the Democratic World, Australia has an obligation to confront Governments that engage in such violations with actions to influence change. In order for this to occur in a healthy political environment, the Australian people and all other peace loving people throughout the World must be informed of the existing situations so that conclusions can be drawn and representatives influenced accordingly. If the World disagrees the crimes occurring and likely to occur upon the Albanian people by Belgrade Chauvinists we may forget a very important reality that the Balkans is the powder-keg, where both world wars started . . .

Kosova is the poor house of Yugoslavia and Europe. Unemployment and standard of living is far worst of the Yugoslav average. Tens of thousand of Albanians and their families live below the poverty level. The Chauvinist Serbia is reaching the highest point against the Albanian history and cultural values. Albanians are sent into the streets on their jobs and are treated as scums. We are asking that the freedom loving people of Australia and the world to raise their voices and protest against this unparalleled corrupcy and injustice perpetrated by the Yugoslav Government. Albanians in Yugoslavia are asking for equality to have as much as other nationalities enjoy. They are asking for recognition of Kosova as a full pledge Republic free of Serbian tutelage and exploitation. Albanian people in Yugoslavia want to live in dignity and peace and harmony with other nationalities of the Yugoslav federation, free of oppression and persecution. We felt morally compelled to keep the UNO appeared to this situation.

Today seven and half years after we have seen no improvement force coming in that unfortunate land of Kosova we must therefore retaliate our efforts hoping that people of good-will assist the two and a half million Albanian people in Yugoslavia. Albanian community in Australia is also convinced that if constructive steps are to be taken, they will greatly benefit on improvement and stabilization of the situation in that area inhabited by Albanians in Yugoslavia and by extension, they will be seen to great contribution to peace in the Balkans. These steps are:-
1. The Territories inhabited by Albanians in Yugoslavia, being constituted by a Socialist Republic presenting the Albanians in Yugoslavia and therefore within the framework of the SFR of Yugoslavia.
2. Violence and terror by army and police forces must end immediately.
3. All political prisoners must be unconditionally released immediately and investigations must start to uncover the cases of these whom have mysteriously disappeared.
4. Albanians in exile to be left free of fear and not threatened with assassinations by the Yugoslav secret police and also to be allowed to return to their homes.
5. Albanian education, language, culture, art and history must be promoted to develop freely.
6. National resources of the region must be utilized to promote the local economic development of the region.

7. The entire political life of the region must develop on democratic principals. We also respectively request that the UNO take the initiative to explore the possibilities of a popular referendum in the areas involved as a just means of finding a solution to these difficult problems. With your help and ours, all this can be achieved prevailing upon the Yugoslav authorities to free themselves of dreadful chauvinism and the problems with understanding and justice. All this will contribute to a lasting key for security of Yugoslavia, Balkans and Europe.
With best regards,
THE INTER-COMMITTEE OF THE ALBANIAN COMMUNITY FOR VICTORIA, AUSTRALIA
MELBOURNE-17th of September, 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: —Included in the letter is reference to a resolution of the United States Congress protesting against Yugoslavia's violation of human rights and calling upon Yugoslavia to comply with the Helsinki Accords. I would hope that this Senate would be prepared to adopt a similar resolution. I propose to pursue this matter at an early opportunity.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 20 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government completed its drafting of the proposed treaty or compact with the Aboriginal people; if not, when will it be completed and ready for the approval of Aboriginal Australians.
(2) Will the Government make public a draft copy of the treaty or compact so that all Australians can comment on the proposed document; if so, when will it be made available; if not, why not.
(3) Will the Government recognised tribal sovereignty over tribal areas and/or tribal territories in the treaty or compact; if not, why not.

(4) Does the Federal Government grant excisions of land to Aboriginal people for the purposes of social, cultural, and economical progress in States other than the Northern Territory; if so, in which States is this done; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. When the Minister announced the Government's proposal for a compact he made it clear that it was important to consult extensively with Aboriginals. The Government has always indicated that it has no intention of rushing the task or of imposing its own will on Aboriginal people.

On 12 June the Prime Minister announced, at Barunga, that he would assist the process of Aboriginal consultation by a committee of seven elders. He envisaged that the wishes of Aboriginal people would be ready for negotiation with the Australian Government prior to the end of the life of the present Parliament.

(2) A number of proposals are being considered to allow the non-Aboriginal community to effectively participate in these negotiations. It is too early to indicate the proposed timing of such negotiations, or of the manner of participation by other Australians.

(3) The Government has made its position on sovereignty clear on a number of occasions. It is not negotiable. While I expect that the issue will be raised during the consultation process, those raising the issue will, once again, be informed of the Government's position.

(4) No. State Governments have responsibility for land title and the administration of pastoral and other leasehold land. The Western Australian State Government has granted a number of excisions to Aboriginal communities. There are few Aboriginal people living on pastoral properties in the other States, and the States have therefore determined that there is no need for the type of excision arrangements which apply in the Northern Territory.
